Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T6G-8161-JB20-G0VJ-00000-00President Trump Met Today with the 44 Sheriffs Representing 35 Counties in the White House Where the Association Gave Him a Plaque Recognizing His Work to Improve Law Enforcement in the Country; President Trump Brought Up the Controversial Bombshell that Came Out from an Anonymous "New York Times" Op-Ed Where He Says It's an Obvious Proof How Bias the Media is; Nike Not Giving Up on Colin Kaepernick in their New Ad Campaign Despite Some People Have Boycotted Their Product; Judge Brett Kavanaugh's Confirmation Hearing Today at the Hill Were Raucous and Many Were Arrested for Causing Some Chaos; Resistance In White House; New Uber CEO Talks to FBN; White House Aide Anonymous Op-Ed; DOW Closing 22 Points2018-09-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:39ZLexisNexisEVENING EDIT5:00 PM ESTMichael Lee, Lawrence Jones, Dara Khosrowshahi, Kayleigh McEnanyNEWSFinancial090501cb.233President Trump Met Today with the 44 Sheriffs Representing 35 Counties in the White House Where the Association Gave Him a Plaque Recognizing His Work to Improve Law Enforcement in the Country; President Trump Brought Up the Controversial Bombshell that Came Out from an Anonymous "New York Times" Op-Ed Where He Says It's an Obvious Proof How Bias the Media is; Nike Not Giving Up on Colin Kaepernick in their New Ad Campaign Despite Some People Have Boycotted Their Product; Judge Brett Kavanaugh's Confirmation Hearing Today at the Hill Were Raucous and Many Were Arrested for Causing Some Chaos; Resistance In White House; New Uber CEO Talks to FBN; White House Aide Anonymous Op-Ed; DOW Closing 22 PointsElizabeth MacDonald, Blake Burman, Andrew Napolitano, Lawrence Jones, Mike Lee, Susan Li, Nicole Petallides

(JOINED IN PROGRESS)

DAVID ASMAN, FOX NEWS HOST: "THE EVENING EDIT" starts right now.

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX NEWS HOST: We're staying on that breaking news. That rare move by "New York Times" to publish an anonymous op-ed by a quote, "senior official inside the White House in D.C." Saying there is a quite resistance within the administration of people choosing to put country first.

And that the cabinet earlier has discussed invoking the 25 amendment to remove the president. We've got immediate reaction from Kayleigh McEnany of the RNC coming up.

And we are awaiting the president to come out during a meeting with sheriffs. He may comment on this anonymous op-ed.

And big tech taken to the woodshed on Capitol Hill. Senators threatening the government will take action to regulate social media like Facebook, Twitter, and Google. The Justice Department now looking into claims of conservative censorship on social media. More on that story.

Another day of chaos, more protests during day two of Kavanaugh's hearing. We've got the highlights. We are monitoring the ongoing hearing.

Plus, a Fox Business exclusive. Tonight, Uber CEO here to talk to Susan Li. He has to prove to Wall Street that Uber is ready to go public despite a deluge of controversy and scandal.

And a story flying under the radar, President Trump plans to chair a U.N. Security Council meeting to take on Iran. You heard me right. The U.N., a place that President Trump has blasted for wasteful spending and ineffectiveness. We've got that story.

Well, thank you so much for joining us. Thank you for watching. Money, politics, we've got the debate behind tomorrow's headlines. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. The Evening Edit starts right now.

First to your money, the Dow closing slightly higher, ending the day at 25,974. The NASDAQ and the S&P falling. Netflix lead a steep tech sell-off. More on your money in just a second.

But first to that "New York Times" anonymous op-ed, it appears to be written by a male senior official, that's according to the Times Twitter account.

With me now live from White House is Blake Burman with the latest. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hi, there, Liz. Don't know exactly who this person is, the New York Times op-ed page in which this article is published, identifies as person as a senior administration official. The title here is, quote, "I am part of the resistance inside the Trump administration."

When you boil down this op-ed this person says that themselves along with others are working inside the Trump administration to essentially keep it on track as they see it. This is what the senior administration official writes anonymously in this op-ed at one point.

Quote, speaking of the president, "The dilemma - which he does not fully grasp, is that many of the senior officials in his own administration are working diligently from within to frustrate parts of his agenda and his worst inclination."

This anonymous senior administration official also goes on to write in that op-ed the following. Quote, "Given the instability, many witnessed there were early whispers within the cabinet of invoking the 25 amendment which would start a complex process for removing the president. But no one wanted to precipitate a constitutional crisis, so we will do what we can to steer the administration in the right direction until one way or the other it is over."

We need to point out, Liz, that this person is identified as a senior administration official, so we don't know if that person works within this very White House or if they are an official within the Trump administration somewhere here in Washington D.C.

The president is here about to speak inside the White House right now, Liz. Let's listen in.

(APPLAUSE)

THOMAS HODGSON, SHERIFF, BRISTOL COUNTY, MASSACHUSETTS: Great job, keep up the good work. Thanks, everybody.

Mr. President, we remember when you first were giving your acceptance speech of the nomination at the GOO convention, you said at that time that one year from now when I take over the White House I am going to reestablish the rule of law in this country, and you have done that, Mr. President. We thank you for that.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Thank you.

HODGSON: Very, very much.

TRUMP: Thank you.

HODGSON: You know, behind me, Mr. President, are 44 sheriffs, who are representing 35 states that came here to Washington for two reasons. The first is to go to Congress to the Capitol today hold a press conference and let Congress know enough is enough.

We've been for 20 years, asking Congress to move on the security aspects of immigration reform, and nothing has happened for 20 years.

But what's really amazing, Mr. President, with your strength and purpose the commitment to your convictions you've done more in less than two years in supporting law enforcement and dealing with this illegal immigration problem that we've been asking for solutions on in less than two years.

And again, all these sheriffs and sheriffs across the nation are grateful to you for that, Mr. President.

(APPLAUSE)

HODGSON: And like so many of the promises that you made, you have come through and the energy that you put behind law enforcement in supporting us on our partnership with 287G, going after MS-13 and getting them out of our neighborhoods, t building the wall, Mr. President, you've really did amazing.

And so, before I president this plaque I just want to add one thing that maybe you heard about, maybe you didn't. But when we were on the Hill today, we announced that the National Sheriff Association has done a crowd funding page to raise money and mobilize the citizens of this nation to get behind you, to get behind the sheriffs to build this wall.

So, in having said that, I would like to present this to you, Mr. President, because, it's not surprising for any of the sheriffs who are here, that shortly after you took office, people started saying the citizens and members of the media saying, there is a new sheriff in town.

And that's an endearing statement, and all these sheriffs know it. Because what it denotes is that there are problems and somebody is coming in that's going to be able to fix those problems. You've done that, Mr. President, we can't thank you enough for your support, you said you have our back. And the sheriffs across this nation, have yours. And God bless you. Thank you, Mr. President.

(APPLAUSE)

TRUMP: Well, that's really nice. This is an honor because when I was running I think number one on our list of law enforcement, taking care of law enforcement, working with law enforcement.

And really we have to create guidelines and principles for the incredible job you've done, and you've done an amazing job.

And I will tell you, a lot of times you are scorned and you are looked at by the media, because the media is very dishonest, much of it in this country, very, very dishonest. And the job that you've done in light of all the things that you have to go through, I guess a little bit like me also, but I will say that you have been really outstanding, incredible people.

Crime statistics are down. We're really doing well other than you take a couple of places on a nation where they have different policies than we would put, and you know where I'm talking about.

But there are a couple of places they don't believe in what we believe, but we have together done something very special.

I also remember so well, sheriff, when we were together, I said we're going to get a lot of military equipment that you weren't able to get and it was sitting in warehouses all over the country.

And in many cases like in other countries, you remember, and we brought it back home, and you were able to get great military equipment that you couldn't afford to buy in your budgets and we gave it to you and it protected a lot of people.

We have a lot of people living today in your profession that would not frankly be around right now without the protection of that kind of equipment that we have sitting around, waiting and doing nothing, and just drawing dust.

So, the fact that you gave me this award is very meaningful. I will put that in a place of great honor in the Oval Office. But I really appreciate it. Thank you very much, it's a great honor. Thank you.

(APPLAUSE)

TRUMP: Thank you, all.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Thank you very much.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Mr. President, keep up the good work.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We stand behind you.

(CROSSTALK)

BURMAN: Liz, you are hearing the President of United States at an event with sheriff officers here inside the White House. One of the big question is whether or not the president will answer any questions from the press pool inside that event. Of course the biggest question will be about this New York Times op-ed.

I'll send it back to you in case you want to (Inaudible) the president.

MACDONALD: Blake, and we are going to need you to monitor the press pool, we want to know what are the questions, and what the president says about this anonymous bombshell op-ed by a senior White House official.

Apparently, a man, who is alleging a bunch of things about the president, including that there were early whispers that amongst cabinet members to evoke the 25 amendment to remove President Trump.

Thank you, Blake. You're going to stay on that story for us throughout the hour.

Let's bring in Fox News senior judicial analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. You read the op-ed. What's your reaction?

ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: Well there obviously are substantial forces very close to the president that candidly do not believe he's fit for office. This is calling a bombshell, which is the phrase that you used is actually being charitable.

I mean, this devastating to the president, the president should have around him people who believe in him and trust him. This is obvious somebody who he thinks believes in him and trust him who has revealed a consensus amongst those around him that question his fitness for office. And it was also revealed that there were serious discussions about the 25th amendment.

MACDONALD: You know, so in the piece, whoever the writer is said we want the administration to succeed. They bring up that the president is in their mind, anti-trade an anti-democratic. They say the root of the problem is the president's immorality he's not more to discern with first principle, and that he acted in a manner detrimental to the health of the Republican.

NAPOLITANO: That is a serious an allegation as could be. That is a code phrase for worthy of impeachment. If he is acting in the opinion of this writer whoever it is.

MACDONALD: OK.

NAPOLITANO: Acting in a manner injurious to the health of the republic.

MACDONALD: And as Melissa Francis has said pointed out earlier in the hour, opinions usually, you own the opinion with your name on it. Let's listen to the president.

TRUMP: -- working today that at any point ever in our history. We've created 400,000 manufacturing jobs. Manufacturing jobs are growing at the fastest pace in more than 30 years, economic growth last quarter was 4.2 percent.

And as you people know it was headed down, big, and it was a low number, very low number. It would have been, in my opinion, it would have been less than zero, it was heading to negative numbers.

New employment claims recently hit a -- think of that. The unemployment picture in the country is the best it has been in 49 years, African- American unemployment is lowest in the history of the country.

Asian-American unemployment lowest in the history of our country, Hispanic- American unemployment lowest in the history of our country.

I mean, I'm just looking at this point after point. Under my administration, veteran's unemployment reached its lowest in many years. The -- let's see, almost 3.9 million Americans have been lifted off food stamps just since my election.

Then you go into all of the benefits that we got from the tax cuts, all of you people benefitted tremendously from the tax cuts.

(APPLAUSE)

TRUMP: We're going to regulation cuts, we're going to right to try, right to try is where you have right is if a person is terminally ill you have a right to go and try and see whether or not a drug that's not approved yet can be used. They didn't allow that.

A point after point we're getting rid of the individual mandate, the most unpopular thing there is in Obamacare. Coming up with new healthcare plans.

We've never had a period, even if you look at the Olympics, we got the Olympics, the World Cup, you say them, they were in my office, got the World Cup, nobody has -- and we have started the wall. Nobody has ever done in less than a two-year period what we've done.

So when you tell me about some anonymous source within the administration, probably it was failing and probably here for all the wrong reasons, no. And the New York Times is failing. If I weren't here I believe the New York Times probably wouldn't even exist.

(APPLAUSE)

TRUMP: And some day -- and some day when I'm not president, which hopefully will be in about six and a half years from now. The New York Times and CNN, and all of these phony media outlets will be out of business, folks. They'll be out of business because they'll be nothing to write, and they'll be nothing of interest.

So nobody has been what this administration has done. And I agree, it's different from an agenda which is much different than ours, and it's certainly not your agenda, that I can tell you.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thank you.

TRUMP: It's about open borders, it's about letting people flee into our country, it's about a disaster and crime for our country.

So, they don't like Donald Trump, and I don't like them, because they are very dishonest people. Remember this also, about the New York Times, when I won they were forced to apologize to their subscribers. They wrote a letter of apology it was the first time anybody has ever done it because they covered the election incorrectly.

So if the failing New York Times has an anonymous editorial -- can you believe it, anonymous, meaning gutless, a gutless editorial -- we are doing a great job. The poll numbers are through the roof. Our poll numbers are great.

And guess what, nobody is going to come close to beating me in 2020 because of what we've done. We've done more than anybody ever thought possible in - - it's not even two years. So thank you very much. We appreciate it.

(APPLAUSE)

MACDONALD: OK. That was President Trump taking on directly this anonymous op-ed in the New York Times that is quoting a senior White House official - - let me back up, it was written by a senior White House official. We at Fox Business believe it a man, according on the New York Times own Twitter account he is identified as a he, the author of this anonymous piece.

Let's bring the judge back here. You saw the president really going hard at New York Times with his comments that, basically the Times is failing according to his mindset and that it wouldn't exist without him and when he is going to -- he says he is going to be here for six an half more years. And CNN and New York Times may not exist then.

NAPOLITANO: Well, I thought that his impromptu response now was actually a pretty good one. If he started to go through line by line the anonymous op- ed a, he is going to give it more credibility than he wants to give it, and b, he is going to find himself going down rabbit holes of attempting to retort anonymous allegations which are incendiary, in which he doesn't want to give the credence to.

MACDONALD: You know, the other thing the president brought up which is interesting is about the New York Times letter of apology that New York Times wrote to its readers about -- I guess people are trying to contact you about this op-ed that basically--

(CROSSTALK)

NAPOLITANO: This is not from the author of the op-ed. I don't think it is.

MACDONALD: That is, it looks like I'm looking at the New York Times apology letter to readers after the election. Basically, the New York Times is taking accountability for the coverage, because they too were surprised that Trump won. What do you make of President Trump bringing up the Times apology letter to readers there?

NAPOLITANO: Well, it's the Trump strategy, go on the offensive, he is not going to dignify this op-ed piece or New York Times by going through it line by line, he is going to attack the messenger here.

MACDONALD: OK. Judge--

(CROSSTALK)

NAPOLITANO: The 25th amendment is something that in my view can only be invoked if a vice president personally authorizes it, not going to happen.

MACDONALD: All right. Wow. We've got an hour of thick and fast breaking news. Judge, thank you so much for your insights here.

NAPOLITANO: You're welcome.

MACDONALD: The anti-Trump resistance movement in the White House. We're staying on story of this anonymous current senior Trump official in the White House writing that New York Times op-ed. We're going to have more on that story after the break, stay there.

MACDONALD: Moments ago, addressing that anonymous New York Times op-ed by a senior official within the administration while talking with the nation's sheriffs at White House.

Let's talk more with the judge more about what happened with that op-ed. It says a senior official, that's a pretty elastic term. It could be anybody in the executive branch.

NAPOLITANO: Right. As our colleague Blake Burman just pointed out, it could be anybody in the executive branch which means all around the world. You're talking about the diplomatic correlate the military, the State Department, it sounds to me. And I read this now three or four times as though it's somebody who works daily with the president and interacts with them daily, which means somebody in the West Wing.

But I don't want to begin speculation because the speculation I could tell you from my iPhone is rampant with proper names in there and I'm not going to go because it's just speculation.

But it does sound as though this is a human being that knows the president well and interacts with him on a daily basis.

MACDONALD: You said it's the one two punch because we have a Bob Woodward book coming out.

NAPOLITANO: Well, the Bob Woodward book is been excerpted in the Washington Post. He is an editor and a reporter for the Washington Post with two Pulitzer Prizes who notoriously tape records every conversation he has every interview that he has.

MACDONALD: Currently there are recording for that.

NAPOLITANO: Correct. So the one-two punch is the Washington Post and the New York Times same time same subject, same week. This is more ganging up on a president than they did on Richard Nixon. And as I said before--

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: And have you ever seen an anonymous op-ed.

NAPOLITANO: No, I've never seen or heard of an anonymous op-ed which means the New York Times wants to keep this person employed there. So this person can be a source for them as this person obviously was in tomorrow's paper.

MACDONALD: That's an interesting take on it. Yes. So, here's the thing. We may have New York Times reporter trying to crack and find out who this person is.

NAPOLITANO: What if the New York Times would let its own reporters figure out who this person is.

MACDONALD: Yes. All right. Gang, in the control room where fast and thick news breaking in this hour. Do we want to get the judge's reaction on Judge Kavanaugh.

So, let's -- I want your reaction to the sound bite, judge. Let's watch what happened at that Judge Kavanaugh's hearing today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Justice Jackson--

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Ask them to suspend.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Your reaction to the protest and disruption.

NAPOLITANO: The protest and distraction are a sideshow. The senators didn't lay a glove on him today. They attempted to but they didn't. Now much of the questioning was boring. Some of that was highly academic and really into the weeds except for people that monitor the stuff.

But politically speaking, the consensus is he's worthy of confirmation and will more likely than not receive it.

MACDONALD: Judge Napolitano, thank you so much.

NAPOLITANO: You're welcome.

MACDONALD: Really rolling with the breaking news with us. OK. We've got this story for you coming up. Despite fans threat to boycott, Nike is doubling down on Colin Kaepernick. The new ad will air tomorrow night at the launch of the NFL season. It isn't just do it ad campaign. It is coming tomorrow night. We're going to have that debate coming up after the break. Stay there.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

COLIN KAEPERNICK, FORMER NFL PLAYER: MACDONALD: Believe in something even if it means sacrificing everything.

When they talk about the greatest team in the history of the sport, make sure it's your team.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right. That's just part of Nike's new just do it ad campaign, featuring Colin Kaepernick. It is set to debut during the NFL season open tomorrow night. It's featuring athletes who have overcome adversity.

Now social justice warrior Kaepernick he launched the anthem protest by first taking a knee. Nike's stock took a knee too, a loss nearly $4 billion in market value after this ad news broke under threats of boycotts from customers.

The tag line sacrificing everything now also being criticized. Here are the facts. Kaepernick earned $43 million from the NFL, millions more coming his way from this new advertising campaign.

Now Colin Kaepernick has not played in two years, he is suing the NFL for alleged collusion, claiming no team will hire him. The NFL offering a measured response ahead of tomorrow's kick-off. Saying quote, "The social justice issues that Colin and other professional athletes have raised have deserve our attention and action."

Now a new report says Nike stock may drop further, maybe 10 percent due to these ads.

Let's take it up with Investmark Advisory Group principal, Michael Lee, and conservative commentator, Lawrence Jones. Mike, Nike specifically decided to hire Kaepernick not for his athleticism but for his political views. What does that mean for Nike's bottom line that it is now face of NFL national anthem protest?

MICHAEL LEE, PRINCIPAL, INVESTMARK ADVISORY GROUP: So, Nike just decided to get political, not only get political, they decided to shove a certain brand of politics down everyone's throat.

I do not think this is a good decision for any corporation regardless of the politics. Colin Kaepernick has every right to be a social justice warrior, to kneel during the anthem.

But let's face it. His politics are that he hates America, and he hates law enforcement. That not popular. That is not going to go over well with large swaths of the population. And I think Nike has permanently damaged its brand.

MACDONALD: So, you know, here's the thing, Lawrence Jones, there is a question of do millennials like this, is the Nike playing to millennials, that millennial like to protest according to polls. I mean, one marketing group says Nike got tens of millions of dollars worth of free media exposure.

But here's the other side of that, Lawrence. Critics say Nike is charging $100 plus for fancy sneakers made by poor workers in Asia earning a lot low pay, it then uses the profit to pay millions to athletes like LeBron James or Kaepernick. Your take in all of this.

LAWRENCE JONES, CONSERVATIVE COMMENTATOR: Yes, Liz. This is complicated because I have conflicting views, on one hand you want a private business to be able to do whatever they want and then suffer the consequences that may come. But I think when it comes with Nike, I don't even think it about politics for them, I don't even think they care about social justice, I think that they just made a business decision, and they felt like getting behind this Colin Kaepernick movement would somehow benefit them. Remember when Colin Kaepernick left the league and he was a superstar at that point, he was the number one failing jersey at the time because he decided to take a knee.

The men was on the bench was still the number one jersey and so I think they plan on capitalizing on this, some way, I don't know how it will turn up even the President of United States, who has been very vocal on this issue pivoted on this issue, because as he said, Nike pays a lot of rent. And so he has been more critical in past, but because there a business investment there, he kind of backed off some of his criticism.

MACDONALD: Yes, you know, to Lawrence's point, Michael, Nike, it looks like making a bet, that its biggest gross market is China, it is Asia, they don't care about the U.S. protest over there, I mean, 40 percent of Nike's sale comes from the very (inaudible) of North America and Nike's biggest athletes in its ads are basketball players like Michael Jordan, Kobe Bryant and LeBron James, not football games.

JONES: LeBron James.

LEE: yes, I would say that very conspicuous timing here, this is coming out the day that tariffs go into effect in China. A lot of their products is made over there. That is the biggest opportunity for growth so a little bit of anti-American sentiment might go a long way to sell some more sneakers over there.

MACDONALD: Mike and Lawrence, you had been great tonight. Thank you so much for coming in.

JONES: Thank you, Liz.

MACDONALD: OK. We are staying on this story about the anti-Trump resistance movement in the White House that is allegedly anonymous. Current senior Trump official in the White House writing a New York Times Op-ed, saying he is working against President Trump. This is a story that is now being questioned, because who exactly is the author. And why did the Times run an anonymous opinion piece? We are staying on this for you.

But first, an exclusive one-on-one interview with Uber's new CEO is next, coming up.

MACDONALD: Well, we have an exciting exclusive interview coming up. Our own Susan Li sat down with Uber's new boss, Dara Khosrowshahi, who is now in the fight of his life. He has to clean up Uber's toxic image, just one of the scandals we give any executive a cold sweat. Hundreds of thousands of customers deleting Uber's app and protest over its pricing. Uber's Freight House executive culture leaning to charges, and settlements for alleged sexual harassment and discrimination and cities like New York and London blocking Uber drivers, Uber testing of a self-driving car also killed a pedestrian, Susan Lee is all over the story. You know, Uber, still had the biggest fight of his life. Are they kind of prove to Wall Street that can be profitable? This is a story filled with scandal.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESSES: There is a lot of different angles to it and Dara has been in job for one year. Just one year, 12 months and he had a lot to fix. Today in midtown Manhattan it was all about safety that is the focus, that is what they are here to do, there are some new safety features that includes tracking your ride. If it takes a little bit longer to get there, if you make an executive stops, Uber will now check in, that is what they call the new ride check in feature. Also they are going to make it your locations, your drop off, your phone numbers anonymous, so that means drivers cannot tell where you are going, they can't reach you in the future. But yes, we talked about IPO, we talked about liberal bias. And let's listen in to -- first of all his thoughts on this new safety features.

(BEGIN VIDEO)

DARA KHOSROWSHAHI, CEO, UBER: When you have 15 million trips on a daily basis on a global platform, such as ours. The vast majority of time is everything is OK. But once in a while something happens, and we as a company leadership got together last year and we declared that safety is going to be top priority for us as a company in 2018.

LI: Why.

KHOSROWSHAHI: Frankly beyond -- because safety is universal, because anyone who is at home or they are home or going to a ball game or going to work, you want to feel safe. And we believe that we can use the power of technology and the innovation that we have brought to bear to revolutionized transportation to make Uber the safest transportation platform on earth. And what you are seeing is very early in the game. But, features such as 911 button that location aware so that 911 dispatch can react to anything that might happen incredibly quickly with a huge determine and success or failure. Trust the contact, tracking where you are going, and improve background checks and continuous background checks as well, both available for riders and drivers.

And now some of the new future, that were introducing privacy, for example, you may not want a driver partner to know the exact address where you are dropped off, because that is something private, location information is incredibly important, we have masked that, and we masked your phone number if you ever speak to your driver partner and then we have introduced some really cool wiz ban technology, where we know where you started, we know where you ended, we know how long your trip should take, and if for some reason your trip is taking longer than it should, we will send you a notification to make sure that you are OK, and in some cases, we can actually detect an accident, if it ever happens to again make sure the rider and driver partner are OK too.

LI: You are mining a lot of data off of driver and the passenger's smartphone, in terms of speed, where they are going, how do you assure that user data is safe?

KHOSROWSHAHI: I think it is a great question. We made very significant investments in data privacy, we do know a lot of data about payment information and location information, but the religion, at Uber is that we are going to use that information for you the rider or the driver. So, for example, in the morning now my (inaudible) that in mornings I go to work, so it is one click. It is one click, we have an idea where you are going, but ultimately we're not selling data, we don't have any advertising, et cetera. So ultimately the use of data is to make life easier for you, to make it faster, to make it more affordable, and now, to make riding on an Uber safe as possible we can.

LI: So, you are celebrating your one near anniversary as CEO.

KHOSROWSHAHI: Yes I am. I made it.

LI: You made it. That is very true, now people want to know, are you still sticking with your timeline of an IPO in perhaps 2019, because you are new CFO who will start in a few days.

KHOSROWSHAHI: I would be starting next week, yes.

LI: Nelson, he says he is not on board yet though for 2019 Mustang.

KHOSROWSHAHI: I would expect nothing less of Nelson, he is independent minded, he is rigorous, and so far he is on the outside, so I think, I absolutely want Nelson to come in and I think that when he sees all of the work that the teams are doing, I think that he will agree that we're ready for a 2019 IPO, there is a bunch of systems first that is going on, financial work that is going on, the company is big enough, the company is incredibly important to the world. And we have some incredibly talented technologists out there, so, I think we are going to be ready, but I absolutely want that stamp of approval from our CFO.

LI: Yes, there is always a but. (Inaudible) The thinking on street, if they IPO before you, they would take up all the IPO capital in the market, are you concerned?

KHOSROWSHAHI: I'm not concern. This is Lyft and ourselves are part of a transportation revolution this is about ultimately ending car ownership, the transportation market is 6 trillion dollar business, you may think that Uber's big. We're 50 billion, we account for less than 1 percent of miles driven, and really what ourselves and Lyft are trying to do is to break apart all the use cases of owning a car. You owned a car, you get to work, and you owned a car to pick up the kids at school. You owned a car to get groceries, etcetera and we're building out services to solve each of those use cases and ultimately make it unnecessary for you to own a car. And we think that there are plenty of companies who can be a part of that evolution. I think investors are going to line up behind us and Lyft. I certainly hope they are.

LI: Are you guarantee a 2019 IPO?

KHOSROWSHAHI: Well, there is no guarantee, you don't know what the market is doing. I can guarantee that we'll be ready, hopefully markets will be ready for us.

LI: So, you talk about how big Uber is and the ride hailing services. Some say you owned 73 percent of the market, given that the U.S. President has talked about anti-trust situation with big tech company, Google, Amazon and Facebook. Do you think that big tech company like Uber may be regulated in the future?

KHOSROWSHAHI: Listen, we're regulated now. We work in every single city and et cetera. We look at market as 6 trillion dollar transportation market, we're a tiny, tiny, tiny part of the market, and we account for less than 1 percent of miles driven on the road. So, I think Uber can be ultimately 20, sounds bigger than it is today.

LI: So, no fear of being broken up at all?

KHOSROWSHAHI: No fear of being broken up and listen, I think that ultimately, regulators are our partners, you know, we work with -- we operate on the streets of New York City and while we may not agree on everything, ultimately we think that we as a transportation service are incredibly valuable for every city around. And that ultimately we have a be partners in building this solution together. It takes dialogue, sometimes you agree, sometimes you don't agree, but we think that opportunity is enormous, and we think there is a need for rider and drivers around all around the world for or service.

LI: Well, talking with our audience, you know, there has been a lot of concern of political bias in Silicon Valley. There are giants, respectable (inaudible) at Silicon Valley, so I have to ask you this question, President Trump thinks that there is a liberal bias in Silicon Valley with big tech companies, employees of big tech companies, and so that they feel that their conservatives voices have been silenced. You think that is true?

KHOSROWSHAHI: I guarantee that your wait times for your Uber are going to be equal whether you're Republican or not or Democrat. I don't think -- I think that biases, if there's a bias, I don't think that is a bias on purpose. We as a company's leadership team have been trained on biases as well. There are some implicit policies that you may not be aware of as a person and I think awareness is step one. So I don't think that there's any bias on purpose, but if you have a bunch of like-minded people building product, you may get product that straight one or the other. That's one for sample from our standpoint, we want to have more women. We want to have more underrepresented people working as engineers and product people and have representation at all parts of our company so that the products that were building reflect our driver partners in our rider partners and aren't with any biases that were not aware of. So, listen, we are human, all of this is vulnerable. I think that all of these companies are trying to do the right thing, but they got some learning to do. And I think the way that they operate going forward have to change.

LI: Dara, thank you so much.

KHOSROWSHAHI: I appreciate it.

(END VIDEO)

MACDONALD: that was a great interview. Are they going to go public? Uber is going public?

LI: I would be surprised if they did not.

MACDONALD: Next year.

LI: Next year 2019.

MACDONALD: Wow. Great interview, Susan. Thanks for bringing it to us.

LI: Thank you.

MACDONALD: OK. We're staying on this anti-Trump resistant movement in the White House, it has been somewhere in the executive branch, we don't know if it is in the White House, is some of the executive branch. Stay with us here for time of the anonymous op-ed story for you. Kayleigh Mcenany is coming up.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The failing "New York Times" has an anonymous editorial, can you believe it? Anonymous. Meaning gutless. Gutless editorial. We're doing a great job, the poll numbers through the roof, our poll numbers are great, and guess what nobody is going to come close to beating me in 2020, because of what we've done. We have done more than anybody ever thought possible in -- it is not even two years, so thank you very much, appreciate it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: That was President Trump, just moments ago refuting "New York Times" anonymous op-ed from someone allegedly in the administration said that person and others are working against the President. The op-ed writer say and we had identify him as a he. Actually New York Times did in a tweet saying he is a he, quote, I am part of the resistance under the Trump administration and said they work for President, and they unlike my colleagues and have vowed to thwart parts of President Trump's agenda and his worse quote, his worse inclination. Let us get RNC spokesperson, Kayleigh Mcenany joins me now, over the phone, Kayleigh what do you hear from your people on who they think wrote it?

KAYLEIGH MCENANY, REPUBLICAN NATIONAL COMMITTEE SPOKESPERSON: Hi, Liz. Great to join you, I don't think there is any indication at-this-point as who wrote it -- who wrote the op-ed, but I can give you a description of them, he is a coward. He is an absolute coward to leak in this fashion, to write anonymously in this fashion, to come out and say that he wants this agenda and this administration to succeed and write an op-ed. In direct contradiction of anything that would behoove this administration. This person called himself an unsung hero, I don't know who he is, but he is a coward, he is very far from an unsung hero.

MACDONALD: You know Kayleigh, the debate now is up though New York Times and the Washington Post or another news outlet would run it but here -- I want you reaction to this. Some are very unimpressed by this. Walter Schaub, he is a former director of the office of Government ethics. He said this op-ed is ridiculous on so many levels. We now present an opinion piece with no substantive content by an anonymous contributor who no employer should ever trust again. Your reaction.

MCENANY: Yes, he is absolutely spot on here. What a great mistake by the New York Time, the media and newspaper are already out of his story low and trustworthiness among the American people. In fact they hit their lowest approval rating in the history of Gallup asking the question. But for the New York Times to run with a fake news story from a fake news source, we don't even know if this individual really exists, this is a big hit to their credibility, President talks about making up sources, well this certainly looks a lot like that.

MACDONALD: You know, Walter Shaub of the government ethics former official satirize this op-ed saying, dear America, in other words, this is the tone of the anonymous op-ed, quote dear America, this administration is wonderful but I'm trying to so sabotage from the inside also be super afraid and no you owe me. Your take.

MCENANY: Yes. That is right, this is a quiet resistant on how it is described, from inside the administration, their goal to frustrate part of the agenda is what he said frustrate parts of the agenda.

MACDONALD: We have to leave it there, Kayleigh, sorry, we had a hard break. Kayleigh Mcenany weighing in. We will have Kayleigh on soon on another show. More on this story and your money after the break, stay there

MACDONALD: You know what, how is your money doing today. Let us take a check on your money, the markets finishing and here is our finish the DOW up to 22 points. Let us get right Nicole Petallides on the floor of the big board with latest, Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK: Stocks finished mixed, the DOW is higher, the S&P and NASDAQ hold back, you saw the worries about trade and tariffs and emerging market. And we have job reports on Friday, the NASDAQ though was a big loser, in fact it got crash on 1.1 percent. While the others were not too far off from the unchanged line. As you look at the NSADQ, you can break down social media stocks today, as we heard testimony from Jack Dorsey of Twitter, and Sandburg from Facebook, and with that this group got hit hard, we saw Facebook down 2 percent, Twitter down 6 percent. Snapchat, yelp all lower, some of the others lagers on the NASDAQ, would also be jd.com micron and PayPal. Back to you.

MACDONALD: Great to see you Nicole. We'll be right back with a jam-pack hour. We will be right back after the break. Stay there.

MACDONALD: Well, President Trump just tweeting quote, the failing "New York Times" in response to that anonymous New York Times op-ed. The president will be traveling to Montana tomorrow where he plans to host a Make America Great Again rally in the evening. He is expected to hold an official event following that rally. We will stay on that story for you. Thank you so much for having us in your home. It's been a jack-packed hour. Thank you so much for watching. Charles Payne is here now with Making Money. Take it away Charles.

CHARLES PAYNE, MAKING MONEY THE FOX BUSINESS NETWORK: Thank you very much E-mac. And good evening. I'm Charles Payne. We are going to get right to this major breaking news.

urn:contentItem:5WJC-XH81-DYG2-R36H-00000-00President Trump Praises Sen. Hawley's 'Ending Support for Internet Censorship Act'2019-07-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:39ZLexisNexisPresident Trump Praises Sen. Hawley's 'Ending Support for Internet Censorship Act'Targeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

Sen. Josh Hawley, R-Missouri, issued the following news release:

Today at the White House Social Media Summit, Senator Josh Hawley (R-Mo.) discussed his Ending Support for Internet Censorship Act and President Donald Trump praised the legislation.

Senator Hawley said, "And that's why we need to step up now, and I think we need to say to them, here's the deal - Google, FacebookTwitter, they've gotten these special deals from government. They've gotten a special giveaway from government. They're treated unlike anybody else. If they want to keep their special deal, here's the bargain: they have to quit discriminating against conservatives. You agree with that? No more. No more discrimination. It's that simple. That's all were asking for."

President Trump said, "And you know what Josh is doing right now? He's doing some very important legislation, because we have to do something about what's happening."

President Trump's praise for Sen. Hawley's legislation comes on the heels of comments (https://thefederalist.com/2019/07/11/lawmakers-weigh-revoking-section-230-regulate-big-tech-companies/) from Sens. Lindsey Graham (R- S.C.) and Ted Cruz (R- Texas) about the need to reign in Section 230 immunity for big tech companies.

urn:contentItem:5TTY-W0N1-JB20-G1DS-00000-00President Trump Pressures General Motors after the Company Announced They are Going to Lay Off Thousands of Jobs2018-11-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:40ZLexisNexisEVENING EDIT6:00 PM ESTMarsha Blackburn, Robby Soave, Domenic Romano, Greg Bolin, Scott Bolden, Kelsey Harkness, Kevin CramerNEWSFinancial112601cb.233President Trump Pressures General Motors after the Company Announced They are Going to Lay Off Thousands of Jobs Elizabeth MacDonald, Edward Lawrence, Kristin Fisher, Jack Keane, Andrew Napolitano

DAVID ASMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: All right. Well, we wish Tesla the very best. Thanks, gang. Bulls and Bears.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We don't like it. I believe they'll be opening up something else. I was very tough. I spoke with her when I heard they were closing. And I said, you know, this company has done a lot for General Motors. You better get back in there soon. That's Ohio. And you better get back in there soon.

So, we have a lot of pressure on them. You have senators, you have a lot of other people, a lot of pressure. They say the Chevy Cruise is not selling well. I said well, they get somebody -- get a car that is selling well and put it back in. So, I think you are going to see something else happen there, but I'm not happy about it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: President Trump fighting to protect U.S. jobs, slamming General Motors over its new plan to lay off thousands of workers and close multiple factories. We've got the details straightening out the media hysteria now trying to politicize this one. Big hint. It potentially involves a let's make a deal throwdown from G.M. on tariffs. We've got the story.

To big tech now facing big problems at home and abroad. Facebook under historic pressure in the U.K. The Brits now say they do not believe Mark Zuckerberg anymore as the U.K. parliament seizes Facebook and Zuckerberg's private company e-mails. And they urge corporate boycotts.

Senator-elect Marsha Blackburn, she's fired up and ready to go on that one. And how President Trump was right about both Facebook and Google.

To Nancy Pelosi now facing a raucous, contentious vote Democrat leadership vote this week. Her first fight with President Trump is here. A possible government shutdown over the border wall. Matt Schlapp weighs on that.

And the big weakness in the Democrat Party that Trump can capitalize on. The Ukraine just declared martial law after a Russia fired on its navy ships over the weekend wounding several sailors. This after Ukrainian protesters swarmed the Russian consulate over the weekend. We've got General Jack Keane on that, coming up.

To President Trump threatening to shut the border permanently as Democrat Maxine Waters now tries to claim the border crisis is just a political stunt by President Trump. This, as border officials now say migrants purposely used women and children as human shields as migrants threw rocks at border agents.

We've got that and news on secret government documents showing how bad the crime really was pouring over the border during the Obama years. You will not believe the new numbers. We take that on.

And Republicans undercutting a defiant James Comey. Saying Comey is basically doing fake grandstanding about resisting a subpoena for closed- door testimony next week. Judge Napolitano joins us to explain and the common-sense solution to all that.

Well, thank you so much for joining us. Thank you for watching. Money, politics, we're going to bring you the debate beyond tomorrow's headlines. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. THE EVENING EDIT starts right now.

Welcome to the show. You're watching the Fox Business Network.

President Trump pushing back hard on General Motors today after G.M. said it may lay off up to 14,800 jobs in North America including jobs in the big swing state of Ohio. The UAW, the big labor union agrees with Trump, so does Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.

Edward Lawrence is here with more. Edward, here's the back story. The UAW union labor contract with G.M. expires next year. G.M. does not want a labor union strike. So, this could be a bargaining throw down by General Motors to get Trump to dial back on the tariffs. If this hearing is held in secret, Republicans will leak their version, Democrats will leak their version, and the public, we pay all their salaries, are treated like children.

MACDONALD: Trey Gowdy is saying that's better than nothing. Actually, he is saying in a public hearing, it's actually worse because you only have five minutes to do a Q&A with the guy.

NAPOLITANO: Well, it doesn't have to be a videotape if they don't want a videotape. It can be a transcript of what has said. But when only certain people know the questions and answers and they got to do the leaking, that's government they leak.

MACDONALD: Are they going to get it done? Are Republicans get this done?

NAPOLITANO: I don't know the answer to that.

MACDONALD: What took them so long? Why did it take so long?

NAPOLITANO: That has been a very valid criticism of them because the Republicans have controlled the House of Representatives and the White House for the past two years. They didn't serve any subpoenas. They did it all by negotiating.

Now in the death rows of their tenure, they're finally serving a subpoena. They could have done this a year and a half ago at the time he was fired by the president.

MACDONALD: All right. Finishing off a tweet by -- the president has been tweeting about this. He has been very upset with of course again tweeting about the Mueller probe. What's your take now with the Mueller probe? Are we going to get the results?

NAPOLITANO: I happen to believe that the president is being advised by his lawyers not to tweet, not to taunt the alligator until after he crosses the stream, and the president is rejecting that advice. I don't know where is this going to go but I have a feeling, a feeling a lot is going to come down from Bob Mueller before Christmas and some after the Democrats take control of the House after Christmas.

MACDONALD: Wow. Judge, will you come back? We need you.

NAPOLITANO: Of course.

MACDONALD: Judge Napolitano.

NAPOLITANO: I'll see you in the morning.

MACDONALD: Great to see you. We love the judge. You know, Barney (ph) says this is a spin-off show.

(LAUGHTER)

NAPOLITANO: Barney (ph) is trying to take credit for your success.

MACDONALD: Yes, he is.

(LAUGHTER)

MACDONALD: Coming up next, Democrat Maxine Waters is trying to say the crisis at the border is just a political ploy by President Trump. We will bring in Republican Senator-elect Kevin Cramer. He is fired up about that. He is ready to go. Stay there.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RUSH LIMBAUGH, RADIO TALK SHOW HOST AND CONSERVATIVE POLITICAL COMMENTATOR: There's not one indictment, there's not one conviction that Mueller has that has anything to do with the Russians having anything to do with the election in 2016.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Fast-moving developments at the border. Border officials defending their use of teargas after 500 migrants rushed the border. They said migrants are shoving women and children to the front. If they were really peaceful asylum-seekers, the migrants would not be throwing rocks at border patrol officials.

Dozens of migrants were arrested on the U.S. side of the border for crossing illegally. Also, Democrat Maxine Waters says the crisis there is nothing but a political ploy by President Trump. Kevin Cramer is a Republican senator-elect from North Dakota. He joins us now. Great to see you, sir.

REP. KEVIN CRAMER (R), NORTH DAKOTA: Good to be with you. Thank you.

MACDONALD: Sir, what is your take on all of this?

CRAMER: I think that Congresswoman Waters is missing the entire point. I'm surprised because if there's one thing that the crisis at the border has shown us, it really should be a wake-up call for all of those who doubted the seriousness of the situation.

To somehow suggest that it is manufactured crisis when there are 6,000 people who walked all the way through their country of Mexico to come to our border and try to storm it, that's not a fabrication, that's not a Hollywood production, those are real people. I think that it deserves the type of scrutiny that our president is giving.

MACDONALD: Yes, sir, it's hard to say that it is not a crisis when there's a video showing what's happening. You know there are some 5,000 migrants camped in Tijuana. You know there has been information coming in that the government documents show that under Obama, there was something like more than 24,000 serious incidents that occurred in 2014 of crime and violence among illegal border crossers.

CRAMER: Right.

MACDONALD: How can Maxine Waters say this is just a stunt?

CRAMER: Because Maxine Waters is doing the exact thing that she is accusing our president of doing and that is politicizing the crisis. That's exactly the wrong approach. I think, you know, few weeks ago, our voters voted in a divided government to replace the unified Republican government.

I think the message that I take away from that is that they want two sides to get together and come up with some solutions. I think there are solutions that should be acceptable to all sides as long as one side is willing to give the other side something in exchange for the thing that they want.

That's been the problem with the four pillars approach that the president offered up which I thought had winners all the way around but the winners didn't want to be winners unless somebody else is a loser. I think that's exactly what the borders are telling us they don't want in this next Congress.

MACDONALD: Here is Brandon Judd, the president of the National Border Council. He said this -- Here's what he said this morning about what's going on. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BRANDON JUDD, PRESIDENT, NATIONAL BORDER PATROL UNION: Our agents did not deploy teargas until they were hit with projectiles. Rocks and bottles. That's when they in fact deploy the teargas. If you look at what this caravan did, they pushed the women and children up to the front. How monstrous is that?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Your reaction to that, sir?

CRAMER: Well, clearly, this is not the type of refugee crisis that is sponsored by your local church. The refugees have come here through the right process, come with sponsors. They come through the legal process. And I think that he's exactly right.

When you look at the video, when you think that they can't possibly be peace-loving asylum seekers, who would do this to children and women and innocent people, nor were they storm a border illegally, they've come through illegal (ph) process, in which case they would be met with the type of hospitality that is significant and that is our tradition.

MACDONALD: Kevin Cramer, senator-elect out of North Dakota. Great to see you, sir. Thank you so much for coming in. We appreciate it. We welcome you back on soon.

CRAMER: My pleasure. Thank you.

MACDONALD: Thank you for having us in your homes. It has been a jam- packed hour. Thank you so much for watching. Lou Dobbs is here next on the Fox Business Network. Have a good night.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TV6-GYC1-DY0W-432K-00000-00President Trump Pressures General Motors after the Company Announced They are Going to Lay Off Thousands of Jobs2018-11-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:39ZLexisNexisPresident Trump Pressures General Motors after the Company Announced They are Going to Lay Off Thousands of Jobs LanhamFULL TEXT

DAVID ASMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: All right. Well, we wish Tesla the very best. Thanks, gang. Bulls and Bears.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We don't like it. I believe they'll be opening up something else. I was very tough. I spoke with her when I heard they were closing. And I said, you know, this company has done a lot for General Motors. You better get back in there soon. That's Ohio. And you better get back in there soon.

So, we have a lot of pressure on them. You have senators, you have a lot of other people, a lot of pressure. They say the Chevy Cruise is not selling well. I said well, they get somebody -- get a car that is selling well and put it back in. So, I think you are going to see something else happen there, but I'm not happy about it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

and Also Planning to Close Seven Plants Including the One in the Key State of Ohio; Facebook Under Historic Pressure in the U.K. and Its Parliament Seizes Facebook and Zuckerberg's Private Company E-mails; Ukraine just Declared Martial Law after Russia Fired on Its Navy Ships over the Weekend and Wounding Several Sailors; President Trump Holds Two Rallies Tonight in Mississippi to Support Controversial Candidate Cindy Hyde-Smith; Northern California Residents Are Now Starting to Clean-Up the Area and Rebuild the Infrastructures There that Are being Burned by the Devastating Wild Fires; Vice Governor Greg Bolin on California Fires; Dems Silent on Free College, Trump Tax Cuts May have Hurt Republicans and High-Taxed States; Gen. Jack Keane Discusses How Ukrainian Lawmakers Voted to Declare Martial Law in Areas Bordering Russia, after Russian Attacked and Seized Ukrainian Navy Ships; Comey to Push Back on Subpoena for Closed-Door Testimony; Judge Andrew Napolitano Discusses How Former FBI Director James Comey is Expected to Push Back on a Subpoena Issued by House Republicans; Securing the Border: 500 to 1,000 Migrants Involved in Attempt to Rush the Border; Dozens of Migrants Arrested on the U.S. Side of the Border for Crossing Illegally; Democrat Maxine Waters Says the Crisis There is Nothing but a Political Ploy by President Trump

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: President Trump fighting to protect U.S. jobs, slamming General Motors over its new plan to lay off thousands of workers and close multiple factories. We've got the details straightening out the media hysteria now trying to politicize this one. Big hint. It potentially involves a let's make a deal throwdown from G.M. on tariffs. We've got the story.

To big tech now facing big problems at home and abroad. Facebook under historic pressure in the U.K. The Brits now say they do not believe Mark Zuckerberg anymore as the U.K. parliament seizes Facebook and Zuckerberg's private company e-mails. And they urge corporate boycotts.

Senator-elect Marsha Blackburn, she's fired up and ready to go on that one. And how President Trump was right about both Facebook and Google.

To Nancy Pelosi now facing a raucous, contentious vote Democrat leadership vote this week. Her first fight with President Trump is here. A possible government shutdown over the border wall. Matt Schlapp weighs on that.

And the big weakness in the Democrat Party that Trump can capitalize on. The Ukraine just declared martial law after a Russia fired on its navy ships over the weekend wounding several sailors. This after Ukrainian protesters swarmed the Russian consulate over the weekend. We've got General Jack Keane on that, coming up.

To President Trump threatening to shut the border permanently as Democrat Maxine Waters now tries to claim the border crisis is just a political stunt by President Trump. This, as border officials now say migrants purposely used women and children as human shields as migrants threw rocks at border agents.

We've got that and news on secret government documents showing how bad the crime really was pouring over the border during the Obama years. You will not believe the new numbers. We take that on.

And Republicans undercutting a defiant James Comey. Saying Comey is basically doing fake grandstanding about resisting a subpoena for closed- door testimony next week. Judge Napolitano joins us to explain and the common-sense solution to all that.

Well, thank you so much for joining us. Thank you for watching. Money, politics, we're going to bring you the debate beyond tomorrow's headlines. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. THE EVENING EDIT starts right now.

Welcome to the show. You're watching the Fox Business Network.

President Trump pushing back hard on General Motors today after G.M. said it may lay off up to 14,800 jobs in North America including jobs in the big swing state of Ohio. The UAW, the big labor union agrees with Trump, so does Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.

Edward Lawrence is here with more. Edward, here's the back story. The UAW union labor contract with G.M. expires next year. G.M. does not want a labor union strike. So, this could be a bargaining throw down by General Motors to get Trump to dial back on the tariffs. The White House already said it could give a waiver to save jobs for other companies when it granted waivers on steel tariffs to seven big corporations.

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Right.

MACDONALD: To you, what do you say, Edward?

LAWRENCE: Well, you know, G.M., though, the cars haven't been selling as well as Ford, too. It comes down to sales too. But it could be a little of all of that mixed in here. The labor unions and automakers have always been at odds over and over and over again. And G.M. did not have a great deal the last time around for its investors. They're trying to get a better deal going forward.

But, again, it also boils down to sales. Now isn't it funny though, Liz, how some of these decisions by automakers bring political opponents together. You mention all of these folks in the same sentence supporting President Trump to get back into Ohio.

Well, the announcement shocks and many sent ripples to the White House today while President Donald Trump says he will pressure G.M. to bring those jobs back to Ohio. He says that he told the G.M. CEO, Mary Barra to get back into Ohio.

Barra met White House adviser or economic adviser Larry Kudlow today. And this is part of the pressure now to get G.M. to reconsider closing seven plants.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I spoke with her when I heard they were closing and I said, you know, this one country has done a lot for General Motors. You better get back in there soon. That's Ohio. And you better get back in there soon.

So, we have a lot of pressure on them. You have senators, you have a lot of other people.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: Now four factories in the U.S. and one in Canada could be closed by the end of 2019. The other two are outside North America. The plant closing in Ohio specifically angered the president and shocked Ohio Senator Rob Portman.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. ROB PORTMAN, (R) OHIO: General Motors has let down those workers who have done so much for General Motors. I'm disappointed on that. What I said several months ago to G.M., and again more recently, a couple of months ago in meetings with their CEO and in discussions with their executive is we need another product.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: Now Ohio is crucial for the 2020 presidential race. The president has made it a priority to help people especially there get back to work. Liz?

MACDONALD: Great to see you, Edward. To our viewers, the issue is whether G.M. could retool U.S. factories to build SUVs and trucks. That's the issue too, right, Edward?

OK. We lost Edward there. We're going to move on.

Members of the U.K. parliament now urging big companies to boycott advertising on Google and Facebook because these guys still have not stopped terror content and other negative content on their platforms. Companies don't like when their ads to show up next to this content.

This is also what's happening. There's push back in Canada, Ireland, Argentina, Brazil, Singapore, and Latvia as well against Facebook and social media.

Let's bring in Tennessee Senator-elect Masha Blackburn. Great to see you, Marsha. Thanks for coming on.

SEN.-ELECT MARSHA BLACKBURN, (R), TENNESSEE: Good to see you. Thanks.

MACDONALD: What's your reaction to the story?

BLACKBURN: It just seems like there is no end to the number of messes that you see Google and Facebook and Twitter and that FAANGS as they are called getting themselves into these days. And I know that they have the ability to do a little bit more policing on their networks that they then they are doing.

But Liz, they are choosing not to do that. And I think that the American people are getting wise to this. They are tired of the privacy breaches that you are seeing, the invasion of privacy, and the data breaches. And what people want to know is that there is the ability for they themselves to protect their virtual you and protect their sensitive information.

MACDONALD: Yes. That's an important point because the pushback is Facebook and other social media, they are collecting data on you that you don't know about.

You know what's really interesting, Congressman and Senator-elect is that the U.K., the United Kingdom is really pushing back hard, they don't believe Facebook at all and they believe Facebook purposely built and knew about a back door so companies like Cambridge Analytica could get in and take our information. What's your reaction to that?

BLACKBURN: This is the reason I wrote the BROWSER Act. What you saw in 2015 and 2016 from the Obama administration was trying to put in privacy rules that would only affect your internet service provider and they did not want it to apply to the entire ecosystem.

Now the U.K. moved forward with some privacy regulations that are more stringent than anything we've considered in the U.S. But here is the thing and the nugget. You, the consumer should have the ability to protect your information and your sensitive data and say you do or do not want that shared. Then for non-sensitive data you should have the ability to say I'm going to opt out and not allow you to gather this information on me.

What we have seen some of these platforms to do and these are the apps, basically that are not present, if you will, on your screen. They go in they scrape your data.

MACDONALD: Yes.

BLACKBURN: And they pull all that information and then they sell that or they use it for their advertisers and you, the consumer, know nothing about and you can't stop it.

MACDONALD: And you know Jane Wong, she is a UMass Dartmouth underground, Marsha. She basically reverses engineered apps. She wants to see what they were collecting.

BLACKBURN: Right.

MACDONALD: She discovers shocking new information that we didn't know about, that these apps are actually tracking the cell towers and the Wi-Fi networks near you to find out where you're located, and now Google may track your movement and your behaviors inside your home via Google devices, including that of your children, Marsha.

BLACKBURN: That's exactly right. And here is the thing about that. Even if your device is not activated, turned off, the SIM card pulled that Google operating system still tracks every single base station that you are passing. And so, they are tracking you. And then also if it is an in-home device that you can say, OK, Google play this or do that it is recording and storing all of that and other conversation bits and pieces.

MACDONALD: It is unbelievable. We thought big brother--

(CROSSTALK)

BLACKBURN: Unbelievable.

MACDONALD: We thought big brother was in government. It's in Silicon Valley. Senator-elect--

(CROSSTALK)

BLACKBURN: Well, that's right.

MACDONALD: Yes. Senator-elect Marsha Blackburn, it's been great to see you have you on the show. Thank you so much for joining us. I appreciate it.

BLACKBURN: Good to see you. Thank you.

MACDONALD: Now is the time to break up big tech monopoly on things like that and public discourse. Let's bring in Reason magazine staff editor Robby Soave, and business attorney and tech expert, Domenic Romano. Domenic, what do you think.

DOMENIC ROMANO, BUSINESS ATTORNEY: I agree with Senator-elect Blackburn. I think a surgical approach is necessary. I don't think these companies can be trusted to regulate themselves. You know, they say the superpower, absolute power corrupts, absolutely, who controls the controllers. It's time for some regulation.

In fact, Zuckerberg and Cook are asking for that, at least earlier they expressed a willingness for some regulation.

MACDONALD: It's interesting. Robby, what do you think?

ROBBY SOAVE, STAFF EDITOR, REASON MAGAZINE: Well, I'm also concerned about privacy but I'm more concerned about the government having access to this information. I don't particularly trust Congress to regulate these companies very well. I don't think they have a strong base of knowledge for how to do so.

And you know, you can ultimately decide to opt out of some of these services just by not using now. I mean, Facebook is crashing and burning recently because people don't like it. So, there is a, there is a market check on their behavior. The only true monopoly is one actually maintained by the government and I worry that's what could happen inadvertently if we get the government to get involved.

ROMANO: Yes.

MACDONALD: And Robby makes an important point, Domenic. Facebook though does track you even if you unplug Facebook. In other words, Domenic Facebook still follows you around the internet even after you've killed off your Facebook.

MACDONALD: Welcome back. The Ukraine declaring martial law today in regions bordering Russia. This after Russian forces opened fire on its naval vessels over the weekend. KEANE: That's likely a bald-faced lie, to be frank about it. They lie through their teeth on all of these things. In every incident they have, they always claim that they were provoked and they just had to take action.

What this is really about, Putin's strategy here, five years after he moved into -- almost five years after he moved in to Crimea and the eastern part of Ukraine, he's already trying to squeeze Ukraine even more economically.

North of the Kerch Strait where this incident took place is the Sea of Azov. There are two or three ports there in Ukraine that are used to bring out a lot of exports out of that country particularly steel. They move down through the strait in to the Black Sea and then out into the European and global markets.

Putin, I think, is leading up to squeezing that as much as he possibly can. He doesn't like the fact that Ukraine looks to the west for economic support from the E.U. and also from the United States, and he's trying to continue to discourage that. So that's the strategic thing that's taken place on Putin's part.

MACDONALD: General, what was your reaction to Democrat Senator Ben Cardin criticizing President Trump today, saying that Trump is helping Vladimir Putin "weaken the west by threatening NATO?"

KEANE: Yeah, I was surprised by that. Senator Cardin is a knowledgeable and respected member of the Senate. I agree with the statement that Putin's strategy is to weaken the transatlantic alliance, NATO, that is, and in my perspective, I think eventually force its collapse.

This is the first president in years who has actually gone to lengths to strengthen NATO by forcing them to increase the funding of the fence. And that is absolutely taking place largely because of the criticism that President Trump has unleashed against the NATO members leaders.

Also, we are pushing troops, Liz, into Eastern Europe as a deterrence against Russian aggression. That's U.S. troops and NATO troops. So, the senator is off in his conclusion there about Trump weakening NATO. Quite the contrary.

MACDONALD: And general, he is also suggesting Trump is not confronting Putin. What's your take on that?

KEANE: Well, I don't get that either because the facts don't support it. I mean, people overreact to the president wanting to have good relationship with adversarial leaders. North Korea, China, and Russia to name the three of them.

But the truth is, quite the contrary. He has issued sanctions as result of election meddling, as result of killing the Russian critic in the U.K. with a chemical biological weapon close to consulate throughout scores of Russian officials from here.

He has provided Ukraine with lethal aid. Obama refused to do it for four years. President Trump has done that to provide even more lethal aid. And twice he has struck the Russian proxy in Syria, the Assad regime, for the use of chemical weapons.

So, despite the rhetoric that President Trump wants relations to be good with Putin to see if we can solve some tough problems together, the policies that he is enacting are clearly pushing back on Russian aggression.
