urn:contentItem:5TV6-GYC1-DY0W-432N-00000-00President Trump Pressures General Motors after the Company Announced They are Going to Lay Off Thousands of Jobs and Also Planning to Close Seven Plants Including the One in the Key State of Ohio; Facebook Under Historic Pressure in the U.K. and Its Parliament Seizes Facebook and Zuckerberg's Private Company E-mails; Ukraine just Declared Martial Law after Russia Fired on Its Navy Ships over the Weekend and Wounding Several Sailors; President Trump Holds Two Rallies Tonight in Mississippi to Support Controversial Candidate Cindy Hyde-Smith; Northern California Residents Are Now Starting to Clean-Up the Area and Rebuild the Infrastructures There that Are being Burned by the Devastating Wild Fires; Vice Governor Greg Bolin on California Fires; Dems Silent on Free College, Trump Tax Cuts May have Hurt Republicans and High-Taxed States; Gen. Jack Keane Discusses How Ukrainian Lawmakers Voted to Declare Martial Law in Areas Bordering Russia, after Russian Attacked and Seized Ukrainian Navy Ships; Comey to Push Back on Subpoena for Closed-Door Testimony; Judge Andrew Napolitano Discusses How Former FBI Director James Comey is Expected to Push Back on a Subpoena Issued by House Republicans; Securing the Border: 500 to 1,000 Migrants Involved in Attempt to Rush the Border; Dozens of Migrants Arrested on the U.S. Side of the Border for Crossing Illegally; Democrat Maxine Waters Says the Crisis There is Nothing but a Political Ploy by President Trump2018-11-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:40ZLexisNexisPresident Trump Pressures General Motors after the Company Announced They are Going to Lay Off Thousands of Jobs and Also Planning to Close Seven Plants Including the One in the Key State of Ohio; Facebook Under Historic Pressure in the U.K. and Its Parliament Seizes Facebook and Zuckerberg's Private Company E-mails; Ukraine just Declared Martial Law after Russia Fired on Its Navy Ships over the Weekend and Wounding Several Sailors; President Trump Holds Two Rallies Tonight in Mississippi to Support Controversial Candidate Cindy Hyde-Smith; Northern California Residents Are Now Starting to Clean-Up the Area and Rebuild the Infrastructures There that Are being Burned by the Devastating Wild Fires; Vice Governor Greg Bolin on California Fires; Dems Silent on Free College, Trump Tax Cuts May have Hurt Republicans and High-Taxed States; Gen. Jack Keane Discusses How Ukrainian Lawmakers Voted to Declare Martial Law in Areas Bordering Russia, after Russian Attacked and Seized Ukrainian Navy Ships; Comey to Push Back on Subpoena for Closed-Door Testimony; Judge Andrew Napolitano Discusses How Former FBI Director James Comey is Expected to Push Back on a Subpoena Issued by House Republicans; Securing the Border: 500 to 1,000 Migrants Involved in Attempt to Rush the Border; Dozens of Migrants Arrested on the U.S. Side of the Border for Crossing Illegally; Democrat Maxine Waters Says the Crisis There is Nothing but a Political Ploy by President TrumpLanhamFULL TEXT

DAVID ASMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: All right. Well, we wish Tesla the very best. Thanks, gang. Bulls and Bears.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We don't like it. I believe they'll be opening up something else. I was very tough. I spoke with her when I heard they were closing. And I said, you know, this company has done a lot for General Motors. You better get back in there soon. That's Ohio. And you better get back in there soon.

So, we have a lot of pressure on them. You have senators, you have a lot of other people, a lot of pressure. They say the Chevy Cruise is not selling well. I said well, they get somebody -- get a car that is selling well and put it back in. So, I think you are going to see something else happen there, but I'm not happy about it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: President Trump fighting to protect U.S. jobs, slamming General Motors over its new plan to lay off thousands of workers and close multiple factories. We've got the details straightening out the media hysteria now trying to politicize this one. Big hint. It potentially involves a let's make a deal throwdown from G.M. on tariffs. We've got the story.

To big tech now facing big problems at home and abroad. Facebook under historic pressure in the U.K. The Brits now say they do not believe Mark Zuckerberg anymore as the U.K. parliament seizes Facebook and Zuckerberg's private company e-mails. And they urge corporate boycotts.

Senator-elect Marsha Blackburn, she's fired up and ready to go on that one. And how President Trump was right about both Facebook and Google.

To Nancy Pelosi now facing a raucous, contentious vote Democrat leadership vote this week. Her first fight with President Trump is here. A possible government shutdown over the border wall. Matt Schlapp weighs on that.

And the big weakness in the Democrat Party that Trump can capitalize on. The Ukraine just declared martial law after a Russia fired on its navy ships over the weekend wounding several sailors. This after Ukrainian protesters swarmed the Russian consulate over the weekend. We've got General Jack Keane on that, coming up.

To President Trump threatening to shut the border permanently as Democrat Maxine Waters now tries to claim the border crisis is just a political stunt by President Trump. This, as border officials now say migrants purposely used women and children as human shields as migrants threw rocks at border agents.

We've got that and news on secret government documents showing how bad the crime really was pouring over the border during the Obama years. You will not believe the new numbers. We take that on.

And Republicans undercutting a defiant James Comey. Saying Comey is basically doing fake grandstanding about resisting a subpoena for closed- door testimony next week. Judge Napolitano joins us to explain and the common-sense solution to all that.

Well, thank you so much for joining us. Thank you for watching. Money, politics, we're going to bring you the debate beyond tomorrow's headlines. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. THE EVENING EDIT starts right now.

Welcome to the show. You're watching the Fox Business Network.

President Trump pushing back hard on General Motors today after G.M. said it may lay off up to 14,800 jobs in North America including jobs in the big swing state of Ohio. The UAW, the big labor union agrees with Trump, so does Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.

Edward Lawrence is here with more. Edward, here's the back story. The UAW union labor contract with G.M. expires next year. G.M. does not want a labor union strike. So, this could be a bargaining throw down by General Motors to get Trump to dial back on the tariffs. The White House already said it could give a waiver to save jobs for other companies when it granted waivers on steel tariffs to seven big corporations.

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Right.

MACDONALD: To you, what do you say, Edward?

LAWRENCE: Well, you know, G.M., though, the cars haven't been selling as well as Ford, too. It comes down to sales too. But it could be a little of all of that mixed in here. The labor unions and automakers have always been at odds over and over and over again. And G.M. did not have a great deal the last time around for its investors. They're trying to get a better deal going forward.

But, again, it also boils down to sales. Now isn't it funny though, Liz, how some of these decisions by automakers bring political opponents together. You mention all of these folks in the same sentence supporting President Trump to get back into Ohio.

Well, the announcement shocks and many sent ripples to the White House today while President Donald Trump says he will pressure G.M. to bring those jobs back to Ohio. He says that he told the G.M. CEO, Mary Barra to get back into Ohio.

Barra met White House adviser or economic adviser Larry Kudlow today. And this is part of the pressure now to get G.M. to reconsider closing seven plants.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I spoke with her when I heard they were closing and I said, you know, this one country has done a lot for General Motors. You better get back in there soon. That's Ohio. And you better get back in there soon.

So, we have a lot of pressure on them. You have senators, you have a lot of other people.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: Now four factories in the U.S. and one in Canada could be closed by the end of 2019. The other two are outside North America. The plant closing in Ohio specifically angered the president and shocked Ohio Senator Rob Portman.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. ROB PORTMAN, (R) OHIO: General Motors has let down those workers who have done so much for General Motors. I'm disappointed on that. What I said several months ago to G.M., and again more recently, a couple of months ago in meetings with their CEO and in discussions with their executive is we need another product.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: Now Ohio is crucial for the 2020 presidential race. The president has made it a priority to help people especially there get back to work. Liz?

MACDONALD: Great to see you, Edward. To our viewers, the issue is whether G.M. could retool U.S. factories to build SUVs and trucks. That's the issue too, right, Edward?

OK. We lost Edward there. We're going to move on.

Members of the U.K. parliament now urging big companies to boycott advertising on Google and Facebook because these guys still have not stopped terror content and other negative content on their platforms. Companies don't like when their ads to show up next to this content.

This is also what's happening. There's push back in Canada, Ireland, Argentina, Brazil, Singapore, and Latvia as well against Facebook and social media.

Let's bring in Tennessee Senator-elect Masha Blackburn. Great to see you, Marsha. Thanks for coming on.

SEN.-ELECT MARSHA BLACKBURN, (R), TENNESSEE: Good to see you. Thanks.

MACDONALD: What's your reaction to the story?

BLACKBURN: It just seems like there is no end to the number of messes that you see Google and Facebook and Twitter and that FAANGS as they are called getting themselves into these days. And I know that they have the ability to do a little bit more policing on their networks that they then they are doing.

But Liz, they are choosing not to do that. And I think that the American people are getting wise to this. They are tired of the privacy breaches that you are seeing, the invasion of privacy, and the data breaches. And what people want to know is that there is the ability for they themselves to protect their virtual you and protect their sensitive information.

MACDONALD: Yes. That's an important point because the pushback is Facebook and other social media, they are collecting data on you that you don't know about.

You know what's really interesting, Congressman and Senator-elect is that the U.K., the United Kingdom is really pushing back hard, they don't believe Facebook at all and they believe Facebook purposely built and knew about a back door so companies like Cambridge Analytica could get in and take our information. What's your reaction to that?

BLACKBURN: This is the reason I wrote the BROWSER Act. What you saw in 2015 and 2016 from the Obama administration was trying to put in privacy rules that would only affect your internet service provider and they did not want it to apply to the entire ecosystem.

Now the U.K. moved forward with some privacy regulations that are more stringent than anything we've considered in the U.S. But here is the thing and the nugget. You, the consumer should have the ability to protect your information and your sensitive data and say you do or do not want that shared. Then for non-sensitive data you should have the ability to say I'm going to opt out and not allow you to gather this information on me.

What we have seen some of these platforms to do and these are the apps, basically that are not present, if you will, on your screen. They go in they scrape your data.

MACDONALD: Yes.

BLACKBURN: And they pull all that information and then they sell that or they use it for their advertisers and you, the consumer, know nothing about and you can't stop it.

MACDONALD: And you know Jane Wong, she is a UMass Dartmouth underground, Marsha. She basically reverses engineered apps. She wants to see what they were collecting.

BLACKBURN: Right.

MACDONALD: She discovers shocking new information that we didn't know about, that these apps are actually tracking the cell towers and the Wi-Fi networks near you to find out where you're located, and now Google may track your movement and your behaviors inside your home via Google devices, including that of your children, Marsha.

BLACKBURN: That's exactly right. And here is the thing about that. Even if your device is not activated, turned off, the SIM card pulled that Google operating system still tracks every single base station that you are passing. And so, they are tracking you. And then also if it is an in-home device that you can say, OK, Google play this or do that it is recording and storing all of that and other conversation bits and pieces.

MACDONALD: It is unbelievable. We thought big brother--

(CROSSTALK)

BLACKBURN: Unbelievable.

MACDONALD: We thought big brother was in government. It's in Silicon Valley. Senator-elect--

(CROSSTALK)

BLACKBURN: Well, that's right.

MACDONALD: Yes. Senator-elect Marsha Blackburn, it's been great to see you have you on the show. Thank you so much for joining us. I appreciate it.

BLACKBURN: Good to see you. Thank you.

MACDONALD: Now is the time to break up big tech monopoly on things like that and public discourse. Let's bring in Reason magazine staff editor Robby Soave, and business attorney and tech expert, Domenic Romano. Domenic, what do you think.

DOMENIC ROMANO, BUSINESS ATTORNEY: I agree with Senator-elect Blackburn. I think a surgical approach is necessary. I don't think these companies can be trusted to regulate themselves. You know, they say the superpower, absolute power corrupts, absolutely, who controls the controllers. It's time for some regulation.

In fact, Zuckerberg and Cook are asking for that, at least earlier they expressed a willingness for some regulation.

MACDONALD: It's interesting. Robby, what do you think?

ROBBY SOAVE, STAFF EDITOR, REASON MAGAZINE: Well, I'm also concerned about privacy but I'm more concerned about the government having access to this information. I don't particularly trust Congress to regulate these companies very well. I don't think they have a strong base of knowledge for how to do so.

And you know, you can ultimately decide to opt out of some of these services just by not using now. I mean, Facebook is crashing and burning recently because people don't like it. So, there is a, there is a market check on their behavior. The only true monopoly is one actually maintained by the government and I worry that's what could happen inadvertently if we get the government to get involved.

ROMANO: Yes.

MACDONALD: And Robby makes an important point, Domenic. Facebook though does track you even if you unplug Facebook. In other words, Domenic Facebook still follows you around the internet even after you've killed off your Facebook.

ROMANO: Well, that's the whole point. I think it's an overstatement to say that Facebook is crushed and burned. They've loss the music but still the dominant platform. So, I think it's time to regulate, but it should be surgical, it should be measured. and that it should be very, very limited to start.

MACDONALD: And Robby, you know, the U.K., the United Kingdom Britain clearly not believing Zuckerberg anymore. They say he may have known about privacy abuses and other problems way earlier than he has said according to e-mails at U.K. parliament has seize. What do you think, Robby?

SOAVE: Well, that's true, but of course Europe has different laws in some important ways, right. Don't have a First Amendment, they can -- you can be arrested for hate speech there so they take kind of these matters a little differently.

Look, I just think it's going be quite difficult to put the genie back in the bottle relating to some of these privacy concerns.

MACDONALD: OK.

SOAVE: I'm concerned about privacy as well, but these are difficult questions.

MACDONALD: Robby and Domenic, that's why we want to have you guys back on to talk about it.

ROMANO: I love to.

MACDONALD: It's a developing story. Great to see both. Thank you so much.

ROMANO: Thank you.

MACDONALD: In other headlines, the Supreme Court is appearing skeptical against Apple in arguments over whether customers of those iPhone apps can actually sue Apple over its potential illegal monopoly on app sales.

Let's get to black Friday and cyber Monday setting sales records, look at this, MasterCard projecting shoppers spent $23 billion on black Friday. Adobe says shoppers are on track to spend nearly $8 million during today's cyber Monday -- cyber Monday shopping extravaganza.

And we've got a stunning accomplishment for NASA high- fives all around. The Mars insight Lander successfully touched down on Mars earlier this afternoon. This lander made a 300-million-mile trek to Mars. This is the second U.S. robot to land on the red planet. The first was a curiosity rover in 2012.

And take a look at this. A brutal fight erupting during last night's football game between the Buffalo Bills and the Jacksonville Jaguars. The brawl ended with running back Leonard Fournette of Jacksonville and the bills shock loss in getting ejected from the game. Fournette has since apologized on Twitter.

Coming up, President Trump holding not one but two rallies tonight in Mississippi. We're on the ground with the latest from the president.

Also coming up, a potential government shutdown. The first fight Nancy Pelosi faces as she is expected to win the Democratic House speakership. The election is coming up this Wednesday. We've got all those fights and we're going to show you what is really going on and what is going wrong with the Democrat Party behind the scenes.

Matta Schlapp, he's here. He is fired up and ready to take it on, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Welcome back.

A special Senate election is bringing President Trump to Tupelo, Mississippi. The president will be holding a make America great again rally in support of controversial junior Senator Cindy Hyde-Smith now accused of making racist comments.

Fox News reporter Kristin Fisher has more. Kristin?

KRISTIN FISHER, FOX NEWS REPORTER: Well, Liz, President Trump just wrapped his first of two rallies tonight in Mississippi in support of the Republican candidate in this race Senator Cindy Hyde-Smith. You know, the president's track record is pretty good. He proved to be very helpful for all the Republican Senate candidates that he campaigned for earlier this month during the midterms.

And so, he's really helping that that same strategy is going to work tomorrow right here in Mississippi. Now Mississippi, this is a deep red state, so you might think that the Republican Senate candidate in this race might need any help. But she has come under a lot of heat for a racially tense remark that she made earlier this month.

She was caught on camera praising a supporter by saying, quote, "if he invited me to a public hanging I'd be on the front row." Now she since apologized, but that remark has been following her nonstop on the campaign trail especially since her Democrat opponent in this race Mike Espy, he's trying to become Mississippi's first black senator since reconstruction.

He's dealing with his issues though, his baggage from his time in the Clinton administration when he was indicted for accepting improper gifts, though he was later acquitted on all counts.

And then there's also his more recent lobbying for an African dictator currently on trial for crimes against humanity. So, in the end, this race it is going to all come down to turn out as most elections are on non- election day. It's turned out absolutely key. That's why President Trump is coming here. And why he came here tonight in Tupelo and why he's going to Biloxi in just a few hours.

He's hoping that all of these folks, all of his supporters that came out to see him tonight he's hoping that they will get out and vote for Cindy Hyde- Smith tomorrow in what is the final Senate race to be decided in 2018. This is it, Liz.

MACDONALD: OK. Kristin, live in Tupelo, Mississippi. Great to see you, Kristin. Thank you so much. The clock now ticking on Capitol Hill to potential government shutdown over the border and it's unfolding as it is now show time for Nancy Pelosi. She is now set to reclaim her role this Wednesday as House speaker. High-fives there as the Dems did take 40 seats in the House.

But here's the problem with the Democrats. Massive leadership deterioration. No fresh talent. No fresh leadership, no accountability. Big losses over the last decade at all levels of government.

Joining me now is the American Conservative Union chair, Matt Schlapp. Great to see you, Matt. Your take here.

MATT SCHLAPP, CHAIRMAN, AMERICAN CONSERVATIVE UNION: I think the Democrats are in a world of hurt in the House. I think it's very interesting to watch. Nancy Pelosi was always considered the most progressive of progressive. She's from San Francisco. She's always been to the left on every major issue, but now it seems like she's lost the support of some of these new upstarts that just were elected to her caucus majority.

MACDONALD: So, here's the thing. The House Republicans have term limits on their committees of committee chairs and the chairs of subcommittees. The Democrats do not have that. So, there's no other Democrat running against Pelosi for speaker. What does that tell you about Dem leadership? Some critics say this is insane, Matt, that this is why the Democrat Party has imploded when it comes to leadership.

SCHLAPP: Well, the other thing is not only do they have these 70-year-olds who are wanting to take all these leadership positions at all these are committee gavels. You know, the other issue that's involved in all this is that you have a fair number of new Democrats who were elected partially on the promise that they wouldn't vote for Nancy Pelosi.

Now if give Nancy Pelosi a lot of credit. She is arm twisting. She is hammering them. She is pressuring them to vote for her, but many of them in voting for Nancy Pelosi will break a campaign promise and they won -- and many of them won in districts that Republicans previously held.

So, as a Republican, I'm kind of just enjoying the whole spectacle.

MACDONALD: Yes, because Nancy Pelosi hands out the plum committee assignments and then they meet the Democrats of the top leadership, they meet behind closed doors and tell the junior Democrats how to vote.

Here's the thing, Matt. We saw Democrats Rahm Emanuel, Kirstjen Gillibrand, and Chris Van Hollen quit the House at the first good opportunity because of the sclerotic top-down leadership from Pelosi.

And here's the thing, Matt. Critics have said if Barack Obama had run for the House, as he did in 2001 and if he won back in 2000, Barack Obama might still be stuck. He might still be stuck trying to advance for--

SCHLAPP: Right.

MACDONALD: -- trying to get beyond the House energy committee where Bobby Rush his opponent won and that's where he says.

SCHLAPP: It's a very fair point. Look at all the freshman senators who ran for president, you had people like Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz, you know, running for president, Rand Paul where they haven't even in the Senate that long on the Republican side.

The same is true with Barack Obama on the Democratic side. It seems like in politics these days in America you got to go up or you're out. And just hanging around the old phrase used to be, go along to get along and that seems to be dead because if you don't move up you just kind of stuck and when you're in the minority in the Houses as these Republicans are going to realize there is not a whole lot to do, Liz.

MACDONALD: So, let me ask you something. Will the House Republicans get more vocal and will the House Democrats get more vocal? Because if Nancy Pelosi is doing top-down, Nancy Pelosi may realize, she probably realizes, you do need electrifying new leadership to take on a guy like Trump, right?

SCHLAPP: Yes, that's exactly right. Look, I think Nancy Pelosi is in a fight here that she might very well win, but she's about yesterday, and I think there's a lot of Democrats in her caucus in the House that realize they got to find a new generation of leadership. And it's going to be very interesting.

Because let's face it. They elected a lot of new faces. Some of them were very interesting. Some of them don't. Are not that impressive for my point of view, but others are. And it's going to be very interesting to see if they can project a leader who represents these new diverse congresspeople who have been elected all over the country.

MACDONALD: Smart insights and analysis from Matt Schlapp. We love having you on, Matt. Great to see you.

SCHLAPP: Thanks.

MACDONALD: OK. We're coming into the bottom of the hour. Coming up, what do taxes and suburban Republican soccer mom have in common a lot. They've got a lot in common. Losing those suburban soccer moms that might be the Republican's biggest fear. We're going to explain that next.

And later in the show. Ukraine declares martial law after Russia fired on several of its navy ships, wounding numerous sailors. General Jack Keane is here to break it all down. That's up there. Stay there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: The Camp Fire in Northern California now contained. But tens of thousands still homeless, plus a number of missing statewide still 296. That is down from about 1,000 people thought to be missing just a few days ago. The death toll statewide hitting 88. Almost 19,000 buildings have been destroyed.

The scorch land amounts of the size of two Rhode Islands or one Delaware that has been burned in the state of California in his recent spate of fires.

Joining me now is a vice mayor of Paradise, California. He is Greg Bolin. Your honor, it's so great to have you on the show. It is a world of pain. We were talking about this here at the Fox Business Network.

And the town of Paradise it's an ashy eerie quiet right now. Can you bring us up to date what's going on?

GREG BOLIN, VICE MAYOR, PARADISE, CALIFORNIA: Well, right now we just have an army of people up there all doing their best to get through town and start putting power back in and get the water up and running. Our infrastructures just completely gone, so they're just trying to get to resources in there.

I just talked to someone today, one of the policemen. They have around 25 to 30 cranes in there, removing trees that are damaged or destroyed, and trying to set new poles and get things going again. It's a monumental task, but we've got a lot of people there to move it and make it happen.

MACDONALD: What is the prognosis for going forward and rebuilding?

BOLIN (via telephone): Well, that's a great question. I can't say that I've been here before. None of us have been here before. Even the experts are saying this is even new to them. You know, right now, it's one day at a time. The meeting I'm sitting in, they are very happy with their progress. They are moving forward very fast.

But the size of this thing, it is going to cost -- it will take some time to get it to where people can move back in, even into home that did not get destroyed.

MACDONALD: Again, people lost -- this is such a painful story. It is absolutely heartbreaking. It is heartache. We are showing images on camera right now of the rescue effort. Looking back, you know, years from now, vice mayor, what will stand out to you when it comes to what happened?

BOLIN (via telephone): Well, people are lost. We are here -- I'm here at the disaster center right now in Chico. We are meeting people, talking to them, answering what questions we can answer. But you know what, every time I leave here, I am more encouraged than I was before. There is a sense of optimism. They want to move back. They want to build their houses back again and make Paradise better than it was before.

So, even though the shock is devastating and most of us including myself lost everything we had, I live out of two bags right now, and most of the people in the same way.

MACDONALD: Vice mayor, you are living out of two bags? Is that what you just said? This is such a devastating situation that can drive people to their knees at night, at home, alone, in the shower, in the hallway. I mean, you're saying now that you're living out of two bags, is that what you just said?

BOLIN (via telephone): Well, all my possessions are in two bags. Those two bags, that's everything I got. We came out of -- we got what we could. We got some pictures out. But most of our possessions fit in our car.

MACDONALD: Yeah.

BOLIN (via telephone): That's the way everybody is. We had to flee and get out of there and we didn't have time to wait. But that's everybody. But you know, it's still amazing to see the optimism. I just got done talking to a guy. He is an elderly person who said, I'm going back, how long before I can start building?

MACDONALD: Wow.

BOLIN (via telephone): I'm going to be back up there. They want to get back to Paradise. That's home. They want to be back there.

MACDONALD: OK. Just be safe. We got to have you guys safe up there. You know, when things break down, humanity steps up. That's the story you just gave us, vice mayor. Thank you so much for coming on.

BOLIN (via telephone): Keep praying for us.

MACDONALD: We will.

BOLIN (via telephone): Don't forget about us.

MACDONALD: We will. Absolutely we will.

BOLIN (via telephone): Thank you.

MACDONALD: Vice Mayor Greg Bolin of Paradise, California. Switching gears now, the Republicans' biggest fear in 2020 may be losing the Republican suburban soccer mom, those moms always worried about pocketbook issues. They won't be happy about Republicans capping a popular deduction for state and local taxes when they do their tax returns next year, may even lost Republican House seats in the midterms.

Let's bring in the political panel, Kelsey Harkness with The Daily Signal and look who is here, Democrat strategist Scott Bolden. We welcome you both. Thank you so much.

SCOTT BOLDEN, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Thank you.

KELSEY HARKNESS, SENIOR NEWS PRODUCER, THE DAILY SIGNAL: Glad to be here.

MACDONALD: Kelsey, first to you. Five high tax states actually lost Republican seats in the midterms. What is your take on what is coming when it comes to the salt deductions?

HARKNESS: I think that tax reform is actually a winning issue for Republicans. I think if Republicans figure out how to communicate, how the tax reform plan has been good for them, and what more they could do if we continue down this path of lowering taxes for every day Americans and businesses to stimulate the economy, I do think it will suit President Trump very well in 2020.

MACDONALD: Let's shift gear here, Scott. Socialist Democrats still talking about free things like Medicare for all. Everybody knows that taxpayers have to put (ph) the bill there. You know, we are not hearing much about from Democrat socialist free college, free college tuition. Why is that, Scott?

BOLDEN: I'm trying to get over the term socialist Democrats but I'll move on from there. The reality is that we really don't know how to figure out or get people to trust how we pay for one. But secondly, the white working class just simply aren't buying it. Sixty percent of Americans like the idea compared to 38 percent.

But the reality is it's not selling with that group that we need to pull from Trump in 2020 and bring them back to the -- bring them back to the Democratic Party.

MACDONALD: Kelsey --

BOLDEN: Those are two short answers.

MACDONALD: Yeah, I hear you, Scott. Kelsey, federal aid to colleges has exploded to nearly $160 billion a year, but that has only fueled rampant tuition price hikes. The families out there watching know that. They know that we've also nationalized student loans. Taxpayers are on the hook for that. The more money you give to colleges, the more they raise tuition, Kelsey.

HARKNESS: Absolutely. College affordability is an issue that all Americans are --

MACDONALD: OK.

HARKNESS: -- concerned about. It is something that moving forward I think Republicans and Democrats could come together, but providing free college is certainly not the answer. That is going to cause more trouble for the country.

MACDONALD: Scott, I'm so sorry. We ran out of time. Scott, we want to have you back on. Kelsey, too. You guys have been great.

BOLDEN: Sure.

MACDONALD: Thank you so much.

HARKNESS: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Coming up, former FBI Director James Comey says he will not agree to closed hearings before Congress next week. He wants a public hearing instead. Republicans say he is doing fake (ph) grandstanding. We've got a common sense fix to stop James Comey here. We bring in Judge Napolitano on that.

But first, the Ukraine declaring martial law after Vladimir Putin's forces opened fire on Ukrainian navy vessels over the weekend, wounding a number of sailors. Tensions ratcheting up. NATO calling an emergency meeting over this. We are going to tell you what it all means. That's coming up, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Welcome back. The Ukraine declaring martial law today in regions bordering Russia. This after Russian forces opened fire on its naval vessels over the weekend. They seized three of those vessels and left several sailors wounded. NATO calling an emergency meeting, expressing full support of the Ukraine.

Joining me now, retired four stars army general and Fox News senior strategic analyst General Jack Keane. Great to see you, general.

JACK KEANE, SENIOR STRATEGIC ANALYST, FOX NEWS: Yeah, great to see you, Liz.

MACDONALD: What's your take on the situation because Russia is trying to claim that it was provoked by the Ukraine navy.

KEANE: That's likely a bald-faced lie, to be frank about it. They lie through their teeth on all of these things. In every incident they have, they always claim that they were provoked and they just had to take action.

What this is really about, Putin's strategy here, five years after he moved into -- almost five years after he moved in to Crimea and the eastern part of Ukraine, he's already trying to squeeze Ukraine even more economically.

North of the Kerch Strait where this incident took place is the Sea of Azov. There are two or three ports there in Ukraine that are used to bring out a lot of exports out of that country particularly steel. They move down through the strait in to the Black Sea and then out into the European and global markets.

Putin, I think, is leading up to squeezing that as much as he possibly can. He doesn't like the fact that Ukraine looks to the west for economic support from the E.U. and also from the United States, and he's trying to continue to discourage that. So that's the strategic thing that's taken place on Putin's part.

MACDONALD: General, what was your reaction to Democrat Senator Ben Cardin criticizing President Trump today, saying that Trump is helping Vladimir Putin "weaken the west by threatening NATO?"

KEANE: Yeah, I was surprised by that. Senator Cardin is a knowledgeable and respected member of the Senate. I agree with the statement that Putin's strategy is to weaken the transatlantic alliance, NATO, that is, and in my perspective, I think eventually force its collapse.

But he is dead wrong when he suggests that President Trump is weakening NATO. Quite the contrary. This is the first president in years who has actually gone to lengths to strengthen NATO by forcing them to increase the funding of the fence. And that is absolutely taking place largely because of the criticism that President Trump has unleashed against the NATO members leaders.

Also, we are pushing troops, Liz, into Eastern Europe as a deterrence against Russian aggression. That's U.S. troops and NATO troops. So, the senator is off in his conclusion there about Trump weakening NATO. Quite the contrary.

MACDONALD: And general, he is also suggesting Trump is not confronting Putin. What's your take on that?

KEANE: Well, I don't get that either because the facts don't support it. I mean, people overreact to the president wanting to have good relationship with adversarial leaders. North Korea, China, and Russia to name the three of them.

But the truth is, quite the contrary. He has issued sanctions as result of election meddling, as result of killing the Russian critic in the U.K. with a chemical biological weapon close to consulate throughout scores of Russian officials from here.

He has provided Ukraine with lethal aid. Obama refused to do it for four years. President Trump has done that to provide even more lethal aid. And twice he has struck the Russian proxy in Syria, the Assad regime, for the use of chemical weapons.

So, despite the rhetoric that President Trump wants relations to be good with Putin to see if we can solve some tough problems together, the policies that he is enacting are clearly pushing back on Russian aggression.

MACDONALD: General Jack Keane, thank you so much for your insight and analysis tonight. It was terrific. Thank you for your service to our country. Great to see you, general.

KEANE: Always good talking to you, Liz. Thank you.

MACDONALD: Coming up next, former FBI Director James Comey is grandstanding, says Republicans. Comey saying he will resist any subpoena from House Republicans. We are going to ask Judge Napolitano about how there is a common sense answer to stop Comey here from Trey Gowdy. That's next.

And then the crisis at the border. Migrants throwing rocks and other projectiles. The border patrol firing teargas. Border patrol now getting blasted. Border patrol now saying the migrants are actually pushing women and children to the front. Also new detail on how bad the crime really was pouring over the border under Obama.

Maxine Waters trying to say it is all political ploy by Trump. We are going to show how she is wrong. That's coming up with Senator-elect Kevin Cramer. He is up, next. Stay there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Former FBI Director James Comey now says he will stand up to any subpoena from House Republicans to testify behind closed doors unless he is allowed to testify in open public. There is a common sense fix here from Republican Trey Gowdy. He says forget the public congressional testimony. Instead, why not just videotape Comey's testimony and then make it public.

Let's bring in Judge Andrew Napolitano, Fox News senior judicial analyst. What do you think of that?

ANDREW NAPOLITANO, SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST, FOX NEWS: You know, when he was the head of the FBI, a lot of my FBI buddies and I had a lot of admiration for him. He was very, very popular. He always supported the troops. But some of the stuff -- I mean, the FBI agents in the field who risk their lives every day, some of the stuff is so political.

I don't think he wants the public hearing for self-aggrandisement. I think he wants to run out the clock until the Republicans who control the Judiciary Committee become the minority in six weeks.

Look, either a subpoena is valid or it's not, it's valid if it's properly served. And if they want to ask you questions that you likely don't know an answer about, you can't choose before --

MACDONALD: Does it stay valid when the Democrats take control?

NAPOLITANO: No. They would either not issue it because they don't care or they would issue their own. Now, on the substance, I would actually agree with him. I think the secret hearings are terrible. The public has the right to watch the questioner and watch the witness and draw their own conclusions.

If this hearing is held in secret, Republicans will leak their version, Democrats will leak their version, and the public, we pay all their salaries, are treated like children.

MACDONALD: Trey Gowdy is saying that's better than nothing. Actually, he is saying in a public hearing, it's actually worse because you only have five minutes to do a Q&A with the guy.

NAPOLITANO: Well, it doesn't have to be a videotape if they don't want a videotape. It can be a transcript of what has said. But when only certain people know the questions and answers and they got to do the leaking, that's government they leak.

MACDONALD: Are they going to get it done? Are Republicans get this done?

NAPOLITANO: I don't know the answer to that.

MACDONALD: What took them so long? Why did it take so long?

NAPOLITANO: That has been a very valid criticism of them because the Republicans have controlled the House of Representatives and the White House for the past two years. They didn't serve any subpoenas. They did it all by negotiating.

Now in the death rows of their tenure, they're finally serving a subpoena. They could have done this a year and a half ago at the time he was fired by the president.

MACDONALD: All right. Finishing off a tweet by -- the president has been tweeting about this. He has been very upset with of course again tweeting about the Mueller probe. What's your take now with the Mueller probe? Are we going to get the results?

NAPOLITANO: I happen to believe that the president is being advised by his lawyers not to tweet, not to taunt the alligator until after he crosses the stream, and the president is rejecting that advice. I don't know where is this going to go but I have a feeling, a feeling a lot is going to come down from Bob Mueller before Christmas and some after the Democrats take control of the House after Christmas.

MACDONALD: Wow. Judge, will you come back? We need you.

NAPOLITANO: Of course.

MACDONALD: Judge Napolitano.

NAPOLITANO: I'll see you in the morning.

MACDONALD: Great to see you. We love the judge. You know, Barney (ph) says this is a spin-off show.

(LAUGHTER)

NAPOLITANO: Barney (ph) is trying to take credit for your success.

MACDONALD: Yes, he is.

(LAUGHTER)

MACDONALD: Coming up next, Democrat Maxine Waters is trying to say the crisis at the border is just a political ploy by President Trump. We will bring in Republican Senator-elect Kevin Cramer. He is fired up about that. He is ready to go. Stay there.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RUSH LIMBAUGH, RADIO TALK SHOW HOST AND CONSERVATIVE POLITICAL COMMENTATOR: There's not one indictment, there's not one conviction that Mueller has that has anything to do with the Russians having anything to do with the election in 2016.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Fast-moving developments at the border. Border officials defending their use of teargas after 500 migrants rushed the border. They said migrants are shoving women and children to the front. If they were really peaceful asylum-seekers, the migrants would not be throwing rocks at border patrol officials.

Dozens of migrants were arrested on the U.S. side of the border for crossing illegally. Also, Democrat Maxine Waters says the crisis there is nothing but a political ploy by President Trump. Kevin Cramer is a Republican senator-elect from North Dakota. He joins us now. Great to see you, sir.

REP. KEVIN CRAMER (R), NORTH DAKOTA: Good to be with you. Thank you.

MACDONALD: Sir, what is your take on all of this?

CRAMER: I think that Congresswoman Waters is missing the entire point. I'm surprised because if there's one thing that the crisis at the border has shown us, it really should be a wake-up call for all of those who doubted the seriousness of the situation.

To somehow suggest that it is manufactured crisis when there are 6,000 people who walked all the way through their country of Mexico to come to our border and try to storm it, that's not a fabrication, that's not a Hollywood production, those are real people. I think that it deserves the type of scrutiny that our president is giving.

MACDONALD: Yes, sir, it's hard to say that it is not a crisis when there's a video showing what's happening. You know there are some 5,000 migrants camped in Tijuana. You know there has been information coming in that the government documents show that under Obama, there was something like more than 24,000 serious incidents that occurred in 2014 of crime and violence among illegal border crossers.

CRAMER: Right.

MACDONALD: How can Maxine Waters say this is just a stunt?

CRAMER: Because Maxine Waters is doing the exact thing that she is accusing our president of doing and that is politicizing the crisis. That's exactly the wrong approach. I think, you know, few weeks ago, our voters voted in a divided government to replace the unified Republican government.

I think the message that I take away from that is that they want two sides to get together and come up with some solutions. I think there are solutions that should be acceptable to all sides as long as one side is willing to give the other side something in exchange for the thing that they want.

That's been the problem with the four pillars approach that the president offered up which I thought had winners all the way around but the winners didn't want to be winners unless somebody else is a loser. I think that's exactly what the borders are telling us they don't want in this next Congress.

MACDONALD: Here is Brandon Judd, the president of the National Border Council. He said this -- Here's what he said this morning about what's going on. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BRANDON JUDD, PRESIDENT, NATIONAL BORDER PATROL UNION: Our agents did not deploy teargas until they were hit with projectiles. Rocks and bottles. That's when they in fact deploy the teargas. If you look at what this caravan did, they pushed the women and children up to the front. How monstrous is that?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Your reaction to that, sir?

CRAMER: Well, clearly, this is not the type of refugee crisis that is sponsored by your local church. The refugees have come here through the right process, come with sponsors. They come through the legal process. And I think that he's exactly right.

When you look at the video, when you think that they can't possibly be peace-loving asylum seekers, who would do this to children and women and innocent people, nor were they storm a border illegally, they've come through illegal (ph) process, in which case they would be met with the type of hospitality that is significant and that is our tradition.

MACDONALD: Kevin Cramer, senator-elect out of North Dakota. Great to see you, sir. Thank you so much for coming in. We appreciate it. We welcome you back on soon.

CRAMER: My pleasure. Thank you.

MACDONALD: Thank you for having us in your homes. It has been a jam- packed hour. Thank you so much for watching. Lou Dobbs is here next on the Fox Business Network. Have a good night.

END

Jack Keane Discusses How Ukrainian Lawmakers Voted to Declare Martial Law in Areas Bordering Russia, after Russian Attacked and Seized Ukrainian Navy Ships; Comey to Push Back on Subpoena for Closed-Door Testimony; Judge Andrew Napolitano Discusses How Former FBI Director James Comey is Expected to Push Back on a Subpoena Issued by House Republicans; Securing the Border: 500 to 1,000 Migrants Involved in Attempt to Rush the Border; Dozens of Migrants Arrested on the U.S. Side of the Border for Crossing Illegally; Democrat Maxine Waters Says the Crisis There is Nothing but a Political Ploy by President Trump
