urn:contentItem:5SFM-DNJ1-JB20-G36F-00000-00President Trump Versus `New York Times'; The President Obama's Netflix Deal Could be Worth $50 Million; U.S.-NOKO Talks; U.S.-China Trade Talks; President Trump Responds To Roseanne Cancellation; Renaming the RINOS; Bill To Fund Trump's Wall2018-05-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:40ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTDiane Black, Gregg Jarrett, Victoria ToensingNEWSDomestic053001cb.229President Trump Versus `New York Times'; The President Obama's Netflix Deal Could be Worth $50 Million; U.S.-NOKO Talks; U.S.-China Trade Talks; President Trump Responds To Roseanne Cancellation; Renaming the RINOS; Bill To Fund Trump's WallLou Dobbs, Ed Rollins, Michael Goodwin, Sebastian Gorka, Howard Kurtz, Lisa Kennedy Montgomery

LOU DOBBS, ANCHOR, LOU DOBBS TONIGHT: Good evening, everybody. Our top stories. The special counsel flailing and the Dems' desperation and deep state dismay on full display tonight. Robert Mueller reportedly intent on using Attorney General Sessions in a poorly considered effort to go after President Trump, building a certain to fail argument of obstruction of justice, a charge that has nothing to do with Russia collusion and like collusion, it has nothing to do with President Trump.

We take up the sorry state of Mueller's contrived witch hunt with attorney Victoria Toensing and FOX legal analyst Gregg Jarrett. Congressional RINOs, determined, apparently, to save their own seats and skins by sacrificing the seats and skins of conservatives and mainstream Republicans. And the RINOs and their leaders have landed on, you guessed it, amnesty for illegal immigrants, which will assure the Dems a huge midterm victory if they follow through.

RINO Ryan acolyte Kevin McCarthy says they're still working on a DACA deal. Disaster at the border and in the midterms, no concern of theirs just as long as Wall Street, the Koch brothers and the Chamber of Commerce keep their money flowing. Tennessee Congresswoman Diane Black is among our guests here tonight. She'll be talking about the fight to fund the border wall, her means of funding the border wall and fake news caught in the act by the president once again.

The New York Times busted for lying about the massive crowd at President Trump's national rally. And this time, President Trump gets a rare gift in return. We'll tell you all about it here tonight.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: This feels just like before our election. This is a big crowd of people. This is a lot of people. It's a lot of people. With bad weather and bad everything and they're still coming in.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: And our top story tonight, Robert Mueller desperate to keep his presidential subversion mission going while RINO Republicans have developed a strange strain of schizophrenia in the increasingly absurdist Russia witch hunt. With the credibility of his all Democrat Dem (ph) team shredded (ph) and even Dem and (ph) the deep state warning him not to interfere in the midterm elections, Special Counsel Mueller is now fully focused on taking the farce he leads to new levels.

Obstruction of justice the call now. Mueller already knows he has zero chance of indicting a sitting president, period. And yet, he has apparently come up with a new direction for his incomprehensible and confused investigation, focusing now on a meeting between President Trump and his attorney general, a meeting in which the president asks Sessions to reconsider his recusal in the Russia case.

Even RINO Trey Gowdy, no friend of the president and committed establishmentarian admitted Sessions never should have taken the Attorney General job if he intended to recuse himself. But as is the RINO way, Gowdy found a quick way to return to his form and defend the FBI's action in planting a spy in the Trump presidential campaign.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. TREY GOWDY (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: I am even more convinced that the FBI did exactly what my fellow citizens would want them to do when they got the information they got and that it has nothing to do with Donald Trump.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: If you can believe that. Extraordinary. Extraordinary. A piece of reasoning. Here to sort it all out, attorney Victoria Toensing, founding partner at diGenova & Toensing. Victoria, great to have you with us. I mean, but I -- when I saw Trey Gowdy say that, I -- I was stunned. Because even by his standards, that's confused, it is absolutely absurd and it's contradicted and contravened by history.

VICTORIA TOENSING, LAWYER, DIGENOVA & TOENSING: Well, as I understand it, they didn't see documents, they just got a briefing. So there's -- to rely on -- on a briefing, I don't trust nothing until I see the documents and so I don't know why he's out spewing this stuff when -- he sounds incredible. And he also says -- this is (ph) the same thing -- well, if the president doesn't have anything to hide, he should just sit down with Mueller.

No. Give me a break. It's spoken like somebody who's never been a defense attorney, which he hasn't and if he were and gave that advice to Trump he could be sued for ineffective assistance of counsel. Let me tell you about Scooter Libby. You know -- you know -- the (ph) nutshell. He came in to the grand jury and said X and a journalist said Y and guess what? Scooter got indicted. And he didn't have anything to hide at all.

This is -- this is ridiculous. I'm -- I'm going to just quote Jim Comey about this. He says if a prosecutor doesn't know his case in a year, he should be fired because he's incompetent. And now it's been a year. Mr. Mueller, it should be over.

DOBBS: You know, Victoria, I think you're exactly right. But this goes beyond that. As all of us in the media -- let or right wing media, whatever you want to call it, is all of us following this, citizens by the tens of millions watching their president being pursued, persecuted when there -- there is (ph) on its face just nothing to the case whatsoever. And as you say, it's not only been a year for the special counsel but that special counsel case is built on over a -- almost a year of investigation by the FBI.

And it is --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: -- everyone knows -- everyone knows there is nothing there by the - - by the admission of the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, by the report of the House Intelligence Committee and the special counsel himself has come forward with nothing within the scope of the mission.

TOENSING: Let me add one more point --

DOBBS: Sure.

TOENSING: -- that is (ph) also important because Trey was an assisting U.S. attorney out in -- you know, in South Carolina. But he doesn't know Maine (ph) justice. I do. I was deputy assistant A.G. there. And I know what cartwheels and -- and angst everyone went through to even open an investigation against a member of Congress. I can tell you that to open this investigation against the presidential campaign within months of the election had to go to the attorney if not to the White House.

This is not done lightly in the Department of Justice. And he doesn't -- Trey doesn't know. He doesn't know diddly-squat about what the rules are for opening an investigation into a presidential campaign.

DOBBS: And -- and -- and Gowdy is a lame duck. So it's almost like he's job hunting out there as he does -- gets ready for his term in Congress to end. I mean, the man is confused just in his own narrative. Let's turn to that narrative, that the people would want a spy planted in the presidential campaign if there were Russian meddling. Don't you think that it would be -- the first thing you would expect of the FBI is first to stop the meddling and to go after the Russians who were doing the meddling.

And instead, we had a president in President Obama who did absolutely nothing, an FBI, a CIA, an NSA who as best we can tell knew not a thing about what the Russians were doing and were absolutely impotent to stop it, to thwart them or any way defend the interests of the United States.

TOENSING: Well here's the proper protocol. They should have gone to the presidential campaign and told them that they were fearful that the Russians were trying to infiltrate, meddle, whatever it is, the term burn (ph) they want to use and ask for their support. And they did not do that. Why? Because they were busy making up the evidence to frame the president. That's what they were doing. That's what this is all about, talked about it for about six months now.

There was a brazen plot to frame President Trump, then the presidential candidate.

DOBBS: And again, you know, I think you're exactly right. But all of this understood, all of this now understood to the American people and yet the special counsel goes on. And we now are watching the Dems and the deep state in Washington in particular divide over the issue of whether there was a spy in the campaign or an informant, as if that is a distinction that amounts to a difference.

The -- the narrative is now turned, they were simply trying to protect the Trump campaign, not -- and watch out for Russians. Even as they did not do a thing, as far as we know, in the (ph) investigation whatsoever of (ph) the Russian offensive, largely a cyber offensive against the United States.

TOENSING: You know, one of the reasons, they say, was the Michael -- General Flynn got $45,000 for a speech paid for by Russia. Well, Bill Clinton got a half a million dollars on a speech from Russia. Where were they in there protecting the -- the Clintons from the Russians for goodness sake?

DOBBS: And as you mentioned, the president getting a half million dollar speaking fee, we cannot forget that almost $145 million went into the coffers of the Clinton Foundation and -- by any -- any reasoning of any kind of honesty there was a connection, a paper play that went right back to Uranium One and the scandal that followed. With Robert Mueller, by the way, acting as errand boy to the Russians during the entire -- well, event.

TOENSING: Mueller was the FBI director --

DOBBS: Yes.

TOENSING: -- at that time.

DOBBS: Yes. Yes. And here we go, as if this is -- we're supposed to pretend that all of this makes sense Victoria? There -- where is there -- is there not a large, in this country, any spirit that says when your are confronted by the absurdity, the obvious lies, the obvious crimes that have been committed and the obvious dereliction of duty and failure to intercede in a Russian offensive against the U.S elections and the interest of this country, there was not a single person in the intelligence community that was so -- they were so sure of Trump's collusion with Russia, but the couldn't figure out what was happening in real time and couldn't mount a counter offensive. That's stunning.

TOENSING: Well here again is where Trey Gowdy is really off track. He says, well let's just let the investigation take it where it needs to go. No. The President has to be president and he has been harmed by this ever since the first day he took office.

He cannot make a decision about Russia without having it second guessed because of the Russian collusion. He's got to make decisions about Russia. I mean Barack Obama did, he was doing reset which failed.

But the President still has to deal with Russia. He has to deal with foreign leaders. What -- they read the papers, they have to come in and say, hey are you going to be here next year at this time. That takes away his leverage with them.

DOBBS: Which is .

TOENSING: This is affecting the Presidency and it's got to stop.

DOBBS: And it's obviously the purpose of the both the Special Counsel, the Democratic party and the deep state, which is to support this administration and they certainly, if they have their way, will not stop with this Special Counsel recon by .

TOENSING: And this obstruction of justice -- this obstruction of justice is ridiculous.

DOBBS: Well, I haven't talked to an attorney who I respect that thinks that there is any possibility of prosecuting a president for obstruction of justice in any form. Period.

TOENSING: Well he could, yes, if they said, oh and destroy evidence, but let the tutorial on obstruction of justice is that you have to willfully interfere with the process of justice by threatening a witness, I'm reading it from the law books, influencing or impeding a witness. Now what impeding did the President asking the Attorney General to unrecuse himself? There was -- it didn't affect the investigation in any way what so ever .

DOBBS: And doesn't go to the intent .

TOENSING: Embarrassing legally. It's embarrassing that Mueller doesn't know better than that.

DOBBS: And powerfully there has never been a president, either ever indicted for obstruction of justice, ever charged with obstruction of justice .

TOENSING: You can't indict a .

DOBBS: . let alone successfully prosecuted. What?

TOENSING: You can't indict a sitting president, so there.

DOBBS: No, no. Another little problem for this Special Counsel. All right, Victoria, as always, instructive, great to have you with us. Thanks so much. Victoria Toensing.

TOENSING: Bye.

DOBBS: Still ahead, even Dems are warning the Mueller team not to meddle in the midterms. I think they're a little late. Looks to me like that effort is well underway. We'll have more on the fake witch hunt, well it's a real witch hunt, the fake Mueller phony witch hunt, how's that? Legal analyst Gregg Jarrett joins me here next.

(COMMERICAL BREAK)

DOBBS: Even some Dems, some of those in the deep state are warning Special Counsel Mueller and his 13 angry Democrats, as the President likes to call them, not -- not to mess around with the midterm elections. Take a listen to Congressman Chris Coons.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CHRIS COONS, D-DE: I would expect that if there is going to be bombshell announcements out of the Mueller investigation, we'll see them in the next two months and we won't see big announcements in the weeks leading up to the midterm election.

JOHN BERMAN, CNN ANCHOR: And you're -- and that is what you are calling for, just to be clear, correct?

COONS: Yes, I think -- yes.

BERMAN: Okay.

COONS: I believe that it's important that the Special Counsel avoid any major announcements in the weeks before -- the months before the midterm elections.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Well, I misspoke, he's Senator Coons, not Congressman Coons. Fox News legal analyst is exactly that. Gregg Jarrett, author of the new book "The Russia Hoax: The illicit Scheme to Clear Hillary Clinton and Frame Donald Trump," now available for preorder everywhere you go to preorder such wonderful products as your book.

GREGG JARRETT, LEGAL ANALYST: Yes. Thank you.

DOBBS: Which we recommend highly.

JARRETT: Thank you very much.

DOBBS: Let's start with "The New York Times," I mean where do we go with all of this?

JARRETT: Well, "The New York Times" is desperate, but Robert Mueller must really be desperate if he thinks that scolding the attorney general over his wrongful recusal is somehow obstruction of justice.

Under the law, obstruction requires a corrupt purpose, and as Victoria pointed out, a lie, threat, bribe, destruction of evidence or altering a document. Scolding you A.G. because he was dumb in relying on the wrong regulation in his recusal is .

DOBBS: That's what I just pointed out for .

JARRETT: Yes. It is not obstruction of justice and so this just underscores what a colossal waste of tax payer money Mueller has cost us.

DOBBS: What -- as I asked Victoria, let me ask you this. I mean we now know many of the facts that are fundamental to the Special Counsel appointment, we know, for example, Rod Rosenstein, there is no question about his conflict. The series of conflicts profound and disqualifying conflicts that he had .

JARRETT: Right.

DOBBS: . whether it pertains to Mueller, whether it pertains to the very idea of being a Special Counsel. The country understands the corruption, the abject profound corruption of the Department of Justice leadership and then of the FBI, the five top officials in the FBI are gone. Why do we persist in this? Why are we, in the media, supposed to pretend, even though we certainly do not, but anyone in this media pretend this is just a perfectly rational process in history in which the President of the United States, Donald J. Trump is being persecuted by the deep state and the Democratic party.

JARRETT: Americans now are beginning to realize who the president is, the victim not the villain here. That there was never any evidence of a crime to justify a criminal investigation. No legitimate intelligence to justify counter intelligence investigation. And Americans are turning against Robert Mueller and James Comey. The latest CBS poll found, a majority of Americans believe this investigation is politically motivated and Americans are right, it is.

DOBBS: No question about it. Let's turn to Jeff Sessions. The president saying point blank and this is one of the many things that we love the president for. I mean he just said straight forwardly, I don't care what you call it. I wish I'd chosen a different man to be - or woman, to be the attorney general of the United States. And certainly, my gosh, when you look at what Jeff Sessions has done and the way in which he's gone about it. Anyone in their right mind would say what have I done here watching him perform.

JARRETT: Yes I've called it .

DOBBS: Perform.

JARRETT: . affectless attorney general and that's a generous assessment of his skills, he has no skills. The president is rightfully angry because Jeff Sessions, while he was standing there taking the oath of office knew that he would be recusing himself. He testified before congress that the very next morning he met with officials at the department of justice to put in motion his recusale. And again he relied on the wrong regulation in the recusal. But he betrayed the president, he wasn't honest with the president of that. He should have told president Trump, here is what I'm thinking about doing.

And the president who said hold on a minute this is an important investigation, you need to be in control of it. Let's look at the law and they would have concluded, I don't have to recuse myself in a counter intelligence probe only in a criminal case. Said it was then not a criminal case. So you know this was a severe and serious betrayal of the president of the United States. No wonder he is angry, I'd be doubably angry.

DOBBS: Yes it's - this president is measured, he's shown patience of an extraordinary degree. And he still is the sail from 360 degrees from every quarter in this country. Even though he has a rising approval rating and a base that is so understated by the national left way media that it's observed. But this is really cold comfort because we are watching a president who could do so much .

JARRETT: Right.

DOBBS: . if unfettered by these little left wing, deep state gnomes who inhabit much of Washington.

JARRETT: The democrats I think are running scared about this Mueller probe. They're beginning to realize the boomerang effect that it will have in the mid term elections if it persists.

DOBBS: Yes.

JARRETT: Unless you add(ph) senator Warner saying it needs to end this year. No kidding senator. Now isn't that a clever thing he did.

DOBBS: He's just got to be just cackling to himself at the old boys school lounge right now. As he suggested it. Wrap up sometimes this year. This is the man who - well, yes anyway. I'm more upset with Richard Burke wrinkle for turning over the senate intelligence.

JARRETT: They're two peas in a pod aren't they?

DOBBS: Yes well pea as you would say is a nice word for what they are. Gregg Jarrett who only uses nice words let me assure you.

JARRETT: Thank you Lou.

DOBBS: Appreciate it. Be sure to vote in our poll tonight, do you believe Netflix will pay a price for it's partisan payoff to the former president and first lady? Just asking. Cast your vote on twitter at LouDobbs. Follow me on Twitter at Lou Dobbs, like me on Face Book, follow me on instagram at Lou Dobbs Tonight. I `m sure president Obama does.

JARRETT: Probably not.

DOBBS: Absolutely sure not.

JARRETT: Maybe not.

DOBBS: Up next president Trump holding a massive rally last night in Nashville and the fake news media, they got caught lying through their teeth. Can you imagine that? And we're going to tell you the really good news in that fake news. Ed Rollins, Michael Goodwin join me here next, stay with us we'll be right back.

DOBBS: You're going to love this. Fake news, New York Times caught lying on the crowd size at the Trump rally in Nashville last night. President Trump called them out with his Tweet saying the "Falling and Corrupt NYTimes estimated the crowd last night at "1,000 people" when in fact it was many times that number in the arena was rocking. This is the way they demean and disparage. They are very dishonest people who don't get me and never did!" Well New York Times reporter Julie Davis did recant Tweeting "President Trump is correct about his crowd last night. My estimate was way off and we have corrected our story to reflect the fire marshals estimate of 5,500 people. When we get it wrong we say so."

Oh sure you do. And even their apology the times continuing to down play the size of the crowd. All man, the president's campaign putting out their own report estimating a crowd of 8,000 strong. We're going right here with a 1,000. I'm telling you right now. And don't you love the fact that Ed Rollins former Reagan White House political director, great America pack chairmen and Michael Goodwin Pulitzer Prize winning columnist for the New York Post are both with us tonight on this historic accusation which the New York Times - Michael the New York has admitted they were wrong and wronged the president.

MICHAEL GOODWIN: Yes I'm an aluminist of the New York Times and on days like this I don't tell anybody. So let's just keep it amongst ourselves.

DOBBS: He only missed by five times. I mean .

GOODWIN: But what's amazing is how can you -- if you are sitting in that crowd and you're estimating, how can you be so wrong unless, it's part of what you want. You want it to be a smaller crowd. That's the clear implication when you're so far off.

DOBBS: Yes, I think he's right, the mean disparage.

GOODWIN: Yes.

DOBBS: That's the purpose of a left-wing media in this country and they really think they're serving some high purpose. Namely, Hillary Clinton when they do it. I mean, there is still embedded in these people and absolute disgust for the craft and the tenets of this craft and a just an absolute commitment to furthering the interest of the left-wing ideology and the partisan Dems.

ED ROLLINS, FOX BUSINESS POLITICAL ANALYST: Well it kills them because they just can't understand how someone like Donald Trump could be elected president and --

DOBBS: You know let's think about that, wait a minute,

ROLLINS: Seriously.

DOBBS: Think about that, which one of these idiots in the National left- wing media or the White House press core, you know, would be able to carry his books to school? He's smarter than they are, he's been more successful, I mean, who that heck they're these -- who do they think they are?

ROLLINS: They totally underestimate the public out, that the public basically had a very long tedious campaign. They made a judgment, she ran a crummy campaign, he ran a great campaign.

DOBBS: Wait a minute.

ROLLINS: No, just let me finish.

DOBBS: OK, I'm going to let you finish.

ROLLINS: She spent -- she spent 10 times more money than he did, she inherited the Obama campaign couldn't implement his structure and he wanted fair and square and they still -- two years later, still complaining about it.

DOBBS: Yes, you know I want to find her square, but you left out one part, she ran a crooked campaign. The entire Democratic Party was led by crooked cheating, I don't even -- what do you call Debbie Wasserman Schultz? What do you call --

GOODWIN: Well and she -- and she had the FBI on her side, she had the CIA on her side, she cheated the Obama White House.

DOBBS: She quashed Bernie Sanders. And that -- and that guy basically went out and said you know, I got myself a beach house or on the lake, I mean -- and he was satisfied (INAUDIBLE) I mean that -- I mean they drained his blood, we could see it happening before our eyes.

GOODWIN: But Lou you asked her who do these people think they are, me in the New York Times, that they think they are the elite of the country who should pick the President of the United States. You know after the Washington Post editorial board met with John Kasich, one of the members came out and said we all thought that should be the Republican nominee. Now, this women editorial board that has never endorsed the Republican for president but they want to pick the Republican nominee, that's who they think they are.

ROLLINS: Well they pick President Hillary Clinton. The Hillary they pick President Kerry, they picked President Gore. Those are the endorsements that they've made in the last several elections, they'd never endorsed a Republican.

DOBBS: Right.

ROLLINS: And never will.

GOODWIN: New York Times has not endorsed the Republicans since Dwight Eisenhower.

DOBBS: Yes, let me turn real quickly to the Obama is going to work for Netflix their content officer Ted Sarandos and his wife -- his wife became ambassador to the Bahamas. Thank You Mr. President Obama. And they put $50 million, it looks like a payoff and he's pledging there won't be any politics in it. The only thing they know is politics, so just exactly what would be the point of bringing them on with $50 million of company money?

GOODWIN: Well Netflix has become a real Obama administration hopping off point, right. Susan Rice is on the Netflix board now.

DOBBS: Board.

GOODWIN: Well yes, look, I mean, I saw that too that there won't be any politics but that's what he said about Obamacare too. That's what he said about all those policies (INAUDIBLE)

DOBBS: This was -- this was Sarandos saying and not just Trump -- not just Trump. We wouldn't take -- we wouldn't take -- I mean, not just Obama we wouldn't take Obama's word for that.

ROLLINS: I promise you, I don't know what's he going to do, talking about his presidency or he's going to talk about community organizing. But Netflix is an ongoing money-making machine right today and it's going to get damaged by this, I'm convinced of it.

DOBBS: Do you think people are going to boycott it?

ROLLINS: I think a lot of people boycott it.

DOBBS: I think anybody's going to --

ROLLINS: Just ask the NFL -- just ask the NFL how it works when you --

DOBBS: Do you think anybody's going to go to their account logo, go in there and just disengage from the DVD service, the streaming service and just --

ROLLINS: I think it could happen here. I think it could happen.

DOBBS: I think it could too. (INAUDIBLE) I know some people who did that, I know something. Ed Rollins, Michael Goodwin, thank you both for being here.

ROLLINS: Thank you.

DOBBS: Up next, things are looking out for the historic June 12 summit. The prospects for it at summit of course between President Trump and Kim Jong-un. We'll have the latest for you. Dr. Sebastian Gorka is here next. We're going to talk summit, we're going to talk Comeys and what happened to all of that intervention by the Russians in our elections? Do any of our intelligence agencies actually work? Let's find out here next, stay with us.

DOBBS: Negotiations between the United States and North Korea moving ahead, hoping to move ahead to in fact through the realization of that June 12th summit planned in Singapore. Today Secretary of State Pompeo met with the top North Korean diplomat here in New York City. The White House also sending delegations to Singapore and to the Korean DMZ where they are holding talks with North Korean officials. Joining us tonight is Fox News National Security Strategist, former strategist to the president, Dr. Sebastian Gorka. Great to have you with us, Seb. Let's start with these talks moving ahead the White House making it clear, if they can and if the conditions are right and that means that basically assurances of denuclearization according to some template that the administration has that June 12th meeting they think can still happen.

SEBASTIAN GORKA, FOX BUSINESS NATIONAL SECURITY STRATEGIST: Yes Lou, it really looks as if things are back on track. And knowing who we have in the White House now John Bolton, Pompeo at State, Mattis at Defense, this isn't going to be some airy-fairy piece of paper, this is going to be incredibly stringent. I've recommended that we have American inspectors access to civilian and military sites and also snap inspections, none of that garbage from the Iran deal from Obama where the Iranian have 30 days where you have to clean up their sites.

DOBBS: Yes, I don't think anyone has any illusions about this administration having any kinship to the previous administration. There is this issue of China that is --

GORKA: Yes.

DOBBS: -- percolating and I think perhaps even profoundly in the background, whether it be the reaction to U.S. ships in freedom of navigation maneuvers in the South China Sea, whether it be trade talks that Mnuchin led frankly to the verge of disaster, which have been rescued it appears. But still we're looking at 301 actions by the administration against some of the imports that's in abeyance until of the 15th of June further penalties could ensue and by penalties, I mean, tariffs from -- so we're seeing some real tough talk here coming as well from the Chinese leadership. What do you make of the strains and the prospects and potential import to the overall relationship with China.

GORKA: Well I learned very rapidly once I was in the White House. I came in to do counterterrorism, but I learned once you have the clearances and read the reports that there's only one strategic threat we face today, and that's China. And luckily the president came around to that view as well and he takes this very seriously. That's why we have the 301 investigation, the tariffs and everything else. The real challenge is not the White House, the challenges the U.S. business elite especially in Silicon Valley. These people have facilitated the rise of China when Apple, when Google go in there and invest and give away their I.P., their intellectual property as part of their access to those markets. Basically, they're undermining not only the U.S. economy but U.S. national security. So, this is an educational process as much as a national security one. And we need the private sector to get on board with the president's message that China cannot be allowed to displace us economically or militarily.

DOBBS: Yes, and to give that a balanced perspective as well in terms of the types of industry not only Silicon Valley and big tech but also U.S. manufacturing which includes --

GORKA: Yes.

DOBBS: -- some of our most elite companies, including, elite in the good sense. They're rarified expertise and products. And that is Boeing for example, having to do compelled transfers of I.P. in order to sell aircraft to China. And the list goes on. All sorts of deals like that which the president to his great credit has identified and is trying to reverse but with a congress whose leadership is bought and paid for by the Koch brothers, the Business Roundtable and the Chamber of Commerce. It is very difficult and Wall Street, very difficult for the president to carry his message through. Today the president dealing with that very issue remembering very clearly Bob Iger walked off one of his industry councils, business councils, taking a shot at him. The bad blood inappropriately so this president when he needed help, and you know, people like Iger were a problem and not part of the solution.

GORKA: Yes, Lou at the end of the day it's a very simple question, it's the conflict between short-termism and making your shareholders happy at the next quarterly meeting or whether it's actually the interests of the nation writ large. All Americans we have to have a long-term approach because, guess what? The Chinese have won.

DOBBS: And there is also a very simple word for the problem and that is multi-national when applied to businesses. They are -- no matter where they do business they had better be American businesses operating globally. Dr. Sebastian Gorka as always, we appreciate it. Good to have you with us.

GORKA: Thank you, Lou.

DOBBS: Up next, President Trump calls out the left-wing national media for hypocrite -- hypocritical treatment of Roseanne Barr. We'll have the story for you straight ahead. Yes, it goes on, stay with us

DOBBS: President Trump accusing ABC of double standard after the network canceled its hit show Roseanne over the stars controversial and racist tweets. Fox News Media Correspondent Howard Kurtz with our report.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

HOWARD KURTZ, FOX NEWS MEDIA CORRESPONDENT: Everyone has an opinion on ABC's cancellation of Roseanne Barr show which she plays a dogged Trump supporter. And today the President himself joined the fray. Rather than assess Bars racist tweet likening former Obama a Valerie Jarrett to an ape, the President tweeted that Disney CEO Bob Iger called Valerie Jarrett to let her know that ABC does not tolerate comments like those made by Roseanne Barr. Gee, he never called President Donald J Trump to apologize for the horrible statements made and said about me on ABC. Maybe I just didn't get the call. This followed a bizarre tweet storm overnight in which Barr ripped her critics, apologized and blamed a sleep medication. Guys, I did something unforgivable so do not defend me. It was 2:00 in the morning and I was ambient tweeting. It was egregious, indefensible. That prompted the drug's manufacturer to declare that racism is not a known side effect of any Santa Fe medication.

Now, some Roseanne fans say HBO should boot Bill Maher for once jokingly comparing Trump's hair to an orangutan. Twitter can be a treacherous tool for anyone in public life. CNN fired host Reza Aslan for tweeting that Trump was a piece of S an embarrassment to humankind. CNN also fired pro- Trump Contributor Jeffrey Lord for tweeting the Nazi salute, Sieg Heil. But ESPN took no action against former Sports Center co-host Jemele Hill for tweeting that Trump is a white supremacist. She was later suspended for suggesting that Dallas Cowboys be boycotted over player protests. MSNBC did not discipline host Joy Reid for decade-old homophobic tweets she admitted were dumb and hateful. Trump's tweeting has also drawn flak from mocking MSNBC's Mika Brzezinski for a supposed facelift to yesterday's unproven charge that Robert Mueller is meddling with the midterms but he also punches back against vicious criticism.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

KURTZ: Twitter erupts in anger so quickly that offenders can lose their jobs and their reputations within hours as Roseanne Barr just learned even having T.V.s most popular show doesn't protect you. Lou?

DOBBS: Certainly not if you're in Hollywood. Howard Kurtz, thank you. On Wall Street, stocks closing higher. The Dow Jones Industrial is up more than 300 points, the S&P up 34, the NASDAQ climbing 66 points, volume of the big board picking up to 3.5 billion shares, total mortgage application volume dropping nearly three percent for the week marking the sixth straight week of losses even as home prices rise. And a reminder to listen to my reports three times a day coast to coast on the Salem Radio Network. Up next, RINOs claim they're this close to getting an illegal alien amnesty vote on the House floor. All of this and more we, take up with Congressman Diane Black. She joins us here next.

DOBBS: Platoons of RINOs in the House are pushing for amnesty for illegal immigrants even if it runs the party right off the cliff in the midterms. House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy telling Fox News the GOP is very close to bringing an immigration bill to the House floor that would include some kind of a DACA deal. A group of RINOs working with the Dems to force a House vote on a number of immigration bills but party leaders oppose that idea, we are told, but what if they're forced to do it? Wouldn't that be terrible because then they could line up with their, well the Business Roundtable, the Chamber of Commerce, the Koch Brothers, you know the usual bunch? Well joining us tonight is an outstanding Republican Congressman from Tennessee. She's also the Chair of the House Budget Committee, Diane Black joining us tonight, great to have you with us. And this is -- I've got to share this with you because RINOs, do you like that word RINO?

REP. DIANE BLACK (R-TN), CHAIRWOMAN, HOUSE BUDGET COMMITTEE: I do like it. It says what they are.

DOBBS: We had a viewer named Wanda, if we can show this because Ed Rollins is very concerned about the use of the term RINO. RINO, he loves rhinoceroses and so Wanda's suggestion, instead of RINO, because he was looking for something -- some way to avoid it she suggested opossums, there they are, well, one of each and armadillos. And she said she prefers possums. Nobody ever calls them opossums that I've heard. Possums, I don't think we've got it yet Wanda but let's see what the Congressman says. What do you think? Do you want to go with RINO or armadillo or possums or keep looking?

BLACK: I think I'm going to stick with the RINOs because the acronym actually is just exactly what it is. And so I think I'll stick with RINO.

DOBBS: So you've got an idea about border security that I think's fascinating and that is to raise the money and build a dadgum wall. Just get it done.

BLACK: That's right Lou. Look, we have been talking about building this wall. Past administrations continue to say yes, we're going to build this wall but it doesn't get funded. And so I have an idea that will jumpstart all of this and that is to actually have a dedicated fund within the Treasury where the American people who want to see the wall will have an opportunity to be able to just send their money in. And people ask me well, is this something that's new? Of course it's crowdfunding but it was done actually with the Washington Monument where there was a lack of completion and the people all over the country said yes we want to have this finished and so they did what was now called crowdfunding and you can go to the Washington Monument you can see these are plaques that are dedicated to people that put the money in various groups and so on. Look, we know it won't fund the entire wall but people are anxious to support the President and secure our country and so we want to get crowdfunding going and this gives us an opportunity to be able to say send your money into a dedicated fund. We'll make sure the money goes to building the wall.

DOBBS: You know, I love the idea. I've only got one question. How long will it take?

BLACK: Well, of course, if we were only to crowdfund it would take probably quite some time but this is along with whatever we were able to get from Congress to put the money there. Look, we should have put the money there a long time ago.

DOBBS: Can I ask you this?

BLACK: Yes.

DOBBS: I'm going to ask you this. You're the chair of the Budget Committee, you got a Republican leadership in the House, Republican leadership in the Senate, they're both RINOs as we know. I won't ask you to comment on that. I know it might create some unease for you and I don't intend that, but it does create more than unease for the American people. It's a national security issue. The President has proposed it and what the House sent to this President with at 1.3 omnibus was no funding for the wall whatsoever, not a dime, not a dime for the wall, and there's still no money to build a wall. And that's -- I'm sorry.

BLACK: Oh no that's because we have to deal with the Democrats and unfortunately --

DOBBS: Wait a minute. So what's the point of having a Republican Party are electing new people at?

BLACK: Well, that's what I say. If the Senate doesn't change their filibuster rule, they will continue to do this until they get 60 Republicans.

DOBBS: Yes, but this was the House. This was the House, Congressman.

BLACK: But this has been something that we have talked about funding for a long time and we put that out there and we send it over to the Senate and the Senate is really our stopper in so many of these bills. It is so frustrating for me to do.

DOBBS: Can we -- can we agree then? Can we get rid of Mitch McConnell? Can you and I agree on that? I know it will work on Ryan --

BLACK: Now, that's up to the Senate to do, but I think we sent enough Republicans over there from the House of Representatives that were frustrated when they were in the House and then they end up not doing anything to push it in the Senate. We would have the last three to four years even when the Obama administration was there been able to get a lot more done had they just had a simple majority like the Constitution calls for, very frustrating.

DOBBS: Well, if we had more congressmen like Diane Black, I would agree. Thank you very much. We appreciate it.

BLACK: You're welcome. Thank you for having me.

DOBBS: Diane Black, good to see you. Tonight's quota the evening for the beleaguered and appropriately so Attorney General Jeff Sessions. It was Lao Tzu who said, "If you do not change direction, you may end up where you are heading." That's it for us tonight. Thanks for being with us. See you tomorrow night. Good night from New York.

LISA KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Roseanne Barr started the national dumpster fire with her racially charged tweet.
