urn:contentItem:5WP2-WGK1-DXH2-61TH-00000-00President Trump versus the Democrats; Mueller Testimony2019-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:40ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTMitch Roschelle, Lee Carter, Jack Hough, Robert Ray, Curtis Chin, Lou Basenese, Lance UlanoffNEWSFinancial072902cb.231President Trump versus the Democrats; Mueller TestimonyCharles Payne, Newt Gingrich, Lauren Simonetti, Susan Li

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning.

I'm Charles Payne, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, July 29th.

Your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern time.

Trade is in focus, face-to-face talks between the U.S. and China resume tomorrow in Shanghai. A look at what we can expect from these high stakes negotiations as we await a string of high profile earnings, a fed rate decision, and don't forget, the June jobs report. All this week.

Futures now showing the markets edging just a little bit lower right at the moment. This after the Nasdaq and S&P ended the week, last week at record highs, the Dow was up for the week, just shy of their all-time record.

Taking a look at global action, Europe markets are mixed there.

And Asia overnight markets are lower. South Korea hit especially hard by tech and auto. And ongoing riots in Hong Kong also hitting stocks.

The growing call for impeachment -- nearly half of House Democrats now calling for action, putting more pressure on Speaker Nancy Pelosi.

And Tesla looking to entertainment -- the automaker bringing movies into vehicles. Details ahead on that.

Plus, taking a bite out of "Baby Shark", the song inspiring a new cereal. You can't buy it everywhere. Find out where you can get it.

And here to break it all down with me: pollster and Maslansky & Partners president Lee Carter; PWC Partner Mitch Roschelle and Barron's associate editor Jack Hough.

Man -- the "Baby Shark" thing might be the biggest news of the week.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNER: That's quite a clip there.

(CROSSTALKING)

PAYNE: Yes. Yes, we'll see.

Also folks, coming up this morning: former Arkansas governor and former presidential candidate Mike Huckabee; chairman of Laffer Associates and former Reagan economic advisor, Art Laffer; former Whitewater independent counsel, former federal prosecutor and Thompson and Knight partner Robert Ray. And Milken Institute's Asia fellow Curtis Chin.

You do not want to miss this all-star line up.

Our top story though of the hour, President Trump versus the Democrats. Nearly half of the Democrat controlled House now back impeachment inquiry, at least, against the President. The numbers steadily climbing closer to a majority.

House Judiciary Committee chairman Jerry Nadler ramping up his push for impeachment.

Maria Bartiromo spoke with House Judiciary and Intelligence committee member John Ratcliffe yesterday. He said the case for impeachment is becoming a joke.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JERRY NADLER (D-NY): My personal view is that he richly deserves impeachment. He has done many impeachable offenses. He's violated the law six ways since Sunday but that's not the question.

The question is, can we develop enough evidence to put before the American people. We've engaged in investigations into these different alleged crimes and to whether the President violated his oath of office.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Do you think you've popped the impeachment bubble?

REP. JOHN RATCLIFFE (R-TX): I think everybody saw and a lot of Democrats have conceded that it's time to move on, that there's a hole in the impeachment balloon that's large enough for Jerry Nadler and Adam Schiff to walk through together.

Look, it's becoming a joke. I think people see that and Nadler and Schiff are starting to look more like "Laurel and Hardy". It's time to move on.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PAYNE: Joining me now, Fox News contributor, former speaker of the House and "Collusion" author, Newt Gingrich. Newt -- thanks for joining us.

NEWT GINGRICH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Glad to be with you.

PAYNE: You know, it felt like last week with the Mueller testimony that this would have been the end. That we would never, ever hear about this yet again.

And here we are, where more and more Democrats are still climbing on-board the impeachment train. What do you make of it?

GINGRICH: Well, look, I think that the Democrats don't have any policy ideas that they want to go to the country with so this is what they're left to talk about in the House.

But I watched Mueller last week and my first reaction was, and I wrote a piece on the newsletter about this Friday, I mean, who wrote the report? It was very clear that Mueller did not write the report. He didn't understand the report. At points, various congressmen were reading back to him his own report to correct what he was saying.

So, One -- we ought to find out and I hope Attorney General Barr will really push hard to find out who was really in charge since obviously Mueller wasn't.

But second, I reached the conclusion after all of this noise that there was an effort by a government to affect the election of 2016. Unfortunately, that government was the American government under Barack Obama and it was the FBI and the Justice Department and some other key people in the Obama administration who were trying to affect the election in a you way that clearly violates everything we've known about how to elect a president. PAYNE: Right.

GINGRICH: So, I came away from all this at least as worried about what the Americans had done illegally and inappropriately to change the election as I am about what the Russians may or may not have done.

PAYNE: So when you say who wrote the report, are you suggesting they're not those who did wrote the report were motivated -- politically motivated and hence, you know, taking us through this two and-a-half year, $30 million drama -- is that where you reach your conclusions that perhaps it was the Obama administration -- yes.

GINGRICH: Well, you know, When I first heard that Mueller was being appointed, I tweeted at the time and a lot of liberals have cheerfully retweeted since then that I thought that his record was terrific, he was an outstanding person, he had a clear tradition of being bipartisan.

But the man I watched last week, I began to realize that he really wasn't the Mueller of historic fame, that he had come into a job unprepared to do it. I'm assuming that the left wing Democrats, and that's all he hired -- I mean his lawyers were entirely anti-Trump. I assume they actually ran the project and the goal of the project was simple. Avoid dealing with the Clintons, avoid dealing with the real sources of corruption, avoid dealing with the people who started the whole Russian story. And focus only on the Trump side of the equation.

And I think if you were to look at it honestly, it's astonishing how many things the FBI and others were doing to interfere with and undermine the President and before that the Presidential candidate on a totally one-sided basis.

PAYNE: So how hopeful are you then that this will be, you know, revealed through efforts by Barr, the IG report we keep hearing about. Will we get more conclusive evidence of this?

GINGRICH: Well, I think from everything I've heard and I don't know much more than anybody else, but from what I've heard the inspector general is doing a professional, very thorough job. In in fact that comes out with the kind of information I think it will, then I think the chairman, Lindsey Graham, of the Senate Judiciary Committee will have an opportunity to establish an investigation.

Look, for example, why was it if you were for Clinton you could lie and nothing was done to you, if you were for Trump you could end up in solitary confinement for months.

I mean you go back and look at exactly the same kind of patterns, it is such an overwhelmingly anti-Trump protect Clinton process that I have to assume that it was the left wing lawyers, some of whom by the way had worked for Hillary Clinton, some had actually been at an election night party for her. It's not exactly like this was in any way a neutral effort.

PAYNE: I want to talk about the White House shakeup. Director of National Intelligence, Dan Coats will be leaving the job next month.

President Trump tweeting the announcement yesterday saying I'm pleased to announce that highly Dan Coats, the current director will respected Congressman John Ratcliffe of Texas will be nominated by me to be the director of national intelligence. A former U.S. Attorney John will lead and inspire greatness for the country he loved.

Dan current Coates, current director will be leaving office on August 15, I would like to thank Dan for his great service to our country. The acting director will be named shortly.

Newt -- your take on this change.

GINGRICH: Well, first of all I think John Ratcliffe did an amazing job dealing with the Mueller deal today and I thought he clearly on television again on Sunday on Sunday was remarkably effective. I think he serves on the intelligence committee, he's a smart guy. I think he'll probably do a do a very good job as director of national intelligence.

Dan Coats has a long career of serving the country and the congress, the first in the House, then the senate, then as ambassador to berlin and then finally back in the senate and then the last couple years. But I think if the President believes that Ratcliffe is going to be dramatically different from Dan Coats, he's in for a surprise.

The director of national intelligence has to report to the congress as well as the President and their number one job, frankly, is to tell the truth, not to prop up policy. Sometimes presidents -- every president sooner or later gets unhappy if the intelligence doesn't fit what their bias was and I think that Dan Coats said what he thought was true. I have a hunch that John Ratcliffe is going to follow exactly the same process.

PAYNE: Want to talk about the Democrats divided, House Nancy Pelosi downplaying tensions with freshman Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. This following their meaning last week.

Pelosi tweeted afterward today Congresswoman -- tweeted afterwards. "Today Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and I sat down to discuss working together to meet the needs of our districts and our country, fairness in our economy, diversity in our country. President Trumping just tweeting on the squad moments just a moment ago.

And if the Democrats are going to defend the radical left squad and King Elijah Baltimore failure, it will be a long road to 2020.

The good news for the Dems is that they have the fake news media in their pockets. Your thoughts?

GINGRICH: Well, I thought it was wonderful that Speaker Pelosi met with Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and that AOC and she are together. And I think everything we can do to get every Democrat to be with AOC is to the advantage of the Republicans.

You have a very radical group. Their views are way to the left of the American people. If the election next year is a choice of which direction we should go in, and the Democrats are represented as they were at the first set of debates -- remember, every single candidate raised their hand and said they were for giving tax paid free healthcare to illegal immigrants. That's a position that I think you have five or six positions like that, they could be in for a catastrophe, both in the Congress and the presidency.

PAYNE: Yes we'll see. Again, Nancy Pelosi going t have a hard time holding off impeachment, another thing that might be driven by the AOC wing of the party.

Newt Gingrich -- thank you very much. We appreciate all your thoughts.

GINGRICH: Good to be with you.

PAYNE: Tesla revs up the ride, what streaming extras the company is looking to put inside its cars, ahead.

Plus, "Baby Shark" biting into breakfast, the hit song inspiring a cereal brand. Where you can get it, next.

PAYNE: A deadly shooting rampage at a popular gathering in California.

Lauren Simonetti has the details -- Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Unbelievable -- Charles.

A gunman opened fire at the annual Gilroy Garlic Festival in California, killing three people, wounding at least 15 others before police fatally shot him. Police say the shooter cut through a fence that borders the parking lot to avoid tight security to get into the festival. A manhunt is now underway a after witnesses reported a second person may be involved here.

More trouble for Puerto Rico. The woman next in line to be governor says she doesn't want the job. The territory's governor, Ricardo Rossello and the secretary of state both resigned amid an inappropriate messaging scandal.

Successor -- Secretary of Justice Wanda Vasquez said in a statement quote, "I have no interest in occupying the seat of governor. She is hoping that Rossello will appoint a new secretary of state before he leaves office this Friday.

Well, entertainment options are coming to Tesla. CEO Elon Musk says drivers will soon be able to stream Netflix and youtube videos. Here's the catch.

Content will only be available when the car is parked. Musk does say a program could be watched on the go after fully autonomous driving is approved by regulators.

Let's take a look at shares of Tesla. They're moving up about half of 1 percent, 229 a pop right here in the premarket

And Discovery's "Shark Week" very popular, has officially kicked off and just in time. Kellogg's, the cereal company, has announced it's releasing "Baby Shark" cereal. You know what this is. The limited editions cereal based off the catchy kids' tune, will feature berry flavored loops and marshmallows, it will be available at SAM'S YCLUB on august 17th and Walmart in late September. We're not playing the music but you know how it goes. Daddy shark --

(CROSSTALKING)

SIMONETTI: You have to do --

Well, four months in, my baby in the bathtub she, dances to this song and it's the best thing ever.

PAYNE: Well, if I buy any boxes, I'm never going to open them. I'm going to hermetically seal them and put them in the tank, see if I can sell them 10 years from now.

SANDERS: Bingo.

PAYNE: That's all I'm doing. That's all I'm saying.

You know, I did that with Billy Beer in the '70s. They're still worth nothing.

PAYNE: That strategy backfired.

PAYNE: Maybe I'll eat some and then seal the rest. Thanks a lot.

Thanks -- Lauren.

A new news alert for you -- California Senator and 2020 hopeful, Kamala Harris unveiling her healthcare plan. She's looking to reshape the U.S. healthcare system by transforming it over 10 years to a federal system that would still allow for a limited role for private insurers. Private insurers would be a lot allowed to offer Medicare. Medicare vanished (ph) plans for instance. This coming ahead of the next Democratic debate.

Coming up here Robert Mueller' role -- new questions over whether the special counsel actually wrote his report.

Plus President Trump versus big tech, the possible investigation of Google over China and Apple's possible request for tariff exemptions.

PAYNE: Welcome back. Turning to the Mueller probe, report, on Sunday morning futures Maria Bartiromo spoke with House intel committee ranking member Devin Nunes about former special Robert Mueller's testimony.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Your reaction from the Mueller testimony.

REP. DEVIN NUNES (D-CA): Well, first of all it's clear that Mueller didn't write the report. And so wrote the report. We think there were five or six lawyers and who wrote the report? We think there were five or six lawyers involved. We're trying to get to the bottom of that.

I would say, you know, one of the main take-aways is that we still don't have any Russians, right? We don't know who the Russians were that supposedly colluded with the Trump campaign? Why? Because they were none.

And that's what we said two and a half years ago. There is evidence that the Democrats colluded with the Russians. We tried to get to the bottom of that. But clearly, Mueller and his team of lawyers and 40 investigators and $40 million didn't bother to look for those Russians. They were only looking for the Russians that were mysterious because they don't exist and they never found them.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PAYNE: Joining me now, former Whitewater Independent, former federal prosecutor. Thompson and Knight partner, Robert Ray.

Robert -- we had Newt Gingrich on earlier and he says his conclusion from all of this that it proves there was a massive cover up of sorts. And a deliberate effort by officials in the Obama administration to sway the election. What did you get from this testimony?

ROBERT RAY, FORMER FEDERAL PROSECUTOR:: He may be right. But that's what we have an investigation to determine. That's why the inspector general's report when we eventually see it I think now, I'm being told sometime in September. It's been promised for some time and apparently there was more investigation to do as a result of the fact that other people became available to be interviewed. And then of course, also the attorney general has commissions now two U.S. attorneys, separately to look into -- I think what we all sort of now understand to be the let's figure out what happened as a result of how this investigation came into being.

And so we're going to learn in the fall, we're going to start I think to hear some more and the narrative will shift I think away from impeachment to the-called investigation of the investigators.

PAYNE: Everyone was shocked by something -- during the hearing. I just was not what was advertised. And a lot of people came away from that with different --

RAY: I hope they weren't too shocked. Because you know, I think you know, Bob Mueller did exactly what he said he was going to do. The Department of Justice was clear that they were going to make sure that he did what he said he was going to do. Which was track the report and don't stray outside of that report.

PAYNE: But if someone came in there where the report was like a maybe he oversaw it but he didn't seem to have as much knowledge about the report as one would have assumed.

RAY: It's a big investigation. I don't think it's surprising, since I've written final reports, that I wasn't responsible for writing every single word that was in a collection of five final reports that were sent ultimately to the court and then on to be -- and release to the public and the American people.

But it is also true that I read everything and stood behind every single word on that report. I did write some of it. Not all of it.

The only criticism I ever had of Bob Mueller was the fact essentially just one sentence. I don't think he should have gotten into this whole question about whether what the investigation represented.

It was either an exoneration or not an exoneration. That's not what prosecutors do. And that's out of 448 pages, again, on the assumption as he said and testified that the words were very carefully chosen.

In my own view that was a poor exercise of judgment. That sentence should not have been there.

CORKE: I'm really fascinated by that. Because I think everybody watched this whole thing, or not everybody watched the whole thing but all everybody took away from it was one sentence and that exoneration sentence, that statement that he made is what the Democrats are now hanging everything on.

They're saying, look, he just gave room for the fact that there was criminal behavior and then when he gets out of office we can go after him.

HOUGH: I agree with you. I don't think that one sentence is a bomb shell. I don't think it's appropriately in the report. If that's what you're hanging your hat on in order to justify prolonging the agony, and this sort of notion about well, we're not really conducting an impeachment proceeding but we have to say that we're at least having an inquiry to look to see whether we're going to have an impeachment proceeding so that we can get an additional --

(CROSSTALKING)

HOUGH: -- particularly on McGahn and all the rest of that.

PAYNE: -- particularly Ratcliffe hit him hard on that whole thing in the first place.

But I do want to shift a little bit because Maria also sat down with former Trump campaign aide, George Papadopoulos. He told her that he plans to head back to Greece to retrieve a !10,000 old payment that he said was used to entrap him by the FBI and the CIA.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: You were given money in Israel, $10,000 in cash. You don't keep the money. You send it and you give it to your lawyers. And then you get on a flight to go home to go back to Dulles wherever you were going to Dulles.

When you land, there are FBI agents arresting you, asking you, do you have any money.

GEORGE PAPADOPOULOS, FORMER TRUMP AIDE: Basically, that's exactly what happened. And what I think this whole setup was all about was trying to frame a FARA violation against me that I was under some sort of illicit surveillance, for actually I think years.

Of course, this $10,000 which I believe was a setup by the FBI, likely, or even the special counsel's office, it was designed to make it look like I was actually some sort of foreign agent which I never had been and I never will be.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PAYNE: Robert, your thoughts?

RAY: He has commented publicly in another -- on another occasion about I think the words were ridiculous prosecutorial overreach. And he may well have a substantial claim in that regard in my view, once we find out and get to the bottom of all this.

I will say for people who don't do this every day, you would be surprised what you see in the name of criminal investigations and the sorts of things that go on.

As the supreme court also once said, prosecutors are around to strike hard blows but not foul ones. And I think here what I think he is providing a window on is that there may well have been foul blows here, which is not acceptable.

PAYNE: Robert Ray -- thank you very much. Appreciate it.

RAY: Thanks, Charles.

PAYNE: Coming up, U.S.-China trade talks are in focus, talks ready to resume. Why investors expectations aren't the brightest.

Plus, millennials and paying the bills. New data showing that they rely heavily on mom and dad. Just how much -- ahead on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

PAYNE: Welcome back. I'm Charles Payne in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, July 29th. Your top stories at 07:30 a.m. Eastern.

Trade is in focus, face to face trade talks between the United States and China resuming tomorrow in Shanghai. And look at what we can expect from the highest stakes negotiations.

We're also waiting for a string of high profiled earnings, the Fed decision this week and the jobs report on Monday.

Right now, Futures showing the markets slightly higher, this after the NASDAQ and S&P ended last week at record highs, the Dow also up for the week, just slightly shy of their all-time record.

And taking a look at global action in Europe, markets are now turned up. They were initially mixed but as you can see, all three major European indices higher.

However in Asia overnight, the markets were down there in South Korea especially hit hard by tech and auto. Escalating violence in Hong Kong also hitting the markets, riot the police firing tear gas and rubber bullets into the crowd. China responding to the turmoil this morning.

Hi, Siri, who's listening to me? The shocking findings from a new report, straight ahead.

Plus, supporting older kids, the number of millennials getting money from their parents every month is higher than you think. Those details are straight ahead.

And our top story this half hour, U.S.-China trade negotiations for the two countries set to meet face-to-face in Shanghai tomorrow, looking to make a deal. President Trump downplaying chances of an agreement saying on Friday, maybe they will, maybe they won't.

Joining me now, Milken Institute Asia Fellow, Curtis Chin. Curtis, it's kind of ref -- it's kind of actually good, I think at least from Wall Street's perspective, that expectations have been ratcheted down. But what can come out of these meetings, out of this next meeting?

CURTIS CHIN, ASIA FELLOW, MILKEN INSTITUTE: You know, really, both sides I think understandably and appropriately are really downplaying expectations. You know, long-standing issues between the United States and China, forced technology transfers, mistreatment of U.S. companies, these issues cannot be resolved overnight. And I think the markets, you know, just are pleased right now that talks are resuming at this high level.

So, you know, Secretary Mnuchin, Lighthizer in Shanghai, as you noted, these next two days, that in itself is an important step forward. But clearly, don't expect any big breakthroughs this week out of Shanghai.

HOUGH: Hi, Kurt, it's Jack Hough from Barrons. It's getting to the point where we can start to envision election sees and approaching the election coming and not having a deal in place, yet the market doesn't seem to mind. Is that because you think that average Americans kind of get it with the -- with the trade deal and China and would rather have, you know, let's say a good deal rather than any deal at this point? What do you think?

CHIN: Yes, I think that President Trump to his great credit has been very consistent. What we're seeking is fair, balanced reciprocal trade. You know, it's not going to happen overnight. But very clear, with an election year and Xi Jinping's own challenges in China and I'm calling it a perfect storm now hitting Xi Jinping from the Hong Kong protests, to pushback with regards to what they're doing to Muslims in Xinjiang, calling out what Huawei is up to. You know, all of these issues are impacting Xi Jinping and China. And to in this context, both the United States and China have domestic concerns that they also have to address in trying to move this forward.

At the end of the day, though, a deal will be to the benefit of both China and the United States and I think that's what we all need to focus on.

CARTER: So Curtis, I've heard it said that the Chinese government does not trust Donald Trump in particular and it's not likely that they're going to be making a deal because of that. Do you think it's that they don't trust Trump in particular so they don't trust our interests and then we can't make them aligned?

CHIN: You know, I can't speak to that. You know, I'm thinking about trust, I'm not so sure businesses trust what China has said through the years.

CARTER: Right.

CHIN: You know, and this goes back to in the Unite -- I began (INAUDIBLE) since when I began under Ronald Reagan where you know, he famously said trust, but verify.

And so clearly, what we need are some incremental steps forward. But I think when we look at the United States, you know, it has also has to get its act in order. And there's some things that Washington can do today.

I mean, one specific thing that I'm hearing more about -- I'm in Washington right now, is really the need to reauthorize an institution called the U.S. Export-Import Bank. And we really need to create that balanced playing field and if China is aggressively promoting its exporters, we the United States need to do something very similar.

We need to move this forward because in my heart, you know, I was at Commerce, I was at Treasury, in my heart I know that American businesses on a very balanced playing field will succeed.

PAYNE: You know --

CHIN: Right now I'm with the Milken Institute out of Singapore and what I'm hearing in South East Asia, and Asia is like, keep fighting Donald Trump. Because the concerns that the United States has about China's behavior are shared by Asian companies and countries throughout the region.

PAYNE: What -- OK, so we all have expectations a little bit, we want something, right, as they move the ball forward? I mean, should we anticipate a large order for soybeans? Should we expect something? Because it feels like really going into this meeting, Curtis, that President Trump has extended more olive branches if you will than the -- than the Chinese counterparts.

CHIN: Well, clearly we may well get large purchases of soybeans. I saw that some Chinese companies were already seeking exemptions from their own Chinese system about what they could actually sell right now to the United States. The Chinese government has said it's up to the businesses themselves.

But my fear is that we be, you know, looking back at what's happened in the past. My fear is that the U.S. Government might say that's enough, because clearly that is enough. That is not enough, you know, to paraphrase Margaret Thatcher from way back when. This is not a time for the United States to go wobbly in its negotiations in this case with China. The United States really in some ways I think is at an advantage here because of its strong economy. I mean, it's about --

PAYNE: And it's more to your point, this morning Hong Kong -- I mean, China rather, had even more weak economic data. By the way, Lighthizer isn't going to go wobbly. But right now on the -- on the screen we're showing the audience, Curtis, a Hong Kong protests. Police and demonstrators back on the streets this weekend, confrontations heating up on back to back days. You know, you mentioned this before. It really feels like the people in Hong Kong are rising up but here in America we're not quite sure what they're trying to achieve, since ultimately China will be in charge of Hong Kong as well.

CHIN: You know, I'm with you there. I mean, I think all Americans are for anyone really fighting for democracy, fighting for really a life that they can decide, you know, what they want to do.

Clearly I'm about to get on a plane to Hong Kong. You know, clearly this last eight weeks of protests have brought to the world what's happening there, which is unfortunately I feel more fast move towards this Hong Kong being absorbed by China.

You know, right now it lives under what's called a one country, two systems way of life. But increasingly there's an encroachment on that Hong Kong way of life.

You know, these protests began when the Hong Kong government sought to introduce an extradition law that would allow Hong Kong people to be -- all people really in Hong Kong to be extradited to China. And I think the world knows what rule of law of China looks like today, versus in a democracy of Canada and the United States.

PAYNE: Right.

CHIN: And so, people are really fighting for their way of life. And when you look at those really striking visuals, tear gas, rubber bullets, you'll see of course people from all walks of life but you'll see a lot of young people. And one could really have tremendous empathy, tremendous sympathy for the Hong Kong young people fighting for, you know, their way of life.

I think we need to stand with the people of Hong Kong. Clearly, like Secretary Pompeo who is really soon also leaving for Asia, we want a peaceful resolution for this but clearly I think we -- most people here would identify with the Hong Kong protester.

PAYNE: There's no doubt that when they arranged those initially agreement upon, many people thought maybe Hong Kong would ultimately influence China but the hard line is there pushing back.

Curtis Chin, thank you very much, always appreciate it.

Coming up, President Trump versus big tech, more on the possible investigation into Google over China and Apple's request for tariff exemptions.

Plus, millennials and money, new data showing they really rely on mom and dad consistently to pay the bills.

PAYNE: Nearly half of millennials getting money from their parents and we're talking every month. Susan Li has the details.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Here we go.

PAYNE: Susan.

LI: So, millennials, what, we're snowflakey, we don't -- over lazy, we don't have ambition apparently. But, you know, it looks like the survey says for Money Under 30 says that over 46 percent of millennials still get help from their parents each and every month. In fact, parents are the first place that they turn to, 48 percent first look to their parents when they're short on cash. 13-1/2 get a bank loan. 4.9 percent go to their friends and 3.7 percent go to their grandparents. And it's not a lot of money that they need help on.

I mean, if you take a look at the bills that they ask their parents for help on, the number one thing is cell phone. Their mobile phone bills. 17.6 percent. Groceries come up next, close to 10 percent, rent, which I found surprising because I thought that would be on the top of the list since they cost so much money to live in these big cities. Rent was only third at 6.5 percent. Insurance and then gas round it all out.

So it's not a lot of money that they ask for but when they do ask for money on a monthly basis it's just for the things that they need to pay to I guess subsist each and every month, right?

But let's think about it. Being a millennial now is different from 30 years ago. I know people always want to make that comparison. Because when you're saddled with $1.5 trillion in student debt which by the way has gone up from $600 billion 10 years ago and those that owe $100,000 quadrupled in just in the past year alone, it's a different time. And rich are going up faster than wages are. So yes, they do need a little bit of help every month.

PAYNE: Susan, I'm breaking out the world's smallest violin right now.

LI: Oh, would you stop?

CARTER: I'm just curios though, I mean --

PAYNE: I'm going to play this Stratovarius that the micro (INAUDIBLE)

LI: wait, do you help out your kids?

PAYNE: Hell yes.

LI: Each and every month if they ask for help and say daddy.

PAYNE: Well, my son is in college but he lives in Notting Hill. He went to a college (INAUDIBLE) in Miami.

LI: Oh, so cheap rent.

PAYNE: Yes, I mean, he's living a pretty good life. But I help everyone in my family out but, you know, they should have had Coachella on that list. They should have some (INAUDIBLE)

And by the way, why does a struggling person need gas money?

LI: Well, I think it's just easy.

ROSCHELLE: Why isn't Uber on that list?

LI: What? Uber?

ROSCHELLE: You know, because that seems to be the most ubiquitous thing that shows up my credit card bills that I pay on behalf of my kids.

LI: On behalf of your kids? Well, I think (INAUDIBLE) City is --

PAYNE: I'm glad you said that. My son had a $4,000 Uber bill in high school and I only found out when someone I got a tipped -- I got a tip.

LI: $5,000 Uber bill? Where did he go?

PAYNE: No, over 4,000 during high school. I never knew that he would use and someone tipped me off, my stepson tipped me off. And he said listen, I looked through the -- it added up to $4,000.

LI: That's a lot.

CARTER: Wow.

PAYNE: That is a lot.

LI: And how did you react to that?

PAYNE: I don't know.

LI: You said, OK, well, if you need it --

PAYNE: If it was 30 years ago, it would have been different.

LI: What about the parents that enable their kids? You don't you think that the parent want to take car and say OK, well, you need some money for your mobile phone bill, sure, honey.

PAYNE: Yes, we do.

CARTER: Well, is it that they're giving them money for them a little mobile phone or they just keep them on a family plan?

ROSCHELLE: I think they're on the plan -- I think they're on the plan forever, for life.

LI: That millennials except parents' help forever?

ROSCHELLE: On the phone.

LI: On the phone.

CARTER: Family plan.

LI: Wait a second --

PAYNE: Great news for Apple, paid. (INAUDIBLE)

CARTER: You're right.

PAYNE: Susan, thank you very much. Appreciate it.

Coming up, folks, big tech in focus. The Trump administration puts the scope on Google for its ties to China and Apple over a tariff exemption. So we're going to discuss that. Stay with us.

PAYNE: Welcome back. If you own an iPhone, it might be time to stop relying on Siri and turn the listening assistant off. Siri can be activated by something as simple as the sound of a zipper, that's what report say, leaving any conversation open to surveillance and user data like location and content.

Joining me now Disruptive Tech Research founder and chief analyst, Lou Basenese and Lifewire.com editor-in-chief Lance Ulanoff.

Lance, let me start with you. I mean, we keep hearing these horror stories about all of these devices in our world. Is there any -- do we have to learn to live with this?

LANCE ULANOFF, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, LIFEWIRE.COM: Well, we should learn -- you know, how they actually work. So they are always listening for what's called the watch word, they're listening for the word Siri, they're listening for Alexa, or they're listening for OK Google. And so, that means they're actually listening all the time. They have to listen for that word, otherwise they don't work.

Everything after that word is considered a command, send it up to Cloud, try and figure it out, send it back. If it's nonsense, because it heard something that it thought was the watch word and wasn't the watch word.

PAYNE: But this means they're vetting all words though even if it's not activated, they're taking everything we say, they're vetting it and sending it somewhere --

ULANOFF: First of all, I wouldn't use the word they because it's not -- it's not people. It's the program literally that is trying to match up what you said with what a command that it understands, so it can do something, it's parsing it, just trying to figure it out.

No, there's nobody sitting there like trying to figure that out. That said, Amazon, Apple, all of them will take samples of anonymous data and samples of audio to try and improve the listening and text to speech or words to speech understanding technology to improve it overtime. If they don't do that, Siri won't understand you as well, you know, in the future, you know, later on, it won't improve.

ROSCHELLE: But we've all had the experience when we talk about it on the show of having a conversation about a specific product and then having it show up in Google search.

CARTER: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: Having it show up in your Amazon, you know, what to buy, when you didn't Google that product.

ULANOFF: I'm going to -- I will tell you the same thing I've told many, many people. It's not -- your phones aren't listening to when you think they're not. It is -- there are so many different ways that can triangulate what you're thinking about, even through relationships you have.

PAYNE: Right.

ULANOFF: Yes, we are a web of connections on social media and through search and through all kinds of data. So that's how it happens. It's not that they're listening.

CARTER: OK.

ULANOFF: And by the way, Apple has no interest in hearing what you're doing in your private time.

PAYNE: Let's bring in Lou -- let's bring in Lou because we do have another guest.

LOU BASENESE, RESEARCH FOUNDER AND CHIEF ANALYST, DISRUPTIVE TECH: I'm not buying it. Look, I'm not buying that, Lance. I think -- I think you make perfectly valid points. But there's a lot of accidents happening on purpose here. We are giving them unfettered access to our data. And look, they can't resist the temptation.

Data is a drug to big tech. It allows Google and Facebook to serve you better ads. To think that they're not going to use this data that it's just going into the Cloud and being crunched by algorithms and not being put into their business I think is just a little bit naive. We are giving them that permission in today's day and age. I'm not saying that big tech is all bad for doing it. But we can't be naive to think that it's not happening.

ULANOFF: Well, I actually -- I know that all of these companies are using the data. That's what they do. That's how they sell -- and that's how they sell ads. Although, Apple doesn't -- Apple doesn't sell ads so they don't -- they don't have to do that. And also, nobody forced us to buy these devices and use them.

PAYNE: All right, let me ask you guys about President Trump, because on Friday he suggested the administration will investigate Google for its alleged work with China and the national security threat there that it could -- that it poses for our country. Some say his statements contradict Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin who said Google had alter -- alleviated concerns of its work in China and said it was minimal. So where are we on this, Jack?

HOUGH: I tell you, every one of these big tech companies -- first of all, every one of them has problems with regulators. Every one of them has some reason to be despised by some part of the public right now. They also lead the American stock market. So when I see, you know, the White House saying look at how great our stock market is doing here in the U.S. but also we need to crack down on these big tech companies, we push that too far, it's going to turn our stock performance around.

What's really surprising to me here is the Microsoft. Suddenly it's the biggest company in the U.S. again. It's the only one I hear left out of this conversation.

CARTER: Right?

HOUGH: But when did Microsoft become the good guys? I mean, they are.

ULANOFF: They don't have the same technology. I mean, they don't -- who do uses Cortana really. So they're not doing the things whether collecting data, they're not selling ads in general.

PAYNE: And also, let's face it, we have the co-founder of Facebook saying that they're bad actors. It's not just the governments, right? There's governments around the world, even these big tech names seem to be -- and maybe Lou, it's a marketing ploy. Maybe they're pushing for more regulations to become a (INAUDIBLE) in the hands of their strength and makes competition harder.

But still, this seems to be a general acknowledgement Lou, that something is wrong, that something needs to be fixed or adjusted.

BASENESE: Look, big tech has gotten too big? Does that mean we break them up? I think that's an idiotic plan. Because how do you break up a social network and keep it from reforming itself? I just don't think that's possible. I mean, how do you break up Amazon which is underpinned by its Cloud computing in every business segment.

But look, they've -- they're actions have warned to this intervention from Facebook just laundry list of privacy violations to Google choosing to work on -- you know, historically it's been rumored they're working on a censored version in China, the search engine. You know, they're inviting the scrutiny and it's no surprise that we're seeing these --

PAYNE: And it doesn't help that they, you know, sort of kicked our Department of Defense to the curb over, you know -- you know --

BASENESE: Right.

PAYNE: And then --

ULANOFF: (INAUDIBLE) working on Dragonfly. They now -- they stopped that as of this year. So now that they're pulled out --

(CROSSTALK)

HOUGH: But they did work with them before?

BASENESE: So that's my point, is they were working with the Chinese government so they invited (INAUDIBLE)

PAYNE: Lou, Lance, thank you both very much.

I want to get to the Trump tweet now. President Trump just tweeting on the E.U. and China. The E.U. and China will further lower interest rates and put money into their systems, making it much easier for their manufacturers to sell product. In the meantime, and with very low inflation, our Fed does nothing and probably will do very little by comparison. Too bad.

Mitch, what do you make of it?

ROSCHELLE: I think that there's -- and Jack made this point earlier, there's all of this negative yielding debt around the world. There's slowing economies around the world. And we'd like to say, we're an island but we're not -- our economies are coupled with the rest of the world. So central bankers have to most likely behave similarly if they want to stimulate global growth.

HOUGH: Did someone help the President Trump with that tweet because he's got it --

PAYNE: He's good.

PAYNE: He got it exactly right -- exactly right. Yes, we have to respond to the strong dollar because of all these negative issue --

PAYNE: But he's also suggesting 25 basis points is not going to be enough.

HOUGH: Well, it maybe won't be enough. But let me tell you, you need to leave some dry powder. This is an aging expansion.

PAYNE: Right.

HOUGH: Eventually we'll get a recession. You don't want to sitting at zero when the next recession hits.

PAYNE: William suggested though that (INAUDIBLE) that forget about the rates, they'll have these unconventional tools.

In the meantime, still ahead, Medicare for All, Senator Kamala Harris releases her healthcare plan just ahead of the second Democratic debate. We're going to take a look in the next hour on just how this moves a needle. More on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

PAYNE: Good morning, I'm Charles Payne.
