urn:contentItem:60G8-74T1-DXH2-63M1-00000-00President Trump Wrapping Up His Speech In All-Important State Of Texas; CEOs Of Apple, Google, Facebook, And Amazon Still On Hot Seat At Capitol, Getting Drilled During An Antitrust Hearing As It Pertains To Social Media In Favor Of Liberals Instead Of Conservatives; Massive Teachers Union Says Its Members Will Refuse To Go Back To Work Until Its Demands Are Met; The Battle To Reopen America's Schools; Summer Shark Panic: Woman Killed In Maine Attack, NY Beaches Closed; Better Late Than Never: Adults Use Pandemic As Excuse To Learn To Ride A Bike2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:40ZLexisNexisTHE FIVE5:00 PM ESTNEWSDomestic072901cb.258President Trump Wrapping Up His Speech In All-Important State Of Texas; CEOs Of Apple, Google, Facebook, And Amazon Still On Hot Seat At Capitol, Getting Drilled During An Antitrust Hearing As It Pertains To Social Media In Favor Of Liberals Instead Of Conservatives; Massive Teachers Union Says Its Members Will Refuse To Go Back To Work Until Its Demands Are Met; The Battle To Reopen America's Schools; Summer Shark Panic: Woman Killed In Maine Attack, NY Beaches Closed; Better Late Than Never: Adults Use Pandemic As Excuse To Learn To Ride A BikeDana Perino, Jesse Watters, Juan Williams, Greg Gutfeld, Katie Pavlich

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: How about we cut it by $200 and make it $400, and revisit every 30 days? Bottom line, Republicans don't want to give up that fight, because they realize it could boomerang on them. Here comes "THE FIVE."

JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Watters, along with Dana Perino, Greg Gutfeld, Juan Williams, and Katie Pavlich. It is 5:00 in New York City, and this is THE FIVE. President Trump wrapping up his speech in the all-important state of Texas, Trump talking about energy independence and going after Joe Biden for embracing far-left policies, take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I don't think Biden's going to do too well in Texas. He's already written it off. He's gone no fracking. That's part of his platform. If these far-left politicians ever get into power, they will demolish not only your industry, but the entire U.S. economy.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: And Joe Biden continuing to bash Trump over the pandemic and claims he's unqualified to be president.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Donald Trump faces a real test, and he has failed it, the basic threshold of being president, the duty to care for the entire country, not just his re-election prospects. He has shown that he can't beat the pandemic and keep you safe. He can't turn the economy around and get America back to work.

And he has horrifyingly and not surprisingly and intentionally stoking the flames of division and racism country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATTERS: OK. Dana Perino, it seems like Trump is trying to put Joe in this left-wing box, where he says he's beholden to the far-left, because, you know, Joe Biden is pretty far-left if you look at his policies on trade, immigration, healthcare, and taxes. And if Joe says no, no, no, I'm not a left-wing guy, then that turns off the Bernie bros, which he needs.

But if embraces the far-left label, it just turns off the people he needs in the battlegrounds.

DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST: Yeah, he's in a pickle. But it was just yesterday that Joe Biden said in response to a reporter's question that he would be the most progressive president in U.S. history, which felt a little confusing because he won the primary based on the fact that he wasn't the most progressive person in the Democratic Party that was running for president.

But yet, he still feels the need to continue to win over that part of the party. On energy issues, you know, today, the president of the American Petroleum Institute was quoted, saying that they were glad that the Biden policy book is -- basically didn't say that they would get rid of fracking, that they felt like it was pretty much OK.

So I do think that President Trump going to Texas today shows us a couple of things. One, Ted Cruz last week warned the Republicans and the White House that Texas is in real danger. And there were numbers today that backed that up, so I think going to Texas is good. It doesn't mean Biden's going to win Texas. But one of the things he pointed out is that in 2018, during the midterms, the turnout for Democrats in Texas was way up.

So think about a presidential election year. That will also be the case. So shoring up Texas makes a lot of sense. But I also think that you've seen a switch from the Trump campaign painting Biden as senile to then focusing on him as a leftist, a progressive, somebody who will be a tool for the far- left. And that must be where they think they can have more fertile ground in order to plant some seeds going into this last 96 days.

WATTERS: And it does look like it's moving some numbers in the battleground states. All right, Greg Gutfeld, I mean, every candidate whenever they run for president, the other guy's going to destroy the country, going to divide the country, all hell's going to break loose. And, you know, you just expect whoever is the better salesman wins.

GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST: Yeah. It's funny, though. You know, I don't think Donald Trump has to put Joe Biden in a left-wing box, because I think he's doing it right in front of everybody. It's not a coffin, but it's a box that he jumps into and it makes no sense at all, because he is chasing people who are going to hate him more than they hate Trump.

I mean, do you think that everybody on the streets, those are all leftists by the way, the people that are burning the buildings and looting and tormenting our police. Those are all leftists. Do you think that suddenly they are just going to stop because Joe might -- Joe wins, if he wins? Of course not, of course not.

They are going to look at him as part of the same problem because they are anarchists. So he's not going to actually have any effect on making the world a less divisive place. And let's not forget. He was the first guy to start using divisive language when he called Donald Trump the most racist president ever and pushing the fine people hoax over and over again. He has been following the divisive playbook since day one.

WATTERS: And he learned it from his mentor, Barack Obama. Katie, how do you see things shaping up? It looks like it's shaping up to be a traditional presidential election, where both sides throw mud, raise a hell of a lot of money, and the debates pretty much catapult the winner into the Oval?

KATIE PAVLICH, FOX NEWS HOST: Well, I do think it's really interesting that the president is in Texas heeding the warnings and, you know, not taking any vote for granted and also reminding Republicans in Texas that they have to get out to vote if they want to keep their state red, if Democrats have -- had Texas on the map for a long time as a golden ticket to winning presidential elections for the near future.

So they have always had that target that they wanted to reach in those goals to turn Texas blue. It's something that activists there have been working on for a very long time. And they're getting close. Ted Cruz didn't win -- very much against Beto O'Rourke. You have to remember that. But in terms of these other swing states, you know.

There is that Zogby poll out today showing that President Trump beats Biden 3-1 when it comes to voters who switched from Obama to Trump in 2016. So that's good news for the Trump campaign, because that means that they are holding onto those voters that really push them over the top in a lot of those places. And in places like Pennsylvania and Michigan, I think it's going to be a very tough sell for Joe Biden to be able to kind of, you know, capitulate to his far-left base on environmental policies.

While also trying to somehow make the argument that he's going to keep manufacturing jobs, bring them back from overseas, and somehow allow oil and gas and fracking to move forward. I mean, they say that in their outline. But when it comes to actually implementing that kind of policy, I think the left might win on that when it comes to pushing that in terms of legislation if he were to become president.

WATTERS: All right. Juan, I want you to react to all that, but also tell us about the buzz going on with Kamala Harris as the VP pick. What are you hearing?

JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS HOST: Well, you know, everybody was talking, Jesse, about Vice President Biden's notes. Remember that photographer got a picture of Biden's notes, and it said that he doesn't hold grudges and all this about Kamala Harris. You can see it there on the screen. But the buzz is not about Kamala Harris. I mean, in fact, the energy all seems to be about either Susan Rice or Karen Bass, the congresswoman from California.

So -- but I don't -- I mean, I don't know what to make of it, because you get all kinds of various signals. Somebody said to me the other day we haven't heard much from Kamala Harris. That's the way it goes before (ph) people show up standing next to the nominee. I don't know. I will say this about the race and reacting. You said react -- all I've heard.

You know, I think the president is obviously running against Joe Biden. And I don't think he can make Joe Biden into the far-left. Nobody's buying that. Even the far-left doesn't think Joe Biden is far-left, OK? But I find it interesting that Trump is preoccupied with Dr. Fauci. Yesterday at White House, he's saying that, you know, he doesn't understand why Dr. Fauci, 80- year-old doctor, researcher is more popular than he is.

And he says it must that it's his personality. Well, what about -- and this applies to Texas and everything else. What about the Coronavirus? I think Biden is plus 17 in the Fox poll on how he would handle the Coronavirus and protect us, the American people from this scourge. And I think that's when you start to see problems in Texas. That's where you have the real clear politics.

The average has, I think, Biden up 8.4. That's where you start to see a big peeling away of people who say, you know what? I think it's time to move on. So for me, I think the virus has become the number one political issue, and that's where President Trump is coming up short.

WATTERS: OK. We'll see about that, won't we, Juan? I think Dukakis was up 17 points at the same point before the election. And I think we all remember what happened to him. Coming up, tech titans under fire on the Hill, facing tough questions about social media censorship. You will want to hear their answers next.

PERINO: You are looking live at Capitol Hill, where the biggest names in tech are still on the hot seat. They've been there all afternoon. The CEOs of Apple, Google, Facebook, and Amazon getting drilled during an antitrust hearing that earlier Republicans went after the executives over allegations over conservatives being censored on social media.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'll just cut to the chase. Big tech is out to get conservatives. That's not a suspicion. That's not a hunch. That's a fact. If I had a nickel for every time I heard it was just a glitch, I wouldn't be as wealthy as our witnesses, but I would be doing all right.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Conservatives are consumers, too. And the way the net was put together, in the eyes of Congress, is that everybody should be able to speak their mind.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: And can you today assure Americans you will not tailor your features in any way to help -- specifically help one candidate over the other -- what I'm concerned about is you're helping Joe Biden over President Trump.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We won't do any work to, you know, to politically tilt anything one way or the other. It's against our core values.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PERINO: All right. The CEOs denied any bias. So another day, another hearing, let me go to you, Jesse. I don't know if you got a chance to see much of that today. But, you know, anytime we have hearings on Capitol Hill about tech, you just kind of want to cringe through the questions that are being asked. Because many times, you realize that the members -- they have an idea of what they are talking about, but they are not well-versed in the technology.

WATTERS: They don't know the difference between Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, nothing. They are worse than I am. I do have to give credit where credit is due, Dana, because the Democrats have done something very smart, and it really pains me to say that. They've launched this campaign in Silicon Valley for these tech giants to root out hate speech and misinformation.

But the Democrats in D.C. agree with the Democrats in Silicon Valley that hate speech and misinformation only comes from conservatives. Because so -- when -- hate speech is basically anything that offends a Democrat. And misinformation is anything a Democrat disagrees with. So these PC police types and the fact-checkers and the mainstream media get on these platforms, and they build these speech walls against conservative speech.

And these walls keep closing in. Yet, the Democrats, they can talk about misinformation all day long, like, the Russia hoax and they can pay no price. They can slander conservatives all day long. Call them white supremacists, rapists. They can plan riots on social media. They don't pay a price. So it's unfair. And the Democrats say you better do this, since you're conservatives to these tech giants or we will break up your monopolies.

The Republicans say you better stop censoring us and aligning yourselves with the Chinese, or we'll break up your monopolies. And what do the big guys do? They just shower them with money. They pay everybody off. And they have all their lobbyists take everybody on (Inaudible) and to fancy dinners. Because all they know is that once a year they come up.

Bend over, get spanked, and then they walk back to their desk their desks, and make a billion dollars a day and nothing changes.

PERINO: All right, so one of those people that are under the gun from Democrats is Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook. And Juan, take a listen to what he said very consistent with what he told us month or so ago when we did an interview with him about this issue of the Democrats wanting Facebook to take down all sorts of things, including basically Trump's Twitter feed or Facebook feed. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Our goal is to offer a platform for all ideas. Be able distinguish their selves as one of the companies that defends free expression the most. We do not want to become the arbiters of truth. That would be a bad position for us to be in, and not what we should be doing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PERINO: Why can't the Democrats seem to think that that's OK, Juan, to say that you want to be neutral on a platform?

WILLIAMS: I think it's all right with everybody. I think the real issue going back to what Jesse was saying has to do with, you know, propaganda, lies, hate speech, that kind of thing. But, you know, I think today, just to pick up again on what Jesse was saying. I saw Sensenbrenner asking Zuckerberg about Twitter like he thought Zuckerberg ran Twitter.

He doesn't even know the difference, apparently. So I get the idea that really watching this, it looked like Republicans, you know, how do you guys said the Democrats weren't allowing Barr to speak yesterday. So today, its Republicans not allowing any of these tech executives to speak, and basically working the rev (ph) saying we don't like it when you limit, you know, Don Jr., when he's putting stuff out there.

We don't like it at all. So OK, I mean, I guess that's their message. But to me, this was supposed to be an antitrust hearing. And, you know, to the point of who's got more political leverage, I think right now, President Trump and his administration had done nothing in terms promoting competition on the high-tech sector. There is more of a threat to those --

(CROSSTALK)

WILLIAMS: -- from the prospect -- I'll just finish up. It's more of a threat, I think, from Joe Biden and Democratic Congress in terms of actually putting in place legislation and passing it that would rein in these monopolies and allow real competition to allow the little guy to get in the game. So if that's the issue, than I think the political leverage is more on the right.

PERINO: But, Greg, thinking about this, you know, free market system, and here you have these four tech CEOs, American companies, employing lots of Americans. And also, you are having a global presence. And you have these guys saying that big government should be -- would be better at running -- making decisions for these companies than the free market.

GUTFELD: Yeah. It's -- when you look at these hearings in general, it's why I didn't even watch these hearings today because I was hearing doubt. It took all of my self-control not to drive to D.C. and TP the Capitol. Whenever you take any issue, whether it's justice or it's the internet, hearings are an intellect removal machine.

It's like -- it replaces brains without range (ph) theater. And I don't think -- you never get to the bottom of anything. You just go back to the top. We're participating in an experiment with social media. It affects all of our lives. It's only going to get bigger and ubiquitous and more powerful. So the question for a conservative is -- conservatives are do you want it to become the fourth horseman of the left, you know -- the left won when it comes to culture.

They have the entertainment industry. They have media. They have academia. So we have this fourth thing. It's social media. It's the social media platform. Do you want to just hand it over without a fight? Because once you hand it over, it never comes back. And we know that with academia. There's never -- academia is purely left. And you know the media will never be conservative.

None of these things will change. And by the way, to Jesse's point, I want to back it up. It's not about hate speech. It's about the accusation of hate speech, which is used to silence you and damage your career. And this is happening everywhere, not just social media.

PERINO: Yeah. Katie, one thing I thought that -- you know, you didn't hear too much about it today. But the Trump administration has gone to bat for these American companies, especially overseas, when you have governments like in the E.U., for example that want to heavily tax or regulate or change these companies. They have gone to bat for them. You know, would a Biden administration do the same?

PAVLICH: I think it depends. You know, there's not a lot in Washington, D.C. that both sides of the political aisle agree on, and they still disagree. But the one thing they do agree on is that big tech. There are problems on both sides. Jim Jordan today was very adamant about pointing out issues of bias that have been alleged against these big tech companies and the double standard that does exist when it comes to free speech on their platforms.

And I have to say, you know, Mark Zuckerberg says we're not going to regulate speech. We're -- arbiters of truth. But they actually kind of -- they cop out, because they hire, quote, "fact-checkers" from, like, the Associated Press or the New York Times that are left-leaning publications to do to the fact-checking for them. And then those posts are then flagged in the pages that they are on are flagged.

And they are limited in terms of their views. So this idea that they don't actually regulate what goes on their platforms isn't necessarily true. But I also don't know if the government is the way to fix this, especially considering how today went. And they always think that they're better than everyone that they're smarter than their witnesses. Today was a show that is not necessarily true.

PERINO: Not true. All right, coming up, a massive teachers union says its members will not go back to school until its demands are met. Wait until you hear what they are asking for.

GUTFELD: As America struggles with COVID, rising crime, and riots, it's nice that the teachers unions are helping out, I kid. And their demand for reopening schools, the United Teachers of LA, a union for public school teachers, has included, surprise, de-funding the police, and a shutdown of publicly-funded, privately-operated charter schools.

Now, these go beyond what normal unions demand. Worse, they use this crisis to preserve their power by destroying those who won't conform, by trying to shutdown charter schools they are demanding the elimination of any competition and depriving desperate poor families of an education that might change kids' lives. This speaks to the real truth of a big American problem.

It's not systemic racism. It's not systemically corrupt education system. It's the teachers union, led by leftists, whose only goal is to cancel competition that might reveal their incompetence. And so at the start of life, poor students are placed in the system where no matter how many billions of tax dollars are shovelled into it, it just gets worse.

The students don't stand a chance. And the unions prefer it that way. Yet, charter schools produce better educated kids with a far better head start in life. You think that would be embraced, but the price of union success is student failure. Once we see the results of charter schools, we realize the cause of all our inequalities isn't racism. It's the scandalous lack of choices.

Left for poor blacks, poor whites, poor everyone, victimized by urban liberals, so these kids begin their lives in a whole, a whole that isn't a grave, but might as well be one, at least for their futures. Dana, how can a union make these demands? I mean, isn't this just basically symbolic crap?

PERINO: Well, I think partly it's that the unions are not serving the teachers or the students well, and this happens often when you have a union that wants to get involved in other political matters like de-funding the police. And this is really probably not the time to be doing an exercise in overreach because you've had people who have had to rethink everything, maybe their job, maybe where they live. Maybe you know how they live, and how they educate their kids.

Many school districts, including I believe down in Miami, they're pushing school back. They're starting later. They're going to start online, and then they're going to try to figure out a way to get into classrooms. I think people generally want their kids back in school, but they are really concerned about safety.

However, one of the things that this is also doing is make people think about how they educate their kids. And necessity is the mother of invention. And you have the opportunity now to say, wait, why do I have to do it this way? Maybe I could try it a different way. And you start to see the possibility of either homeschooling or little pods or people getting together.

Now that might leave behind, though, and there's a very real concern the lower income students that you were talking about. So that has to be a consideration. But I think that this pandemic is going to forever change the way that some parents decide to teach their kids at home.

GUTFELD: Juan, what could be their legitimate defense of wanting to defund charter schools?

WILLIAMS: Charter schools worked, and you just say that. I agree with it. You know, I say that generally, obviously, there are some charter schools that don't work. But I think in general, it's innovation and it forces the option to be made available to parents to say I like this school or I don't like this school, and it does away a lot with a lot of the kind of zip codes segregation, you know, where kids in better neighborhoods get better schools because they get more supplemental funding, more parent parental support.

You know, just picking up on what Dana was saying. One of the issues has to be that if you have innovation in the like, do poor kids. You know, oftentimes I say this with a sad, hard kids coming from single parent families where the mom may be an essential worker, a low income worker and not able to provide that kind of personal interaction with the kid during the day. Does that child there get left behind? That would have been me.

And I think that, you know, obviously, you can imagine how I feel, and I'm a big school choice proponent. Just one last thought though, Greg, on the opening of schools. I just want to make it clear that even people like the governor of New Jersey, Phil Murphy, a Democrat, Bill Gates, nobody is hardline, you know, conservative, but these people everybody wants schools open. It's just a matter of doing it safely.

Parents are hardwired to protect their children. Teachers, obviously have a stake in this. And I think we have to just work at it but we can -- we'll find a way.

GUTFELD: Speaking of which, I think we have taped Bill Gates and a couple of governors saying the very -- what Juan just said, if you want to play that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BILL GATES, CO-FOUNDER, MICROSOFT CORPORATION: I'm a big believer that for young children, the benefits in almost every location, particularly if you can protect the teachers, well, the benefits outweigh the costs. As you get up to age like 13 and higher, then you'll have to look at your locale to decide what you'll do with high schools.

And if they're not in and then you have to put massive effort into trying to get there to be continued learning online.

GOV. KRISTI NOEM (R-SD): The science is clear. Our kids need to be in school. For us, our kids are going back to school on time. We've had great -- definitely, they will definitely be in the classroom.

GOV. PHIL MURPHY (D-NJ): Every education expert we've spoken to over the past few months has confirmed that in-person education is critical. We must try to include at least some aspect of in-person education for our children this fall.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GUTFELD: Katie, feel free to either discuss that or the unions. Your pick.

PAVLICH: Well, that's the scientific path that everybody should be following when it comes to kids being in schools. But on the union side, it is just absolutely despicable that they're putting this laundry list of demands into the futures of America's kids when they claim that they actually, you know, care about them and pretend to care about them.

And it's the reason why a lot of teachers around the country have actually sued their governments which have forced them into these unions, because they don't want to be part of a political party and pay dues to those unions when they don't have the best interests of the kids in mind.

In terms of getting rid of the charter schools. They want to do that because charter schools present them with competition and force them to do better. And they don't want to do better, they just want to be paid for not doing their jobs, and they want to hold kids hostage for generations to come if this keeps going on.

GUTFELD: Jesse, the president of the American Federation -- Teachers Federation is going to be on "THE DAILY BRIEFING" tomorrow with Dana Perino to discuss this. I assume you will be tuning in and watching it.

WATTERS: As always. Also, Greg, did you dress like a middle school math teacher just to do this monologue?

GUTFELD: Yes, I did. This is a new shirt.

WATTERS: I mean, honest to goodness, you look like my middle school math teacher. Did you have sweat stains here too, and chalk in your hands? My God. You also dress like Bill Gates with the glasses and the sweater. Enough about you, Greg. This was a social justice shakedown.

Did you have any idea that teachers' union was this liberal? I mean, who wrote the demands, Omar? This is fanatical stuff here. No wonder that kids can riot better than they can read. I'm terrified of the teachers' union. I think they're the most hardcore union out there, but I can't say anything mean about them because I'll be attacked for going after teachers.

I just know that Trump just send them 100 billion. I hope that winds up in the right hands and not into some pockets of some administrators for fatter pensions and bonuses. I hope that goes to the right place.

GUTFELD: Yes, it's such a good point. If you may -- if you'd say something about the unions, they accuse you of going after teachers, and then you're an evil, evil person which I am. Up next, summer shark fears after a fatal attack and several beaches are forced to close.

WILLIAMS: Park shark panics sweeping the country after a woman is tragically killed in Maine. 63-year-old Julie Holowach was killed by a great white shark while swimming with her daughter. The shark reportedly threw her into the air during the deadly encounter. The kayaker who recovered the body describes the scene.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHARLIE WEMYSS-DUNN, SHARK ATTACK WITNESS: I was almost -- I was about to get in the water essentially because I still thought that it could be something like a boat propeller or some sort of accident like that. My wife is screaming at me not to get into water.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: The death is the first fatal shark attack in Maine's history, but it's the 13th unprovoked attack in the U.S. this year. And several beaches near New York City shut down after three shark sightings. Police now using helicopters to help spot them.

So Jesse, I didn't want to just like grab and pull out what little here I have left. I mean, we have the virus, now we have killer sharks, is a terminator coming next?

WATTERS: (AUDIO GAP) attack the United States pre-emptive war on (AUDIO GAP). I call Americans to join me in that fight. Two things here. First, I'm very sorry to hear about this tragedy and my heart goes out to the family. But you know, this is your typical summer ratings ploy by producer Megan Albano who thinks this is really hip and fun to do at this time of the year.

Last point is this. I am taking a pre-planned vacation to Maine next week. So everybody is aware of that in case I say something controversial the day before I go to Maine. I'm not in trouble.

WILLIAMS: All right, so Greg, let's ask you about that. Are you afraid to go to the beach? We see here in the -- in the statistics that you're more likely to get hit by a car to get cancer. What do you say?

GUTFELD: It's actually you probably would have a better chance of having a vending machine fall on you. (AUDIO GAP) in Maine, in Maine's history, so even like (AUDIO GAP) attack they've had in 200 years, I'm going to go in Jesse's side and say this is a ratings ploy on Megan Albano's behalf.

WILLIAMS: All right. Hey, Katie, I wanted to ask you, I have some suggestions. If you stay away from schools of fish, if you don't dress in dark colors and look like a seal, I think you're pretty safe. What do you think?

PAVLICH: Well, first, it's horrible that this woman was killed this way. But you're right, Juan. I mean, if there are seals around anywhere near the beach that you want to be swimming, I would say do not go in the water at all where there's fish food, meaning shark food, there will be sharks there and seals can be mistaken -- or humans can be mistaken for seals quite often. That's usually what these attacks end up being. So, number one tip, stay away from the shark food.

WILLIAMS: That's a good move. And Dana, just the final thing. The only news here is that some people say oh, it's warmer waters. That's why the sharks are coming in. What do you think?

PERINO: I discount that. Obviously -- we had an expert on the "DAILY BRIEFING" today, a shark expert who said this is -- it's a pretty typical year for shark attacks. We know that they happen. I do feel for the family because I imagine every time they close their eyes, they have a horrible image in their mind and I pray for them because like obviously we're going to talk about it because it is scary. That is why I don't ever go in past my ankles into the -- into the ocean, but I have great respect for everything that lives under the water.

WATTERS: You can swim can you, Dana?

PERINO: I can swim. I won't drown. I will go in a pool to swim but I can't go in the ocean.

WATTERS: OK, you can't swim.

WILLIAMS: All right guys, next up. This is big news, folks. Jesse has a hair news update next for you on THE FIVE.

PAVLICH: Welcome back. They say you never forget how to ride a bike, but what if you never learned? Some adults are using the pandemic as a good excuse to teach themselves how to ride without looking foolish or getting hurt. So Greg, you can keep your dignity if you only ride bikes inside.

GUTFELD: I don't understand how you become an adult without learning how to ride a bike. I mean, what did you do when you were a teenager? I guess -- I mean, I lived in the suburbs. So maybe in the city, you didn't have a bike. I just got an electric bike. And that is like, you don't ever need to ride another bike. Just get an electric bike. It's the best thing ever.

PAVLICH: Does it -- but Dana, is an electric bike really riding a bike? Does that count?

PERINO: It's basically a moped, I think. But I remember one of the sweetest things I ever saw at Central Park was an adult woman learning to ride a bike and the guy who was trying to teach her was so patient and so kind and she was so humiliated. But I watched it for a while and she got it and I thought this is a great thing.

And I see kids around here, four years old, riding a bike with no training wheels. Something is going on. Kids are learning earlier today.

PAVLICH: Juan, do you know how to ride a bike?

WILLIAMS: Oh yes. And you know, I remember teaching my kids. I took him down to the local high school track. And you know, because the surface there is a little bit softer. But that's the big difference between learning as a kid and learning as an adult is if you're a kid, it's a shorter distance to fall. Bumps and bruises are just part of life. But if you're an adult, you better get a helmet, you know.

PAVLICH: A helmet, elbow pads, knee pads, Jesse, all the things. Shouldn't these people get credit for trying something new, especially when the gyms are closed? They're trying to get their exercise.

WATTERS: Yes, I have a Jessie's friendly neighborhood dispute question. So I was riding a bike with my daughter the other day at the beach, and apparently she just ran over some other girl's foot with her bike. And she just said sorry and kept on pedaling. Shouldn't she have stopped turned around and walked back and apologize or was sorry while riding away good enough.

PAVLICH: She probably should have stopped to make sure her foot wasn't broken.

WATTERS: Oh, OK. Good to know.

PAVLICH: You should have stopped, Jesse, to make sure she's OK.

WATTERS: I didn't see it. I didn't see it.

PERINO: Yes, was she?

WATTERS: I didn't.

PAVLICH: All right, finally, everybody, we have breaking news today. It finally happened. Jesse's mullet is no more after fans of THE FIVE voted and told him to get it cut. Jesse is no longer looking like a Long Island version of Billy Ray Cyrus. So now the question is, what do we think of his new, new hair? Dana?

PERINO: I think it's still a little long.

WATTERS: Seriously? No, it's not. It's nice. It's nice. It's very nice.

PERINO: See how it lifts up in the back a little bit.

WATTERS: You know, shut up, everybody. My hair is fine.

PERINO: I have a prediction I'd like to make. I believe that --

PERINO: I think that's a trim, not a cut.

PERINO: I believe that after the haircut, I'm going to predict that Jesse will bring back wearing a tie on the Tuesday. The first -- right after Labor Day, the day after Labor Day, I predict Jesse will start wearing a tie again on the show.

WATTERS: Dana --

(CROSSTALK)

GUTFELD: Jesse reminds me of the local younger weatherman, who thinks he's kind of cool. He has a kind of a pseudo hip haircut and kind of goes to the bars at night at the local affiliate bar near the -- near the station and just hangs out.

WATTERS: Why don't you teach me some long division, Gutfeld?

WILLIAMS: So, Jesse, Jesse, I approve of your haircut. I think you look really clean.

PAVLICH: Juan, do you think that he should cut it?

WILLIAMS: Yes. Well, you know, I was getting worried. I didn't want dreadlocks. I tell you that.

WATTERS: Don't worry. That's not my scene.

PAVLICH: Well, I would have I would have voted no for cutting. I want to see how far this is going to go.

WATTERS: Thank you, Katie.

PAVLICH: But we'll just have to see if you can keep crawling it out.

WATTERS: Thank you.

PAVLICH: All right," ONE MORE THING" up next.

WATTERS: It's time now for "ONE MORE THING." Dana.

PERINO: America lost one of its great -- her great patriots yesterday. I want to take a moment to celebrate the life of someone you might recognize here. Granny Rich, the grandmother of John Rich, our colleague and our friend. Granny rich passed away yesterday. She was 88-years-old. You might know that she was a part of John Rich's Instagram, and his Twitter feed, and he was -- she was also a big part of the wonderful whiskey, Redneck Riviera Whiskey that John Rich and his granny put out.

She was a wonderful woman, a good friend to America, and she will be greatly missed. And we're sorry for your loss John.

WATTERS: Granny Rich, one of the best grandmother names I've ever heard. Juan Williams

WILLIAMS: Well, God bless, John. I hope you're OK. Keep your head to the sky, folks. You never know when good times are coming. Take a look at eight-year-old Ryan Senneff. He has Down Syndrome and from birth he struggled with health issues including speaking. But now, as you can see there, here comes the sun.

In the last month with therapy and medical help, Ryan had a breakthrough. He started skipping, doing jumping jacks, tying his shoes, and speaking more easily. And watch this. Here's Ryan telling his dad he's so proud of him for skipping next to him.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RYAN SENNEFF, HAS DOWN SYNDROME: I'm so proud of you.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm so proud of you.

SENNEFF: I'm so proud of you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: That's pretty wonderful. I'm sure Ryan is proud of his mom too.

WATTERS: Kids are working out more than I am these days.

PAVLICH: That's sweet.

WATTERS: I better get back after it. All right, Katie.

PAVLICH: All right. Well, music can have an interesting effect not just on humans but on animals as well. Take a look at this.

This was a deer in Canada drawn in by this musician's harp playing. Her name -- her name is Naomi and she was practicing outside as the deer just got a little closer to hear her concert. She said that she got a little bit scared not knowing what it was but said next time she hopes that rabbits and squirrels decided to stop by. So good job Naomi, concert in the woods.

WATTERS: That's what Greg goes up by the lake just serenades animals all day.

PERINO: With heavy metal.

PAVLICH: They love his music.

GUTFELD: I'm going to bring -- I'm going to bring a harp next time I go hunting. It'll be great. Check out my podcast with Walter Kirn. You go to FoxNewsPodcast.com. He interviews me over -- I'm sure you know the topic, The Plus.

WATTERS: The Plus, there it is. All right, "SPECIAL REPORT" is up next with Mike.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WJC-1081-JCDY-T0F1-00000-00President welcomes his Web friends, targets tech2019-07-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:40ZLexisNexisA sectionPg. A01President welcomes his Web friends, targets techTony Romm

Some of Trump's fiercest backers join in alleging Silicon Valley political bias

President Trump assailed Facebook, Google and Twitter on Thursday - accusing them of exhibiting "terrible bias" and silencing his supporters - at a White House "Social Media Summit" that critics chastised for giving a prominent stage to some of the Internet's most controversial, incendiary voices.

For Trump, the conference represented his highest-profile broadside against Silicon Valley after months of accusations that tech giants censor conservative users and websites. With it, the president also rallied his widely followed online allies - whom he described as "journalists and influencers" and who together can reach roughly half a billion people - entering the 2020 presidential election.

"Some of you are extraordinary. The crap you think of is unbelievable," Trump said.

Trump delivered his diatribe against Facebook, Google and Twitter - charges of political bias that all three companies long have denied - at a White House event featuring Republican lawmakers, GOP campaign strategists and social media meme-makers, a move that led some critics to express dismay that the president aimed to use the policy summit as a reelection push.

But Democratic lawmakers and watchdog groups said they were most alarmed that Trump had invited supporters who have a history of targeting the president's political opponents with inflammatory tweets, misleading videos and hard-to-debunk conspiracy theories. At one point, the president praised James O'Keefe, the founder of Project Veritas, which has released widely criticized, highly edited videos of his subjects.

"Somebody said he's controversial," Trump said. "He's truthful."

In response, critics fretted that Trump had essentially endorsed such tactics in the early days of the 2020 presidential race.

"This has the appearance not of a social media summit but a political rally and call for the right," said Sen. Mark R. Warner (D-Va.). "The fact that some of the most extreme voices on social media are coming to the White House, and they get a forum to complain about how often they're retweeted, and that the actual platform companies aren't even invited, smacks of the absurd."

The Southern Poverty Law Center charged that the president is "essentially conducting a hate summit at the White House," said Heidi Beirich, the director of the group's work to track online extremism.

Facebook, Google and Twitter each declined to comment.

For much of the summit, Twitter appeared to be down, an outage the company said it was investigating. Outside the gathering, Trump's aides appeared to line the hallways with poster boards calling attention to the tech industry's alleged tactics for suppressing conservatives' speech - along with at least one tweet from Trump calling himself "the best" at using the service.

And Trump threatened additional scrutiny to come, promising to bring big tech companies to Washington for an upcoming meeting while directing federal agencies to explore "all regulatory and legislative solutions to protect free speech."

Trump has skewered Facebook, Google and Twitter for months on allegations that they are biased against conservatives, even accusing them of trying to rig the election. In March, for example, he said the companies had engaged in "collusion" and worked in opposition to a "certain group of people that happen to be in power, that happen to have won the election." Repeatedly, the president also has threatened to investigate or regulate Facebook, Google and Twitter, sparking hearings and similar calls for tough new laws among Republicans on Capitol Hill.

Trump has not provided evidence for his allegations that the tech companies seek to undermine Republicans or U.S. elections, and some of the examples he has cited to illustrate industry bias have been debunked. For example, the president has accused Twitter of tampering with his follower count, a charge he repeated Thursday. The company long has said that users with large followings often experience fluctuations as it removes spam.

"A lot of bad things are happening," he said.

Trump's attacks often have come in response to efforts by Facebook, Google and Twitter to remove hate speech, threats of violence and other troubling content from their platforms. These tech giants have been under pressure to address a litany of online ills, including the rise of disinformation, three years after Russian agents spread falsehoods on social media during the 2016 election. But Trump and his close allies have decried some social media content-moderation policies as censorship, putting those companies in a political bind.

"This is largely, I think, a political event," said Michael Beckerman, the president of the Internet Association, a Washington-based trade group that represents Facebook, Google and other tech giants. He said there is "no conservative bias on our platforms."

Some of the conservatives that Trump consulted Thursday have adopted controversial tactics on social media and even have been disciplined by Facebook, Google or Twitter for running afoul of their rules. That includes O'Keefe and Project Veritas, whose secretly recorded video of Google drew Trump's praise Thursday.

"Project Veritas can be synergistic with the Trump administration to pull back the curtain surrounding Big Tech," O'Keefe said in a statement online after receiving the invitation.

Other attendees included Ali Alexander, who sent the initial, inflammatory tweet questioning whether Sen. Kamala D. Harris (D-Calif.), a Democratic presidential candidate, is actually an "American black," and Jim Hoft, the Gateway Pundit founder who has long been faulted for spreading conspiracy theories online.

"After the 2016 election Google, Facebook, Twitter, Amazon (in advertising) decided the best way to prevent another Trump win was to silence conservative voices in America," according to a statement from the Gateway Pundit site. "The tech giants in two years did more to destroy Freedom of Speech than at any other time in US history."

Initially, the White House had invited Ben Garrison, whose cartoons long have provoked the ire of groups including the Anti-Defamation League and Southern Poverty Law Center for including hateful imagery, including anti-Semitism. But the White House this week appeared to rescind its invitation, Garrison tweeted in a statement Wednesday, out of concern his presence would be a "media distraction from the president's message."

Trump also invited lawmakers such as Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-Fla.) and Sen. Marsha Blackburn (R-Tenn.) who have accused Twitter of limiting the reach of their tweets. They were joined by organizations such as the Media Research Center, a conservative group that has called for the breakup of big tech companies, and PragerU, which produces right-leaning videos that it says Google has censored - a matter the two sides are battling in court.

In an early-morning series of tweets, Trump said that the focus of the conversation would be "the tremendous dishonesty, bias, discrimination and suppression practiced by certain companies," though he did not mention any by name. "We will not let them get away with it much longer," he added.

Trump also appeared to suggest social media sites "would be driven out of business" once he leaves office in six years - or more, acknowledging he had made a joke about exceeding presidential term limits.

Some lawmakers bristled at the summit, saying that the Trump administration had missed an opportunity to explore real challenges facing social media ahead of the 2020 election, amid heightened fears about the spread of hate speech and even harder-to-detect viral falsehoods.

"It's not surprising that one of the loudest disseminators of misinformation is inviting known extremists and conspiracy theory peddlers to the White House social media summit," tweeted Rep. Frank Pallone Jr. (D-N.J.), who leads the House's top tech committee. "It's a shame President Trump would prefer to fan the same fires of online social discord that Russia sparked in the 2016 election rather than bring real experts together to address the issue of content moderation in a thoughtful and rational manner."

tony.romm@washpost.com

urn:contentItem:5WJC-50S1-DXXY-30F1-00000-00President welcomes his Web friends, targets tech2019-07-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:39ZLexisNexisA-SECTIONPg. A01Every ZonePresident welcomes his Web friends, targets techTony Romm

Some of Trump's fiercest backers join in alleging Silicon Valley political bias

President Trump assailed Facebook, Google and Twitter on Thursday - accusing them of exhibiting "terrible bias" and silencing his supporters - at a White House "Social Media Summit" that critics chastised for giving a prominent stage to some of the Internet's most controversial, incendiary voices.

For Trump, the conference represented his highest-profile broadside against Silicon Valley after months of accusations that tech giants censor conservative users and websites. With it, the president also rallied his widely followed online allies - whom he described as "journalists and influencers" and who together can reach roughly half a billion people - entering the 2020 presidential election.

"Some of you are extraordinary. The crap you think of is unbelievable," Trump said.

Trump delivered his diatribe against Facebook, Google and Twitter - charges of political bias that all three companies long have denied - at a White House event featuring Republican lawmakers, GOP campaign strategists and social media meme-makers, a move that led some critics to express dismay that the president aimed to use the policy summit as a reelection push.

But Democratic lawmakers and watchdog groups said they were most alarmed that Trump had invited supporters who have a history of targeting the president's political opponents with inflammatory tweets, misleading videos and hard-to-debunk conspiracy theories. At one point, the president praised James O'Keefe, the founder of Project Veritas, which has released widely criticized, highly edited videos of his subjects.

"Somebody said he's controversial," Trump said. "He's truthful."

In response, critics fretted that Trump had essentially endorsed such tactics in the early days of the 2020 presidential race.

"This has the appearance not of a social media summit but a political rally and call for the right," said Sen. Mark R. Warner (D-Va.). "The fact that some of the most extreme voices on social media are coming to the White House, and they get a forum to complain about how often they're retweeted, and that the actual platform companies aren't even invited, smacks of the absurd."

The Southern Poverty Law Center charged that the president is "essentially conducting a hate summit at the White House," said Heidi Beirich, the director of the group's work to track online extremism.

Facebook, Google and Twitter each declined to comment.

For much of the summit, Twitter appeared to be down, an outage the company said it was investigating. Outside the gathering, Trump's aides appeared to line the hallways with poster boards calling attention to the tech industry's alleged tactics for suppressing conservatives' speech - along with at least one tweet from Trump calling himself "the best" at using the service.

And Trump threatened additional scrutiny to come, promising to bring big tech companies to Washington for an upcoming meeting while directing federal agencies to explore "all regulatory and legislative solutions to protect free speech."

Trump has skewered Facebook, Google and Twitter for months on allegations that they are biased against conservatives, even accusing them of trying to rig the election. In March, for example, he said the companies had engaged in "collusion" and worked in opposition to a "certain group of people that happen to be in power, that happen to have won the election." Repeatedly, the president also has threatened to investigate or regulate Facebook, Google and Twitter, sparking hearings and similar calls for tough new laws among Republicans on Capitol Hill.

Trump has not provided evidence for his allegations that the tech companies seek to undermine Republicans or U.S. elections, and some of the examples he has cited to illustrate industry bias have been debunked. For example, the president has accused Twitter of tampering with his follower count, a charge he repeated Thursday. The company long has said that users with large followings often experience fluctuations as it removes spam.

"A lot of bad things are happening," he said.

Trump's attacks often have come in response to efforts by Facebook, Google and Twitter to remove hate speech, threats of violence and other troubling content from their platforms. These tech giants have been under pressure to address a litany of online ills, including the rise of disinformation, three years after Russian agents spread falsehoods on social media during the 2016 election. But Trump and his close allies have decried some social media content-moderation policies as censorship, putting those companies in a political bind.

"This is largely, I think, a political event," said Michael Beckerman, the president of the Internet Association, a Washington-based trade group that represents Facebook, Google and other tech giants. He said there is "no conservative bias on our platforms."

Some of the conservatives that Trump consulted Thursday have adopted controversial tactics on social media and even have been disciplined by Facebook, Google or Twitter for running afoul of their rules. That includes O'Keefe and Project Veritas, whose secretly recorded video of Google drew Trump's praise Thursday.

"Project Veritas can be synergistic with the Trump administration to pull back the curtain surrounding Big Tech," O'Keefe said in a statement online after receiving the invitation.

Other attendees included Ali Alexander, who sent the initial, inflammatory tweet questioning whether Sen. Kamala D. Harris (D-Calif.), a Democratic presidential candidate, is actually an "American black," and Jim Hoft, the Gateway Pundit founder who has long been faulted for spreading conspiracy theories online.

"After the 2016 election Google, Facebook, Twitter, Amazon (in advertising) decided the best way to prevent another Trump win was to silence conservative voices in America," according to a statement from the Gateway Pundit site. "The tech giants in two years did more to destroy Freedom of Speech than at any other time in US history."

Initially, the White House had invited Ben Garrison, whose cartoons long have provoked the ire of groups including the Anti-Defamation League and Southern Poverty Law Center for including hateful imagery, including anti-Semitism. But the White House this week appeared to rescind its invitation, Garrison tweeted in a statement Wednesday, out of concern his presence would be a "media distraction from the president's message."

Trump also invited lawmakers such as Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-Fla.) and Sen. Marsha Blackburn (R-Tenn.) who have accused Twitter of limiting the reach of their tweets. They were joined by organizations such as the Media Research Center, a conservative group that has called for the breakup of big tech companies, and PragerU, which produces right-leaning videos that it says Google has censored - a matter the two sides are battling in court.

In an early-morning series of tweets, Trump said that the focus of the conversation would be "the tremendous dishonesty, bias, discrimination and suppression practiced by certain companies," though he did not mention any by name. "We will not let them get away with it much longer," he added.

Trump also appeared to suggest social media sites "would be driven out of business" once he leaves office in six years - or more, acknowledging he had made a joke about exceeding presidential term limits.

Some lawmakers bristled at the summit, saying that the Trump administration had missed an opportunity to explore real challenges facing social media ahead of the 2020 election, amid heightened fears about the spread of hate speech and even harder-to-detect viral falsehoods.

"It's not surprising that one of the loudest disseminators of misinformation is inviting known extremists and conspiracy theory peddlers to the White House social media summit," tweeted Rep. Frank Pallone Jr. (D-N.J.), who leads the House's top tech committee. "It's a shame President Trump would prefer to fan the same fires of online social discord that Russia sparked in the 2016 election rather than bring real experts together to address the issue of content moderation in a thoughtful and rational manner."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WK3-07B1-DY0W-40BX-00000-00President Works with Democrats; Trump's Priorities Questioned; Votes on DACA and Tax Reform; Scrutiny from Capitol Hill; Company Regulations;2017-09-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:40ZLexisNexisPresident Works with Democrats; Trump's Priorities Questioned; Votes on DACA and Tax Reform; Scrutiny from Capitol Hill; Company Regulations;LanhamFULL TEXT

CHRIS WALLACE, FOX NEWS HOST: I'm Chris Wallace.

North Korea fires another missile while London is hit by a terror attack, as President Trump prepares to take the world stage and address the U.N.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

REX TILLERSON, U.S. STATE SECRETARY: North Korea is now a global threat and it requires a global response.

LT. GEN. H.R. MCMASTER, NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISOR: We've been kicking the can down the road and we're out of road.

NIKKI HALEY, U.S. AMBASSADOR TO THE UNITED NATIONS: I have no problem kicking it to General Mattis because I think he has plenty of options.

WALLACE (voice-over): We'll discuss foreign hot spot and preview the president's message at the international community on North Korea, Iran and terror with national security advisor, General H.R. McMaster.

Then, does President Trump have an immigration deal with Chuck and Nancy or not?

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY), MINORITY LEADER: We have reached an understanding on this issue. We have to work out details.

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA), MINORITY LEADER: We have an agreement to move forward.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The wall to me is vital. If I don't get the wall, then we will become the obstruction.

WALLACE: We'll break down the DACA discussion and whether there's a new balance of power in Washington with two Senate leaders, Democrat Dick Durbin and Republican Roy Blunt.

Plus, big tech comes under fire. We'll ask our Sunday panel about how Russia used Facebook in the 2016 election.

And our power player of the week, breaking barriers while keeping some of the sports biggest stars in the game.

(on camera): What does it mean to you to be the first female head doctor in the history of both Major League Baseball and the NFL?

WALLACE (voice-over): All, right now, on FOX NEWS SUNDAY.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WALLACE: And hello again from FOX News in Washington.

The United Nations General Assembly has been called the super bowl of diplomacy. And this week, President Trump goes to New York to join other world leaders there for the first time. With plenty of hot spots to discuss, what will the president focus on and what action will he seek?

Joining us live here in Washington, the president's national security advisor, General H.R. McMaster.

General, welcome back to FOX NEWS SUNDAY.

MCMASTER: Thanks, Chris, great to be here.

WALLACE: As we say, President Trump speaks to the U.N. General Assembly on Tuesday, his first time on that stage. How important does he think the speech is and how will he fit it into his appeal to world leaders into his doctrine of America First?

MCMASTER: Well, he thinks the speech is a tremendous opportunity obviously to reach so many world leaders at the same time and to emphasize really three things. First is to protect the American people, the second is to promote American prosperity, and the third is really to help promote accountability and sovereignty. And in those three things will allow him to communicate his vision for America's role in the world, but also what his expectations are for international bodies like the United Nations, but also of other nations -- the expectation that they are up to protect the sovereignty of their citizens and respect the sovereignty of other nations.

WALLACE: Well, let's unpack that and let's start with issue number one. And that, of course, is North Korea. The president tweeted about that this morning. Let's put it up on the screen.

The president said: I spoke with President Moon of South Korea last night, asked him -- excuse me -- asked him how Rocket Man is doing. Long gas lines forming in North Korea. Too bad.

Well, before I get to the substance, Rocket Man, have you heard that from the president before or is that a new one?

MCMASTER: Well, that's a new one and I think maybe for the president, but it reminds me of a cover of the "Economist" a few years ago, portraying him as Rocket Man. But, of course, that's where the rockets are coming from. Rockets, though, we ought to probably not laugh too much about because they do represent a great threat to all -- to everyone.

WALLACE: All right. But let me --

MCMASTER: As Secretary Tillerson said at the outset, it is a global problem.

WALLACE: Let's pick up on that, here's what you had to say on Friday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MCMASTER: We've been kicking the can down the road and we're out of road. And so, for those who have said, and have been commenting about the lack of a military option, there is a military option.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WALLACE: General, what does that mean, out of road? The fact is you want to get sanctions more time. You're not about to go to war.

MCMASTER: Well, really, it really depends on how we see this threat continue to manifest itself and our judgment about how much time we have. We're out of road because in the past, the approach taken to the problem of North Korea and the Kim regime over decades has been to enter into long, drawn out negotiations that then deliver an unsatisfactory agreement, an agreement that then the North Korean regime breaks.

And what that agreement does, though, that's particularly dangerous oftentimes, what has all the time in the past is locked in the status quo as the new normal. And this regime is so close now to threatening the United States and others with a nuclear weapon that we really have to move with a great deal of urgency on sanctions, on diplomacy, and on preparing, if necessary, a military option.

WALLACE: So, how do you draw that line? How do you decide we've reached the point that we have to move to a military option now? How long do you get sanctions?

MCMASTER: Well, the president has asked all of us to work on this. So, we can't really talk about specific timelines or what conclusions we are coming to.

But we are working very hard, very hard to make everything we are doing militarily, diplomatic -- diplomatically, economically, and with our allies and partners to be as effective as we can. And what we recognize is not really much time.

WALLACE: All right. The administration -- I want to pick up on one part of that. The administration talks about getting tough with North Korea's trading partners.

Here's Treasury Secretary Mnuchin this week.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, TREASURY SECRETARY: We will use economic sanctions to bring North Korea to the table.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS HOST: You're saying stopping trade with China?

MNUCHIN: Stopping trade with anybody. Nobody would be off the table.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WALLACE: But the U.S. did $648 billion of trade with China. They're our single largest supplier for imported goods and our third largest market for export of goods.

General, we're not about to cut off trade with China. It would crater our economy.

MCMASTER: Well, this is an indication, isn't it, of how serious this problem is with North Korea, and why it's in all of our interest to work together to resolve it. So, of course, we China to help as much as they can. You know, they have a great deal of coercive economic power over North Korea. And, certainly, we think -- and the Chinese agree -- it's in their interest to have a denuclearized peninsula.

WALLACE: But, I mean, let's be serious here. We're not going to cut off all trade with China.

MCMASTER: Well, they have to take some steps, though, that restrict trade in any way that we can with this regime, to choke off the resources that allowed this regime to continue to prioritize their military efforts, their missile efforts, their nuclear efforts over the well-being of their own people.

WALLACE: Well, let me just pick up on that, that one point, isn't it possible -- in fact, isn't it likely -- that Kim has decided that the key to his survival is to have a nuclear capability? He talked this week about having equilibrium with the U.S. and that there's nothing that can be done diplomatically, nothing that can be done economically that will stop him from pursuing that effort.

MCMASTER: Well, what he should conclude is the exactly opposite, that that continued pursuit of this nuclear capability makes him more and more vulnerable and makes him less and less secure.

WALLACE: Let's turn to another subject. The president is also going to talk about getting tougher on Iran at the United Nations. But this week, he had the opportunity to re-impose sanctions that were lifted as part of the nuclear deal. He didn't do that.

So, for all his talk about tearing up the agreement. I know he has to recertify in October whether or not they are complying with it, all this talk about tearing up the agreement, in fact, isn't he going to live with it and try to find other ways to confront Iran on other fronts?

MCMASTER: Well, we have to see what live with it means, right? Live with can't be giving this regime cover to develop a nuclear capability. And so, a lot of things have to happen immediately, rigorous enforcement of that agreement. It is under-enforced now. We know Iran has already violated parts of the agreement by --

WALLACE: But the IAEA says that they're complying with it, sir.

MCMASTER: Well, the IAEA has identified and we've identified some of these breaches that Iran has then corrected. But what does that tell you about Iranian behavior? They're not just walking up to the line on the agreement. They're crossing the line at times.

So, there has to be much more rigorous enforcement of the deal and we have to recognize the fundamental flaws in this deal. It is -- as the president said -- it is the worst deal. It gave all these benefits to the Iranian regime upfront and these benefits now they are using to foment this humanitarian catastrophe in the greater Middle East.

This broad range of destructive behavior, including support for terrorist organizations, like Hezbollah, support for proxy forces like 80 percent of the affected fighters fighting on the side of the brutal, murderous Assad regime in Syria are Iranian proxies.

And so, we have to -- we have to recognize the broad range of Iranian destabilizing behavior and we can't allow this deal to enable that. Their missile programs, for example, the way they are seeding this Iranian network with more and more destructive capability that places all their neighbors at risk.

WALLACE: I want to turn to that next subject which you brought up which is terror. The president is going to call at the U.N. for the world to continue its war on terror. Here's what he had to say this week.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We have done better in eight months of my presidency than the previous eight years against ISIS.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WALLACE: But, I don't have to tell you, a bomb went off in the London subway this week. That's the fifth terror attack in Great Britain just this year. And experts say, as we succeed, and we are succeeding, in pushing Iraq -- ISIS back in Iraq, shrinking its territory, it is only getting them to focus more on launching attacks in Europe and the U.S.

MCMASTER: Well, the president has told us we have to do three fundamental things very effectively.

The first is to ensure that these terrorists have no safe havens and support bases that allow them to organize, plan, and conduct attacks against us and against our allies.

The second thing is we have to cut off the financing, the way that they resource these kinds of operations.

And the third, we have to defeat their evil ideology. And this has a lot to do with some of Prime Minister May's top priorities, which is to constrict their ability to use the ability to communicate with each other.

And then, of course, none of this is a substitute for important law enforcement actions across the world and improving even further our ability to share information and to gain visibility of these terrorist networks and defeat them.

WALLACE: There is a report this weekend, I'm sure you read, that says that President Trump has decided he's not going to pull out of the Paris climate accord, that we may reduce our commitment to curb greenhouse gas emissions but he's going to live with the agreement, stay in the agreement with a reduced commitment.

Is that true, sir?

MCMASTER: No, it's false. That's a false report. The president decided to pull out of the Paris Accord because it was a bad deal for the American people and because it was a bad deal for the environment. It gave the worst polluters the ability to continue polluting and emitting carbon without significantly reducing those levels.

The president is committed to the cleanest water on Earth, the cleanest air on Earth, to an energy policy that reduces carbon emissions but then also provides clean fossil fuels to generate growth in this country and globally. And these priorities he felt we could not pursue effectively within this flawed agreement.

WALLACE: So, he's out of the Paris Climate Accord?

MCMASTER: He's out of the Paris Climate Accord. What he said, the door is open. If you look at what he said on the day that he announced withdrawing from the accord, he said, at some point in the future, if there can be, if there can be a ideal that addresses these some fundamental flaws --

(CROSSTALK)

WALLACE: But the allies said they're not going to renegotiate.

MCMASTER: Well, the president's ears are open, though, if at some point they decide that they can come forward with an agreement that addresses the president's very legitimate concerns about Paris.

WALLACE: OK. One final area. It's widely known in Washington that you and Steve Bannon have sharply different views of the world. One of the first things you did as national security advisor is kick him out as a regular official member of the NSC.

He has dismissed you and some of the other advisors on the NSC as globalists. He has sharply disagreed with the decision to commit, to double down in Afghanistan.

Question: is the administration better off with Steve Bannon out of the White House?

MCMASTER: Well, the administration is better off when we can serve the president by integrating, coordinating across all of our departments and agencies with our key allies and partners and to present the president with multiple options. And then, based on his decisions, to help the president implement these policies that prioritize, protecting and advancing the interests of the American people.

And so, what's important is to have an inclusive process, not to try to manipulate into a particular decision or to advance your own agenda. You know, we're advancing the president's agenda and we are advancing policies and strategies that are for the American people.

WALLACE: Well, you strike is a pretty straight talker. Are you saying that Steve Bannon was manipulating, that he was trying to work around and advance his own agenda?

MCMASTER: Well, the National Security Council, I think, has served the president well in bringing him multiple options. There were some who try to operate outside of that process for their own narrow agendas, and that didn't serve the president well.

WALLACE: That some people, does that include Steve Bannon, sir?

MCMASTER: I think this has been too hyped on one individual. I mean, these reports of feuding, this really didn't even happen. I mean, we had our doors open to all perspectives within the National Security Council, and it was up to those individuals whether they would walk through that door and permit -- and participate in an open and transparent process.

WALLACE: General McMaster, thank you. Thanks for your time. You're a busy guy, we covered a lot of ground there in about 12 minutes.

MCMASTER: It's always a pleasure, Chris. Thank you.

WALLACE: Thank you. And we'll be watching the president's speech, of course, on Tuesday to the U.N., sir.

MCMASTER: Thank you.

WALLACE: Up next, we'll talk with two leading senators about the president's move to cut deals with Democrats. How long will it affect the Trump agenda and how long will it last?

WALLACE: President Trump had dinner with Democratic leaders Chuck and Nancy this week and they seem to have cooked up at least the outline of a deal on immigration that has many of the most devoted Trump supporters worried. Joining us from Chicago, Dick Durbin, the Senate's number two Democrat. And here in Washington, Republican Senator Roy Blunt.

Well, gentlemen, let's start with the big question here in Washington. The most immediate question, does President Trump have a deal with speaker -- former Speaker Pelosi and Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer when it comes to DACA or not?

And here's part of what was a shifting conversation on Thursday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The wall is going to be built, and it will be funded a little bit later.

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY), SENATE MINORITY LEADER: It was a very, very positive step for the president to commit to DACA protections without insisting on the inclusion of or even a debate about the border wall.

There was great pushback from the right. They didn't like the parameters of this understanding and there has been a lot of conversation since. But we are going forward. We are going forward with the understanding that we can work with the White House to come up with an agreement that includes DACA, that includes citizenship for those who are protected under the DREAM Act and also has a substantial commitment to increase border protection. Those are the two pillars of this understanding.

WALLACE: And very briefly, in this understanding do you believe that the president committed to those pillars over Chinese food on Wednesday night?

DURBIN: Yes.

WALLACE: That's pretty brief.

OK. Senator Blunt, the president seemed to walk away from at least the citizenship part of this deal later on Thursday. Let's take a look at that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We're not talking about amnesty at all. We have not talked about amnesty. There will be no amnesty. We're not talking about that as part of the transaction.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WALLACE: So, Senator, helpless clear this up, because -- I mean, there's genuine confusion here in Washington. Do you believe that there is a deal on these issues and is this something that Republican senators could support?

SEN. ROY BLUNT (R), MISSOURI: Well, I think there's a desire to come to a conclusion here on both sides and Senator Durbin just mentioned border security as part of the understanding, but the details haven't been worked out, another thing that he mentioned.

Well, the details here matter. You know, it's always been three separate questions in my view. One is, how do you secure the border? Two is, what are the legitimate workforce needs of the country? And three, what you do with people who came or stayed, or in the case of the DREAMers, were brought to the country illegally?

I think it would be very shortsighted not to try to do all we can to solve the first problem, and the president has unbelievable credibility here. If you solve the first problem, the other problems I think are reasonably solvable, we are seeing that to happen as people want to come together and deal with the issue who of kids who were brought here illegally.

But you're not going to be able to solve this problem in a satisfactory way unless you give the present at the leeway he needs to be able to some point in the future say the border is now operationally secure. That allows everybody to move to solve these other problems in a better way, Chris.

CHRIS WALLACE, FOX NEWS HOST: But, again, briefly, and I hope you will be as brief as Senator Durbin is, giving them leeway to secure the border, does that have to include funding for the wall, specifically funding for the wall as opposed to other measures, and secondly, citizenship for DREAMers?

BLUNT: It appears it would -- it would not preclude the wall, but it doesn't have to include the wall at this point I don't think. There are a lots of things have to happen to secure the border and should -- in terms of citizenship, does that mean you wouldn't have to take the test that everybody else takes? How long would you have to be here under the DREAM Act (ph)? There are lots of things that can and will be worked out there.

WALLACE: All right. Let's turn to the bigger issue, which is whether or not President Trump is forming a new alliance with congressional Democrats at the expense of Republicans. Here is what the president had to say about that on Air Force One.

(BEGIN AUDIO CLIP)

(END AUDIO CLIP)

WALLACE: Senator Blunt, given the failure of Senate Republicans to pass Obamacare repeal and replace, isn't it wise for this president to go to Democrats and look for some votes?

BLUNT: Well, I think the minority can't abuse the rules of the Senate. But under the rules of the Senate, you have to have some Democrats work with you to get most things done. The tenures -- I was either the chief deputy whip for the deputy whip in the House, we passed two bills in 10 years that didn't have Democrats vote for them. That's part of the work -- that's how you get the work done here in a way that allows everything else to move forward.

So, looking for Democrats on every bill is a good idea, but making it impossible to get your work done because you've lost your own side is not part of that either.

WALLACE: Senator Durbin, do you think that there is the potential for a real -- not permanent, but working alliance between President Trump and congressional Democrats? And what you say to those members -- folks on the left who don't trust this president and don't trust making deals with him?

SEN. DICK DURBIN (D-IL), SENATE MINORITY WHIP: Well, of course, there will be people on the right and left who will be critical. But Senator Roy Blunt and I are good examples of how this can work. I have joined him and applauded his leadership in dramatically increasing biomedical research in the United States on a bipartisan basis. Lamar Alexander, Patty Murray joined us.

Two weeks ago, Schumer and Pelosi sat down with the president and the other leaders and said, we can help you move immediately for Hurricane Harvey assistance, to have a short-term spending bill so the government doesn't shut down and to extend the debt ceiling of the United States, we'll do it on a bipartisan basis, Mr. President. That's what American wants. And the president said, I'll take it.

We did it. And we can do more like that, as long as we trust one another, respect the differences that we obviously do have, but try to work toward a goal. Patty Murray and Lamar Alexander have accomplished more in the last two weeks of strengthening our health care system and moving forward to make the Affordable Care Act more affordable and more transparent than we achieved in seven months of partisan wrangling on the floor of the Senate. WALLACE: But there are some differences. I mean, you talked for instance about NIH spending, the Trump administration wants to cut NIH spending.
